"dc:creator": {"author": [{"@auid": "55355866000", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Vacca K.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/55355866000", "ce:initials": "K.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/117304677", "@id": "117304677"}, "ce:surname": "Vacca", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Vacca K.", "ce:given-name": "K.", "ce:surname": "Vacca", "ce:initials": "K."}}]}, "dc:publisher": "Water Environment Federation", "prism:issn": "15547531", "prism:url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84985916943", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84985916943", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84985916943&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus-citedby", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84985916943&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016, Water Environment Federation. All rights reserved. Constructed stormwater wetlands (CSWs) reduce stormwater volume and improve water quality. One quality improvement is the removal of soluble reactive phosphorus (SRP). There has been limited study on SRP fate and transport or on the mechanisms to improve SRP removal due to the difficulty in quantifying the complex, spatially heterogeneous removal processes in two-dimensional flow. The present research analyzed the ability of wetland soil (Control) and wetland soil amended with 2%, 5%, and 8% (by mass) of aluminum-based water treatment residuals (AlWTRs) to remove SRP in surface-flow vegetated CSW mesocosms. Batch adsorption experiments showed increasing SRP sorption capacity with increased AlWTR content (590-850 mg/kg soil) compared to the Control (385 mg/kg soil); however, AlWTR-amended flowing mesocosms removed only 6.0-8.8 mg/kg SRP compared to 9.3 mg/kg SRP for the Control. The lack of increased SRP removal in AlWTR-amended mesocosms was attributed to flow dynamics (only 20% of the surface outflow was quantified as subsurface flow). These results suggest the extent of infiltration versus surface flow is key to soil amendments improving SRP removal in a CSW.", "source-id": "24563", "eid": "2-s2.0-84985916943"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": "55355866000", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Vacca K.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/55355866000", "ce:initials": "K.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/117304677", "@id": "117304677"}, "ce:surname": "Vacca", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Vacca K.", "ce:given-name": "K.", "ce:surname": "Vacca", "ce:initials": "K."}}, {"@auid": "35236970600", "@seq": "2", "ce:indexed-name": "Komlos J.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/35236970600", "ce:initials": "J.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60000009", "@id": "60000009"}, "ce:surname": "Komlos", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Komlos J.", "ce:given-name": "J.", "ce:surname": "Komlos", "ce:initials": "J."}}, {"@auid": "12242771000", "@seq": "3", "ce:indexed-name": "Wadzuk B.M.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/12242771000", "ce:initials": "B.M.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60000009", "@id": "60000009"}, "ce:surname": "Wadzuk", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Wadzuk B.", "ce:given-name": "B. "classification-description": "Surface Water"}, {"classification-code": "452.1", "classification-description": "Sewage"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "79.25", "classification-description": "WATER ENGINEERING"}}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2304"}, {"$": "2205"}, {"$": "2312"}, {"$": "2300"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "ENVI"}, {"$": "ENGI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 American Society of Civil Engineers. For highly urbanized watersheds where space is limited, distributed low impact development (LID) stormwater controls could offer an effective retrofit to address flooding problems. The goal of this study is to determine the feasibility of using distributed LID controls within an urbanized watershed for flood mitigation. The Rocky Branch Watershed in Columbia, South Carolina, is an excellent case study because it experiences flash floods almost annually and has limited space for traditional, centralized stormwater controls to mitigate these floods. The Storm Water Management Model (SWMM) was used to model flooding with rain gardens as the LID approach for flood mitigation owing to their storage potential. The results of the study suggest that rain gardens with 30-cm berm heights and a total area equal to 20% of the impervious surfaces within the watershed should provide sufficient storage to mitigate flooding for rain events up to and including a 10-year storm event. Once sufficient storage is available, the challenge is diverting runoff generated from impervious surfaces into rain gardens. The results of this study suggest approximately 15, 27, and 38% of the runoff generated from impervious surfaces should be diverted to rain gardens to mitigate flooding from 2-, 5-, and 10-year storm events, respectively. Given prior work on the adoption of LID approaches for other watersheds, rain gardens could be effective at mitigating up to a 5-year storm event within the watershed, although further research on possible adoption rates in the study watershed is needed to more fully support this conclusion."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1061/(ASCE)HE.1943-5584.0001430", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "612957757"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "657521887"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20164402967232"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016699903"}, {"@idtype": "FLX", "$": "1239359"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "5025390"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20162209493"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84992469981"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84992469981"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "FLX"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "01", "@month": "11", "@timestamp": "BST 07:02:35", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "40", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "434", "@last": "443"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Abi Aad M.P.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Abi Aad", "ce:initials": "M.P."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Suidan M.T.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Suidan", "ce:initials": "M.T."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Shuster W.D.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Shuster", "ce:initials": "W.D."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2010"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "77954006094"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "\"Modeling techniques of best management practices: Rain barrels and rain gardens using EPA SWMM-5\""}, "ref-sourcetitle": "J. "SCOPUS_ID:84992469981", "prism:issueIdentifier": "11", "dc:title": "Distributed stormwater controls for flood mitigation within urbanized watersheds: Case study of Rocky Branch Watershed in Columbia, South Carolina", "prism:doi": "10.1061/(ASCE)HE.1943-5584.0001430", "intid": "84992469981", "source-id": "16284", "prism:aggregationType": "Journal", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84992469981", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84992469981&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus-citedby", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84992469981&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "eid": "2-s2.0-84992469981", "prism:publicationName": "Journal of Hydrologic Engineering", "dc:creator": {"author": [{"@auid": "56425599300", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Morsy M.M.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/56425599300", "ce:initials": "M.M.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60021918", "@id": "60021918"}, "ce:given-name": "Mohamed M.", "ce:surname": "Morsy", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Morsy M.", "ce:given-name": "Mohamed M.", "ce:surname": "Morsy", "ce:initials": "M.M."}, "ce:degrees": "S.M.ASCE"}]}, "dc:publisher": "American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) onlinejls@asce.org", "prism:issn": "10840699", "prism:url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84992469981", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016 American Society of Civil Engineers. For highly urbanized watersheds where space is limited, distributed low impact development (LID) stormwater controls could offer an effective retrofit to address flooding problems. The goal of this study is to determine the feasibility of using distributed LID controls within an urbanized watershed for flood mitigation. The Rocky Branch Watershed in Columbia, South Carolina, is an excellent case study because it experiences flash floods almost annually and has limited space for traditional, centralized stormwater controls to mitigate these floods. The Storm Water Management Model (SWMM) was used to model flooding with rain gardens as the LID approach for flood mitigation owing to their storage potential. The results of the study suggest that rain gardens with 30-cm berm heights and a total area equal to 20% of the impervious surfaces within the watershed should provide sufficient storage to mitigate flooding for rain events up to and including a 10-year storm event. Once sufficient storage is available, the challenge is diverting runoff generated from impervious surfaces into rain gardens. The results of this study suggest approximately 15, 27, and 38% of the runoff generated from impervious surfaces should be diverted to rain gardens to mitigate flooding from 2-, 5-, and 10-year storm events, respectively. Given prior work on the adoption of LID approaches for other watersheds, rain gardens could be effective at mitigating up to a 5-year storm event within the watershed, although further research on possible adoption rates in the study watershed is needed to more fully support this conclusion.", "article-number": "05016025", "srctype": "j"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": "56425599300", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Morsy M.M.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/56425599300", "ce:initials": "M.M.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60021918", "@id": "60021918"}, "ce:given-name": "Mohamed M.", "ce:surname": "Morsy", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Morsy M.", "ce:given-name": "Mohamed M.", "ce:surname": "Morsy", "ce:initials": "M.M."}, "ce:degrees": "S.M.ASCE"}, {"@auid": "9841782300", "@seq": "2", "ce:indexed-name": "Goodall J.L.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/9841782300", "ce:initials": "J.L.", "affiliation": [{"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60021918", [{"$": "2305"}, {"$": "2312"}]}, {"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "443.3", "classification-description": "Precipitation"}, {"classification-code": "444", "classification-description": "Water Resources"}, {"classification-code": "444.1", "classification-description": "Surface Water"}, {"classification-code": "483.1", "classification-description": "Soils and Soil Mechanics"}, {"classification-code": "943.3", "classification-description": "Special Purpose Instruments"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "79.25", "classification-description": "WATER ENGINEERING"}}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENVI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 ASCE. Rain gardens have proven to be an effective means to control stormwater; thus, in Pennsylvania's Stormwater Best Management Practice's Manual, rain gardens are the preferred stormwater control measure (SCM). Currently, volume capture in Pennsylvania is calculated using a static bowl equation that does not include the dynamics of infiltration and evapotranspiration (ET). In addition, many states' design guidelines for rain garden soil mixes are often restrictive and vague. The goal of the work described in this paper is to develop guidelines for soil mixes that consider the balance of infiltration and ET using bench-scale experiments at Villanova University. A total of twelve discrete weighing lysimeters were filled with soils that span the lower portion the USDA classification triangle. The lysimeters were divided evenly into two flow path configurations: vertical 46 cm deep columns and horizontal 20 cm deep boxes at a 2.5% slope. Both lysimeter configurations utilized loamy sand, sandy loam (typical rain garden mix in PA), loam, silt loam, and clay loam soils. Switchgrass was planted in all but two lysimeters to provide a non-vegetated control with sandy loam soil. Runoff was added into the lysimeters during rainfall events to simulate actual rain garden performance and the lysimeters were weighed daily for two weeks after the event. Preliminary results of five storm simulations provide an average ET rate of 3.3 mm/day for the vertical lysimeters and 2.6 mm/day for the horizontal lysimeters. In the vertical configuration the silt loam soil produces the most volume removal through ET at 44% of the total volume removal with an average ET rate of 4.2 mm/day. In contrast, the loamy sand soil produces the least volume removal through ET at 25% of the total volume removal."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1061/9780784479889.006", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "611045687"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "652116934"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20162702563770"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84976500772"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84976500772"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "05", "@month": "07", "@timestamp": "BST 08:46:15", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "21", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "1", "@last": "33"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Benson C.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Benson", "ce:initials": "C."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Bareither C.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Bareither", "ce:initials": "C."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2012"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84888388256"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Designing water balance covers for sustainable waste containment : Transitioning state of the art to state of the practice"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "American Society of Civil Engineers"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Benson, C., and Bareither, C. Papers from Sessions of the Proceedings of the 2016 World Environmental and Water Resources Congress", "dc:creator": {"author": [{"@auid": "56709277600", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Hess A.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/56709277600", "ce:initials": "A.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60000009", "@id": "60000009"}, "ce:given-name": "Amanda", "ce:surname": "Hess", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Hess A.", "ce:given-name": "Amanda", "ce:surname": "Hess", "ce:initials": "A."}, "ce:degrees": "Ph.D."}]}, "dc:publisher": "American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) onlinejls@asce.org", "prism:url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84976500772", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84976500772", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84976500772&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus-citedby", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84976500772&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "dc:description": "\u00a9 ASCE. Rain gardens have proven to be an effective means to control stormwater; thus, in Pennsylvania's Stormwater Best Management Practice's Manual, rain gardens are the preferred stormwater control measure (SCM). Currently, volume capture in Pennsylvania is calculated using a static bowl equation that does not include the dynamics of infiltration and evapotranspiration (ET). In addition, many states' design guidelines for rain garden soil mixes are often restrictive and vague. The goal of the work described in this paper is to develop guidelines for soil mixes that consider the balance of infiltration and ET using bench-scale experiments at Villanova University. A total of twelve discrete weighing lysimeters were filled with soils that span the lower portion the USDA classification triangle. The lysimeters were divided evenly into two flow path configurations: vertical 46 cm deep columns and horizontal 20 cm deep boxes at a 2.5% slope. Both lysimeter configurations utilized loamy sand, sandy loam (typical rain garden mix in PA), loam, silt loam, and clay loam soils. Switchgrass was planted in all but two lysimeters to provide a non-vegetated control with sandy loam soil. Runoff was added into the lysimeters during rainfall events to simulate actual rain garden performance and the lysimeters were weighed daily for two weeks after the event. Preliminary results of five storm simulations provide an average ET rate of 3.3 mm/day for the vertical lysimeters and 2.6 mm/day for the horizontal lysimeters. In the vertical configuration the silt loam soil produces the most volume removal through ET at 44% of the total volume removal with an average ET rate of 4.2 mm/day. In contrast, the loamy sand soil produces the least volume removal through ET at 25% of the total volume removal.", "source-id": "21100466766", "srctype": "p"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": Y.", "ce:surname": "Foo", "ce:initials": "K.Y."}, "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "GEOCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "71.6.9.2", "classification-description": "Surface water quality; rivers and streams"}, {"classification-code": "72.2.4", "classification-description": "Hydrochemistry"}]}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2312"}, {"$": "2212"}, {"$": "2310"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "ENVI"}, {"$": "ENGI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00c2\u00a9 2016 Balaban Desalination Publications. All rights reserved. The performance of a gross pollutant trap (GPT) was investigated at 51 catchments of the most polluted river in Malaysia, Klang River and its major attributes, Gisir River, Kemensah River, and Sering River for the entrapment of gross pollutants over the operation period of 10 months. The specific characteristics of gross pollutants generated from the different catchments were measured, and sorted into litter classification. The wet loads collected at the catchments ranged between 14 and 111\u00c2\u00a0kg/ha, with majority of them was contributed by a significant amount of sediment and plastic. The water quality at the inflow and outflow channels was examined. GPT responded effectively for chemical oxygen demand, biological oxygen demand, ammonical nitrogen, and total suspended solids removal, reaching the maximum removal of 88, 94, 94, and 97%, respectively. The water quality index of the influent river water falls in Class V, derived as \u201cvery polluted,\u201d while the downstream river water lies in the intermediate between Class IV and III, defined as \u201cpolluted\u201d and \u201caverage,\u201d respectively. These findings strongly supported the real practical applications of GPTs for the effective management and preservation of urban river systems."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1080/19443994.2016.1145599", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "608601500"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "646227498"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016322680"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "4870998"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "2016569250"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84959052929"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84959052929"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "24", "@month": "10", "@timestamp": "BST 13:57:18", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "25", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "1334", "@last": "1343"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "54"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Liu A.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Liu", "ce:initials": "A."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Jiang Y.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Jiang", "ce:initials": "Y."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Dockko S.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Dockko", "ce:initials": "S."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Guan Y.", "@seq": "4", "ce:surname": "Guan", "ce:initials": "Y."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2015"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84926299829"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Characterizing stormwater treatment efficiency at the laboratory scale for effective rain garden design"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Desalin. All rights reserved. The performance of a gross pollutant trap (GPT) was investigated at 51 catchments of the most polluted river in Malaysia, Klang River and its major attributes, Gisir River, Kemensah River, and Sering River for the entrapment of gross pollutants over the operation period of 10 months. The specific characteristics of gross pollutants generated from the different catchments were measured, and sorted into litter classification. The wet loads collected at the catchments ranged between 14 and 111\u00c2\u00a0kg/ha, with majority of them was contributed by a significant amount of sediment and plastic. The water quality at the inflow and outflow channels was examined. GPT responded effectively for chemical oxygen demand, biological oxygen demand, ammonical nitrogen, and total suspended solids removal, reaching the maximum removal of 88, 94, 94, and 97%, respectively. The water quality index of the influent river water falls in Class V, derived as \u201cvery polluted,\u201d while the downstream river water lies in the intermediate between Class IV and III, defined as \u201cpolluted\u201d and \u201caverage,\u201d respectively. These findings strongly supported the real practical applications of GPTs for the effective management and preservation of urban river systems.", "source-id": "19700175585", "srctype": "j", "link": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2303"}, {"$": "1105"}, {"$": "3303"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "ENVI"}, {"$": "AGRI"}, {"$": "SOCI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 IJED. Environmental damage which leads to the deterioration of groundwater supply potential is caused by changes in land use especially in the area of groundwater recharge. The aim of this present study is to create a model of the mapping of the local housing distribution which is suitable as rainwater catchment system as groundwater recharge. Spatial approach method was used in this study. The measurement of the soil permeability coefficient, soil layer structure, the surface depth of the groundwater with the number of locations as many as 88 residential areas were conducted as measurements in this study. The results of this study in 88 residential areas within 16 districts located in Semarang showed that 30 locations are eligible for the establishment of vertical groundwater catchment system with infiltration wells and 3 locations are eligible for the establishment of horizontal catchment system with infiltration trenches."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84979703607", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84979703607&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus-citedby", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84979703607&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016 IJED. Environmental damage which leads to the deterioration of groundwater supply potential is caused by changes in land use especially in the area of groundwater recharge. The aim of this present study is to create a model of the mapping of the local housing distribution which is suitable as rainwater catchment system as groundwater recharge. Spatial approach method was used in this study. The measurement of the soil permeability coefficient, soil layer structure, the surface depth of the groundwater with the number of locations as many as 88 residential areas were conducted as measurements in this study. The results of this study in 88 residential areas within 16 districts located in Semarang showed that 30 locations are eligible for the establishment of vertical groundwater catchment system with infiltration wells and 3 locations are eligible for the establishment of horizontal catchment system with infiltration trenches.", "source-id": "17700156220", "eid": "2-s2.0-84979703607"}, "authors": "Xi\u2019an University of Science and Technology"}], "@dptid": "104567743", "postal-code": "710054"}, "author": {"@auid": "24399194000", "@seq": "4", "ce:indexed-name": "Li Y.", "ce:e-address": "Li", "ce:initials": "Y."}, "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "GEOCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "901", "classification-description": "Geobase; Related Topics"}}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2312"}, {"$": "2212"}, {"$": "2310"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "ENVI"}, {"$": "ENGI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00c2\u00a9 2016 Balaban Desalination Publications. All rights reserved. The concomitant flux of pollutants carried by urban storm water runoff to the surface of water bodies causes a series of environmental issues. Bioswale, which is an effective purification measure of urban surface runoff pollutants, was investigated to determine the relationship between bioswale composition and purification. Results indicate that the pollutant removal rate of bioswales decreases with an increase in influent concentration. Various selected vegetation combinations showed no significant difference in terms of pollutant removal in two months after being planted within a single rainfall. Increasing the thickness of the planting soil and artificial filler layers can improve the contaminant removal rate. Various artificial filler compositions were proven to have different effects on pollutant purification. Planting soil and a mixture of coal ash and sand were the best choice, whereas sand was the worst. The total nitrogen (TN) removal rate increased with submerged zone height, whereas the removal of chemical oxygen demand (COD) and total phosphorus (TP) showed no significant change. The addition of an external carbon source increased TN concentration removal and decreased COD concentration removal without significantly affecting TP. The curve analysis of the pollutant removal rate and various factors was established by processing the statistical results through the SPSS software. The equation of linear regression, which reveals the relationship between the control effect and its influencing factors, was obtained based on the partial least squares model."}, "item-info": All rights reserved. The concomitant flux of pollutants carried by urban storm water runoff to the surface of water bodies causes a series of environmental issues. Bioswale, which is an effective purification measure of urban surface runoff pollutants, was investigated to determine the relationship between bioswale composition and purification. Results indicate that the pollutant removal rate of bioswales decreases with an increase in influent concentration. Various selected vegetation combinations showed no significant difference in terms of pollutant removal in two months after being planted within a single rainfall. Increasing the thickness of the planting soil and artificial filler layers can improve the contaminant removal rate. Various artificial filler compositions were proven to have different effects on pollutant purification. Planting soil and a mixture of coal ash and sand were the best choice, whereas sand was the worst. The total nitrogen (TN) removal rate increased with submerged zone height, whereas the removal of chemical oxygen demand (COD) and total phosphorus (TP) showed no significant change. The addition of an external carbon source increased TN concentration removal and decreased COD concentration removal without significantly affecting TP. The curve analysis of the pollutant removal rate and various factors was established by processing the statistical results through the SPSS software. The equation of linear regression, which reveals the relationship between the control effect and its influencing factors, was obtained based on the partial least squares model.", "source-id": "abstracts": "As one of the world most water-scare countries, China expands tons of water in urban public landscape spaces. However, on the other hand, due to natural vegetation being replaced by impervious surface, rainwater directly flows into storm sewers with runoff pollutions, and then it drains off into nearby water bodies without treatment, which results in serious waste of rainwater resources and pollution of the river system. During heavy storms the enormous pressure on municipal storm water treatment installations may give rise to urban waterlogging, even serious localised flooding. The contradiction between water shortage and rain water waste has been an increasingly serious problem. To relieve the contradiction, rain gardens can be a valuable part of changing the above matters. As the principal part of a rain garden, plants play a vital role in the rainwater processing system. However, most of the plants applied to rain gardens in western countries cannot adapt to the climate in China. So in the process of rain garden design in China, the evaluation and selection of plants in rain gardens is significant. Two sets of rain gardens were installed with native and prairie plants, respectively, located in northern and southern China with typical climate. On the base of screening plants in the greenhouse with drought, flood and pollution stress, 33 species for Shenzhen and 28 species for Beijing were selected for rain gardens. Ecological index and ornamental index were measured to evaluate and select the plants that grew in rain gardens with the analysis method of AHP. The results indicated that 20 species were separately suited for growing in rain gardens of Shenzhen and Beijing. This would be significant for future work and widely spread application of rain gardens in China."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.17660/ActaHortic.2016.1108.26", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "609914635"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "649120776"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016403340"}, {"@idtype": "SNCABS", "$": "2016020398"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84963621666"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84963621666"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "SNCABS"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "08", "@month": "12", "@timestamp": "BST 13:59:08", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "19", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-sourcetitle": "Rain Gardens: A How to Manual for Homeowners", "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "33644537435"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Bannerman R.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Bannerman", "ce:initials": "R."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Considine E.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Considine", "ce:initials": "E."}]}, "ref-text": "Wisconsin, USA: University of Wisconsin Extension", "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2003"}}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Bannerman, R., and Considine, E. Low Impact Development (LID), a Literature Review, EPA-841-B-00-005 (Washington, DC, USA: Office of Water)."}]}}}}, "subject-areas": {"subject-area": [{"@code": "1108", "@abbrev": "AGRI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Horticulture"}]}, "idxterms": null, "affiliation": [{"affiliation-country": "China", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60006782", "@id": "60006782", "affiliation-city": "Beijing", "affilname": "Beijing Forestry University"}, {"affiliation-country": "China", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/112625906", "@id": "112625906", "affiliation-city": "Beijing", "affilname": "China Urban Construction Design and Research Institute"}], "authkeywords": {"author-keyword": [{"@_fa": "true", "$": "AHP"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Application"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Beijing"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Evaluation and selection"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Rain garden plants"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Shenzhen"}]}, "coredata": {"prism:volume": "1108", "prism:coverDate": "2016-02-08", "dc:title": "Plant evaluation and selection for rain gardens in China", "prism:publicationName": "Acta Horticulturae", "dc:publisher": "International Society for Horticultural Science Pastoriestraat Bierbeek 3360", "prism:issn": "05677572", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:84963621666", "prism:startingPage": "201", "citedby-count": "0", "dc:description": "As one of the world most water-scare countries, China expands tons of water in urban public landscape spaces. However, on the other hand, due to natural vegetation being replaced by impervious surface, rainwater directly flows into storm sewers with runoff pollutions, and then it drains off into nearby water bodies without treatment, which results in serious waste of rainwater resources and pollution of the river system. During heavy storms the enormous pressure on municipal storm water treatment installations may give rise to urban waterlogging, even serious localised flooding. The contradiction between water shortage and rain water waste has been an increasingly serious problem. To relieve the contradiction, rain gardens can be a valuable part of changing the above matters. As the principal part of a rain garden, plants play a vital role in the rainwater processing system. However, most of the plants applied to rain gardens in western countries cannot adapt to the climate in China. So in the process of rain garden design in China, the evaluation and selection of plants in rain gardens is significant. Two sets of rain gardens were installed with native and prairie plants, respectively, located in northern and southern China with typical climate. On the base of screening plants in the greenhouse with drought, flood and pollution stress, 33 species for Shenzhen and 28 species for Beijing were selected for rain gardens. Ecological index and ornamental index were measured to evaluate and select the plants that grew in rain gardens with the analysis method of AHP. The results indicated that 20 species were separately suited for growing in rain gardens of Shenzhen and Beijing. This would be significant for future work and widely spread application of rain gardens in China.", "source-id": "26209", "srctype": "k", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": {"classifications": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2200"}, {"$": "2506"}]}, {"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "442.1", "classification-description": "Flood "MIXING AND SEPARATION"}, {"classification-code": "79.25", "classification-description": "WATER ENGINEERING"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "ENGI"}, {"$": "MATE"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016, Central South University Press and Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg. The behaviors of inorganic nitrogen species in three types of bioretention columns under an intermittently wetting regime were investigated. The mean NH4 +\u2014N, NO3 \u2212\u2014N and total N (TN) removal efficiencies for the conventional bioretention column (Col. T1) are 71%, 1% and 41%, for layered bioretention column with less permeable soil layer (Col. T2) the efficiencies are 83%, 84% and 82%, and for the bioretention column with submerged zone (Col. T3) the values are 63%, 31% and 53%, respectively. The best nitrogen removal is obtained using Col. T2 with relatively low infiltration rate. Adsorption during runoff dosing and nitrification during the drying period are the primary NH4 +\u2014N removal pathways. Less permeable soil and the elevated outlet promote the formation of anoxic conditions. 30%\u201370% of NO3 \u2212\u2014N applied to columns in a single repetition is denitrified during the draining period, suggesting that the draining period is an important timeframe for the removal of NO3 \u2212\u2014N. Infiltration rate controls the contact time with media during the draining periods, greatly influencing the NO3 \u2212\u2014N removal effects. Bioretention systems with infiltration rate ranging from 3 to 7 cm/h have a great potential to remove NO3 \u2212\u2014N."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1007/s11771-016-3077-1", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "608112905"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "645167292"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20160601910260"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "2016432558"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84957045471"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84957045471"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "11", "@month": "02", "@timestamp": "BST 18:39:10", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "22", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "1430", "@last": "1434"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "28", "@issue": "7"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Lin L.-F.", "@seq": "1", "ce:given-name": "L-f", "ce:surname": "Lin", "ce:initials": "L.-F."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Li T.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Li", "ce:initials": "T."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Li H.", "@seq": "3", "ce:given-name": "He", "ce:surname": "Li", "ce:initials": "H."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2007"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "34447649539"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Characteristics of surface runoff pollution of Shanghai urban area [J]"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Environmental Science"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "LIN Li-feng, LI Tian, LI He. The behaviors of inorganic nitrogen species in three types of bioretention columns under an intermittently wetting regime were investigated. The mean NH4 +\u2014N, NO3 \u2212\u2014N and total N (TN) removal efficiencies for the conventional bioretention column (Col. T1) are 71%, 1% and 41%, for layered bioretention column with less permeable soil layer (Col. T2) the efficiencies are 83%, 84% and 82%, and for the bioretention column with submerged zone (Col. T3) the values are 63%, 31% and 53%, respectively. The best nitrogen removal is obtained using Col. T2 with relatively low infiltration rate. Adsorption during runoff dosing and nitrification during the drying period are the primary NH4 +\u2014N removal pathways. Less permeable soil and the elevated outlet promote the formation of anoxic conditions. 30%\u201370% of NO3 \u2212\u2014N applied to columns in a single repetition is denitrified during the draining period, suggesting that the draining period is an important timeframe for the removal of NO3 \u2212\u2014N. Infiltration rate controls the contact time with media during the draining periods, greatly influencing the NO3 \u2212\u2014N removal effects. Bioretention systems with infiltration rate ranging from 3 to 7 cm/h have a great potential to remove NO3 \u2212\u2014N.", "source-id": "21100239402", "srctype": "j", "link": [{"@rel": "self", {"$": "1904"}]}, {"@type": "CABSCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "91.8.1", "classification-description": "ECOLOGICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; APPLIED ECOLOGY/POLLUTION; "ENVI"}, {"$": "EART"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2015, Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg. Taking an area of Xi\u2019an city as an example, the Storm Water Management Model was established according to the measured data after calibration and validation. Three different return period storms (once in 2\u00a0years, once in a decade, and once in 20\u00a0years) were designed to simulate the water quantity and quality of the study area with or without rain gardens. Rain gardens with different proportions (1, 2, and 4\u00a0%) of the study area were set for simulation and comparison. Finally, the control effects of rain gardens with and without discharge facility were compared. Rain gardens can reduce the total amount and peak flow of urban runoff. Such gardens can also reduce pollutant peak concentration and pollution load. The peak time of flow and concentration can be delayed. However, the control effect or reduction rate of rain gardens will decrease with increasing rainfall intensity. A larger area proportion of rain gardens results in a better control effect on urban runoff. The control effect of rain gardens without discharge facility is better than that of rain gardens with discharge facility under the same conditions of rainfall and area ratio. The control effect difference between rain gardens with and without discharge facility decreases with the increase in the area ratio of rain gardens."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1007/s12665-015-4807-7", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "607312017"}, {"@idtype": "CABS", "$": "2015091218"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "643244590"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20155201714168"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016210063"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "4817031"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84950318511"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84950318511"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CABS"}, {"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "25", "@month": "12", "@timestamp": "BST 09:54:40", "@year": "2015"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "30", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "434", "@last": "443"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "15"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Aad M.P.A.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Aad", "ce:initials": "M.P.A."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Suidan M.T.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Suidan", "ce:initials": "M.T."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Shuster W.D.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Shuster", "ce:initials": "W.D."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2010"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "77954006094"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Modeling techniques of best management practices: rain barrels and rain gardens using EPA SWMM-5"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "J Hydrol Eng"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Aad MPA, Suidan MT, Shuster WD (2010) Modeling techniques of best management practices: rain barrels and rain gardens using EPA SWMM-5. "$": "Rain garden"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "SWMM"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Urban rainfall runoff"}]}, "coredata": {"prism:volume": "75", "prism:doi": "10.1007/s12665-015-4807-7", "dc:title": "SWMM-based evaluation of the effect of rain gardens on urbanized areas", "prism:publicationName": "Environmental Earth Sciences", "dc:publisher": "Springer Verlag service@springer.de", "prism:issn": "18666299", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:84950318511", "prism:startingPage": "1", "citedby-count": "0", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2015, Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg. Taking an area of Xi\u2019an city as an example, the Storm Water Management Model was established according to the measured data after calibration and validation. Three different return period storms (once in 2\u00a0years, once in a decade, and once in 20\u00a0years) were designed to simulate the water quantity and quality of the study area with or without rain gardens. Rain gardens with different proportions (1, 2, and 4\u00a0%) of the study area were set for simulation and comparison. Finally, the control effects of rain gardens with and without discharge facility were compared. Rain gardens can reduce the total amount and peak flow of urban runoff. Such gardens can also reduce pollutant peak concentration and pollution load. The peak time of flow and concentration can be delayed. However, the control effect or reduction rate of rain gardens will decrease with increasing rainfall intensity. A larger area proportion of rain gardens results in a better control effect on urban runoff. The control effect of rain gardens without discharge facility is better than that of rain gardens with discharge facility under the same conditions of rainfall and area ratio. The control effect difference between rain gardens with and without discharge facility decreases with the increase in the area ratio of rain gardens.", "source-id": "19400158519", "srctype": "j", "classification-description": "WATER ENGINEERING"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "COMP"}, {"$": "SOCI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 IEEE. With the speeding up of urbanization process, many cities facing a series of problems such as water shortage, water environment pollution and so on. The promotion and construction of rain garden will be one of the effective ways to alleviate this problem. In addition, the establishment of the rain garden brings new green space to the city, and provide residents with recreational environment at the same time, but also promote the recycling of water resources. This paper discusses the rain garden concept, the practical significance, the way and the way of the construction technology, and the basic requirements of the construction technology, and summarizes the applicable of the rainwater garden plants in Beijing area, and discusses the development trend of the rain garden. In order to provide reference and guidance for the construction of rainwater garden system in urban construction of our country."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1109/ICITBS.2015.143", "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84963894274&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016 IEEE. With the speeding up of urbanization process, many cities facing a series of problems such as water shortage, water environment pollution and so on. The promotion and construction of rain garden will be one of the effective ways to alleviate this problem. In addition, the establishment of the rain garden brings new green space to the city, and provide residents with recreational environment at the same time, but also promote the recycling of water resources. This paper discusses the rain garden concept, the practical significance, the way and the way of the construction technology, and the basic requirements of the construction technology, and summarizes the applicable of the rainwater garden plants in Beijing area, and discusses the development trend of the rain garden. In order to provide reference and guidance for the construction of rainwater garden system in urban construction of our country.", "article-number": "7384089", "srctype": "p"}, "authors": {"author": "544.1", "classification-description": "Copper"}, {"classification-code": "802.2", "classification-description": "Chemical Reactions"}, {"classification-code": "804.2", "classification-description": "classification-description": "WASTEWATER AND OTHER EFFLUENT/LIQUID WASTE ENGIN."}]}, {"@type": "GEOCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "70.11.5", "classification-description": "Waste Management and Pollution Policy"}, {"classification-code": "72.14.2", "classification-description": "Pollution and waste management - non-radioactive"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENVI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 Elsevier B.V. Existing biofiltration systems have shown variable and often inadequate bacterial removal efficacy. Previous work has shown antimicrobial media copper-zeolite as a promising alternative to reduce the variability and excessive discharge of faecal indicator bacteria such as Escherichia coli. A large-scale biofilter column study was conducted over eight months to investigate the benefits of incorporating copper-zeolite into biofilters on E. coli removal. The incorporation of copper-zeolite into biofilters improved E. coli log removal rate by 53% reducing E. coli concentration from 21,800 MPN/100 mL (median inflow) to 126 MPN/100 mL (median outflow) comparable to international primary contact recreational water quality. In addition, the E. coli removal performance of copper-zeolite amended biofilters increased after intermittent dry weather periods; this is notable, especially considering biofilter performance usually decreases after drying. Furthermore, these designs reduced inflow copper concentration by 91% (comparable to the metal removal performance of traditional biofilters) and provided a median effluent copper concentration of 8 \u03bcg/L. The vegetation in copper-zeolite filters survived. These results validate the use of copper-zeolite as bioretention media, particularly for sites requiring microbial reduction. Future research will include systematic investigation of the processes involved in reduction of bacteria in copper-zeolite filters and optimise filter design to augment the system performance to meet more stringent stormwater reuse requirements."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1016/j.ecoleng.2016.01.066", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "608959351"}, {"@idtype": "CABS", "$": Existing biofiltration systems have shown variable and often inadequate bacterial removal efficacy. Previous work has shown antimicrobial media copper-zeolite as a promising alternative to reduce the variability and excessive discharge of faecal indicator bacteria such as Escherichia coli. A large-scale biofilter column study was conducted over eight months to investigate the benefits of incorporating copper-zeolite into biofilters on E. coli removal. The incorporation of copper-zeolite into biofilters improved E. coli log removal rate by 53% reducing E. coli concentration from 21,800 MPN/100 mL (median inflow) to 126 MPN/100 mL (median outflow) comparable to international primary contact recreational water quality. In addition, the E. coli removal performance of copper-zeolite amended biofilters increased after intermittent dry weather periods; this is notable, especially considering biofilter performance usually decreases after drying. Furthermore, these designs reduced inflow copper concentration by 91% (comparable to the metal removal performance of traditional biofilters) and provided a median effluent copper concentration of 8 \u03bcg/L. The vegetation in copper-zeolite filters survived. These results validate the use of copper-zeolite as bioretention media, particularly for sites requiring microbial reduction. Future research will include systematic investigation of the processes involved in reduction of bacteria in copper-zeolite filters and optimise filter design to augment the system performance to meet more stringent stormwater reuse requirements.", "source-id": "20291", "srctype": "j", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84960491951", "@_fa": To mitigate the impacts of impervious surfaces in urban areas, structures such as bioretention systems and permeable pavements have been installed to enhance infiltration in many countries. However, relatively little knowledge is available regarding the performance of such infiltration-based structures in humid tropical and highly urbanized areas. This study investigates the feasibility of enhancing the infiltration of stormwater in tropical urbanized areas using Singapore as a case study. It first shows that the rainfall depth and intensity are both high, but the time interval between consecutive rainfall event is long in Singapore. It then numerically simulates single-event local infiltration and finds that the fraction of infiltrated rainfall is actually high. It finally performs catchment-scale simulations and finds that bioretention systems can enhance infiltration and groundwater recharge particularly during wet periods. However, local mounding of groundwater can be significant and can hinder the performance of those structures. Furthermore, with 5% of catchment area being converted to such structures, the infiltration of the entire catchment is enhanced but still not yet up to the natural level. To increase the overall effectiveness, future studies can look into bioretention systems with underdrain systems. To mitigate the impacts of impervious surfaces in urban areas, structures such as bioretention systems and permeable pavements have been installed to enhance infiltration in many countries. However, relatively little knowledge is available regarding the performance of such infiltration-based structures in humid tropical and highly urbanized areas. This study investigates the feasibility of enhancing the infiltration of stormwater in tropical urbanized areas using Singapore as a case study. It first shows that the rainfall depth and intensity are both high, but the time interval between consecutive rainfall event is long in Singapore. It then numerically simulates single-event local infiltration and finds that the fraction of infiltrated rainfall is actually high. It finally performs catchment-scale simulations and finds that bioretention systems can enhance infiltration and groundwater recharge particularly during wet periods. However, local mounding of groundwater can be significant and can hinder the performance of those structures. Furthermore, with 5% of catchment area being converted to such structures, the infiltration of the entire catchment is enhanced but still not yet up to the natural level. To increase the overall effectiveness, future studies can look into bioretention systems with underdrain systems. "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "443.1", "classification-description": "Atmospheric Properties"}, {"classification-code": "443.3", "classification-description": "Precipitation"}, {"classification-code": "454.1", "classification-description": "Environmental Engineering, General"}, {"classification-code": "911", "classification-description": "Cost and Value Engineering; Industrial Economics"}, {"classification-code": "911.2", "classification-description": "Industrial Economics"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "79.22", "classification-description": "THE ATMOSPHERE"}}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": "2312"}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENVI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 Elsevier B.V. Bioretention, as a popular low impact development practice, has become more important to mitigate adverse impacts on urban stormwater. However, there is very limited information regarding ensuring the effectiveness of bioretention response to uncertain future challenges, especially when taking into consideration climate change and urbanization. The main objective of this paper is to identify the cost-effectiveness of bioretention by assessing the hydrology performance under future scenarios modeling. First, the hydrology model was used to obtain peak runoff and TSS loads of bioretention with variable scales under different scenarios, i.e., different Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) and Shared Socio-economic reference Pathways (SSPs) for 2-year and 10-year design storms in Singapore. Then, life cycle costing (LCC) and life cycle assessment (LCA) were estimated for bioretention, and the cost-effectiveness was identified under different scenarios. Our finding showed that there were different degree of responses to 2-year and 10-year design storms but the general patterns and insights deduced were similar. The performance of bioretenion was more sensitive to urbanization than that for climate change in the urban catchment. In addition, it was noted that the methodology used in this study was generic and the findings could be useful as reference for other LID practices in response to climate change and urbanization."}, Bioretention, as a popular low impact development practice, has become more important to mitigate adverse impacts on urban stormwater. However, there is very limited information regarding ensuring the effectiveness of bioretention response to uncertain future challenges, especially when taking into consideration climate change and urbanization. The main objective of this paper is to identify the cost-effectiveness of bioretention by assessing the hydrology performance under future scenarios modeling. First, the hydrology model was used to obtain peak runoff and TSS loads of bioretention with variable scales under different scenarios, i.e., different Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) and Shared Socio-economic reference Pathways (SSPs) for 2-year and 10-year design storms in Singapore. Then, life cycle costing (LCC) and life cycle assessment (LCA) were estimated for bioretention, and the cost-effectiveness was identified under different scenarios. Our finding showed that there were different degree of responses to 2-year and 10-year design storms but the general patterns and insights deduced were similar. The performance of bioretenion was more sensitive to urbanization than that for climate change in the urban catchment. In addition, it was noted that the methodology used in this study was generic and the findings could be useful as reference for other LID practices in response to climate change and urbanization.", All right reserved. Bioretention, one of the recommended technical measures in Eco-sponge City construction guidelines, can reduce stormwater runoff volume and achieve excellent removal of contaminants at the source. The structure and hydrological characteristics of a bioretention system were comprehensively analyzed, and the performance of bioretention in removing pollutants from stormwater was summarized, with a particular focus on promoting the application of bioretention technology. Measures to improve and optimize bioretention functions were also discussed, addressing the problem of unstable removal efficacy for nitrogen and phosphorus. Further research needs were also proposed to encourage the design and application of bioretention systems."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "610185820"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "649873227"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016425423"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20161106175"}, {"@idtype": "SNCPX", "$": "2016037636"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84964570427"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84964570427"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "SNCPX"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "05", "@month": "05", "@timestamp": "BST 12:44:55", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "49", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "1066", "@last": "1099"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "6", "@issue": "4"}}, "ref-authors": {"et-al": null, "author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Liu J.", "@seq": "1", "ce:given-name": "Jia", "ce:surname": "Liu", "ce:initials": "J."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Sample D.J.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Sample", "ce:initials": "D.J."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Bell C.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Bell", "ce:initials": "C."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2014"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84899816383"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Review and research needs of bioretention used for the treatment of urban stormwater"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Water"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Liu Jia, Sample D. "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84964570427&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016, Science Press. All right reserved. Bioretention, one of the recommended technical measures in Eco-sponge City construction guidelines, can reduce stormwater runoff volume and achieve excellent removal of contaminants at the source. The structure and hydrological characteristics of a bioretention system were comprehensively analyzed, and the performance of bioretention in removing pollutants from stormwater was summarized, with a particular focus on promoting the application of bioretention technology. Measures to improve and optimize bioretention functions were also discussed, addressing the problem of unstable removal efficacy for nitrogen and phosphorus. Further research needs were also proposed to encourage the design and application of bioretention systems.", "source-id": "21100287325", "eid": "2-s2.0-84964570427"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2305"}, {"$": "2311"}, {"$": "2308"}]}, {"@type": "CABSCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "91.8.1", "classification-description": "ECOLOGICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; APPLIED ECOLOGY/POLLUTION; Environmental Management"}}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENVI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 Elsevier Ltd. As small scale green infrastructures, rain gardens have been widely advocated for urban stormwater management in the contemporary low impact development (LID) era. This paper presents a simple method that consists of hydrological models and the matching plots of nomographs to provide an informative and practical tool for rain garden sizing and hydrological evaluation. The proposed method considers design storms, infiltration rates and the runoff contribution area ratio of the rain garden, allowing users to size a rain garden for a specific site with hydrological reference and predict overflow of the rain garden under different storms. The nomographs provide a visual presentation on the sensitivity of different design parameters. Subsequent application of the proposed method to a case study conducted in a sub-humid region in China showed that, the method accurately predicted the design storms for the existing rain garden, the predicted overflows under large storm events were within 13-50% of the measured volumes. The results suggest that the nomographs approach is a practical tool for quick selection or assessment of design options that incorporate key hydrological parameters of rain gardens or other infiltration type green infrastructure. The graphic approach as displayed by the nomographs allow urban planners to demonstrate the hydrological effect of small scale green infrastructure and gain more support for promoting low impact development."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1016/j.jenvman.2016.01.016", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "607973099"}, {"@idtype": "CABS", "$": "2016037147"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "644803275"}, {"@idtype": "EMBASE", "$": "20160080783"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016268811"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "4841121"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "2016367822"}, {"@idtype": "RMC", "$": "2016029833"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84955622088"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84955622088"}], "ce:pii": "S0301479716300160"}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CABS"}, {"$": "EMBASE"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "RMC"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "12", "@month": "04", "@timestamp": "BST 03:26:29", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "26", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "151", "@last": "161"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "119"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Ahiablame L.M.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Ahiablame", "ce:initials": "L.M."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Engel B.A.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Engel", "ce:initials": "B.A."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Chaubey I.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Chaubey", "ce:initials": "I."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2013"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84874785303"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Effectiveness of low impact development practices in two urbanized watersheds: retrofitting with rain barrel/cistern and porous pavement"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "J. Conservation Practice Standard (1004) 2010, Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources."}]}}}}, "subject-areas": {"subject-area": [{"@code": "2305", "@abbrev": "ENVI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Environmental Engineering"}, {"@code": "2311", "@abbrev": "ENVI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Waste Management and Disposal"}, {"@code": "2308", "@abbrev": "ENVI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Management, Monitoring, Policy and Law"}]}, "idxterms": null, "affiliation": [{"affiliation-country": "China", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60007381", "@id": "60007381", "affiliation-city": "Yangzhou", "affilname": "Yangzhou University"}, {"affiliation-country": "China", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60026981", "@id": "60026981", "affiliation-city": "Xi'an", "affilname": "Xi'an University of Technology"}], "authkeywords": {"author-keyword": [{"@_fa": "true", "$": "Design storm"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Green infrastructure"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Hydrological evaluation"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Low impact development (LID)"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Rain garden"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Sensitivity analysis"}]}, "coredata": {"pii": "S0301479716300160", "prism:coverDate": "2016-04-15", "prism:volume": "171", "dc:title": "Small scale green infrastructure design to meet different urban hydrological criteria", "prism:publicationName": "Journal of Environmental Management", "dc:publisher": "Academic Press", "prism:issn": "10958630", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:84955622088", "prism:startingPage": "92", "citedby-count": "0", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016 Elsevier Ltd. As small scale green infrastructures, rain gardens have been widely advocated for urban stormwater management in the contemporary low impact development (LID) era. This paper presents a simple method that consists of hydrological models and the matching plots of nomographs to provide an informative and practical tool for rain garden sizing and hydrological evaluation. The proposed method considers design storms, infiltration rates and the runoff contribution area ratio of the rain garden, allowing users to size a rain garden for a specific site with hydrological reference and predict overflow of the rain garden under different storms. The nomographs provide a visual presentation on the sensitivity of different design parameters. Subsequent application of the proposed method to a case study conducted in a sub-humid region in China showed that, the method accurately predicted the design storms for the existing rain garden, the predicted overflows under large storm events were within 13-50% of the measured volumes. The results suggest that the nomographs approach is a practical tool for quick selection or assessment of design options that incorporate key hydrological parameters of rain gardens or other infiltration type green infrastructure. The graphic approach as displayed by the nomographs allow urban planners to demonstrate the hydrological effect of small scale green infrastructure and gain more support for promoting low impact development.", "source-id": "23371", "srctype": "j", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84955622088", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus", "@href": [{"$": "Department of Soil Science"}, {"$": "University of Wisconsin-Madison"}], "@dptid": "113083057", "postal-code": "53706"}, "author": {"@auid": "6602275953", "@seq": "3", "ce:indexed-name": "Balster N.J.", "ce:initials": "N.J.", "ce:given-name": "Nicholas J.", "ce:surname": "Balster", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Balster N.", "ce:given-name": "Nicholas J.", "ce:surname": "Balster", "ce:initials": "N.J."}, "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2303"}, {"$": "3322"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "ENVI"}, {"$": "SOCI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016, Springer Science+Business Media New York (outside the USA). Vegetation type alters surface hydrology and nitrogen (N) cycling by partitioning evapotranspiration (ET) and drainage, but has not been fully utilized for this purpose in the design of urban rain gardens. Replicated treatments of three vegetation types (prairie, shrub, and turfgrass) commonly planted in rain gardens, as well as bare soil (control), were evaluated 1\u00a0year after establishment in 12, free-drainage bioretention cells designed to specifications for residential rain gardens in the Midwestern United States. Water and N budgets were calculated to assess differences in ET, drainage, soil moisture, and N transport following three stormwater applications in July, August, and October of 2006. Evaporative demand was also estimated as potential or reference ET during the study period using Hamon, Priestley-Taylor, and FAO Penman-Monteith models. Results show that after 1\u00a0year of establishment, vegetation type changed the water budgets of rain gardens thus altering their provisioning of ecosystem services via observed tradeoffs between daytime evaporative cooling (ET), stormwater storage, N-load reduction, soil and plant N retention, and groundwater recharge (drainage). Vegetation effects on hydrology and N transport were most significant when evaporative demand was high during the middle of the growing season. Observed changes in ET, drainage, soil moisture, and N transport support the incorporation of different vegetation types into conceptual and numerical models of rain gardens to assess ecological outcomes and tradeoffs at a variety of spatiotemporal scales.", "grantlist": {"@complete": "y", "grant": {"grant-id": "WIS04947", "grant-agency": "National Institute of Food and Agriculture", "grant-acronym": "NIFA"}}}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1007/s11252-016-0568-7", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "610639835"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "651218995"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016476271"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20161314262"}, {"@idtype": "SNGEO", "$": "2016011991"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84973100763"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84973100763"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "SNGEO"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "20", "@month": "12", "@timestamp": "BST 10:38:40", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "68", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "229", "@last": "241"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "55"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Abdou H.M.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Abdou", "ce:initials": "H.M."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Flury M.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Flury", "ce:initials": "M."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2004"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "2942627496"}}, "ref-text": "COI: 1:CAS:528:DC%2BD2cXlsFCks78%3D", "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Simulation of water flow and solute transport in free-drainage lysimeters and field soils with heterogeneous structures"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Eur J Soil Sci"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Abdou HM, Flury M (2004) Simulation of water flow and solute transport in free-drainage lysimeters and field soils with heterogeneous structures. Ecol Eng 54:22\u201331"}]}}}}, "subject-areas": {"subject-area": [{"@code": "2303", "@abbrev": "ENVI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Ecology"}, {"@code": "3322", "@abbrev": "SOCI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Urban Studies"}]}, "idxterms": null, "affiliation": [{"affiliation-country": "United States", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60032179", "@id": "60032179", "affiliation-city": "Madison", "affilname": "University of Wisconsin Madison"}, {"affiliation-country": "United States", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/116755414", "@id": "116755414", "affiliation-city": null, "affilname": "Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest Service"}], "authkeywords": {"author-keyword": [{"@_fa": "true", "$": "Bioretention basins"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Ecosystem services"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Prairie"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Rain gardens"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Shrubs"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Turfgrass"}]}, "coredata": {"prism:volume": "19", "prism:coverDate": "2016-12-01", "prism:doi": "10.1007/s11252-016-0568-7", "dc:title": "Vegetation type alters water and nitrogen budgets in a controlled, replicated experiment on residential-sized rain gardens planted with prairie, shrub, and turfgrass", "prism:publicationName": "Urban Ecosystems", "dc:publisher": "Springer New York LLC barbara.b.bertram@gsk.com", "prism:issn": "15731642", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:84973100763", "prism:startingPage": "1665", "citedby-count": "0", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016, Springer Science+Business Media New York (outside the USA). Vegetation type alters surface hydrology and nitrogen (N) cycling by partitioning evapotranspiration (ET) and drainage, but has not been fully utilized for this purpose in the design of urban rain gardens. Replicated treatments of three vegetation types (prairie, shrub, and turfgrass) commonly planted in rain gardens, as well as bare soil (control), were evaluated 1\u00a0year after establishment in 12, free-drainage bioretention cells designed to specifications for residential rain gardens in the Midwestern United States. Water and N budgets were calculated to assess differences in ET, drainage, soil moisture, and N transport following three stormwater applications in July, August, and October of 2006. Evaporative demand was also estimated as potential or reference ET during the study period using Hamon, Priestley-Taylor, and FAO Penman-Monteith models. Results show that after 1\u00a0year of establishment, vegetation type changed the water budgets of rain gardens thus altering their provisioning of ecosystem services via observed tradeoffs between daytime evaporative cooling (ET), stormwater storage, N-load reduction, soil and plant N retention, and groundwater recharge (drainage). Vegetation effects on hydrology and N transport were most significant when evaporative demand was high during the middle of the growing season. Observed changes in ET, drainage, soil moisture, and N transport support the incorporation of different vegetation types into conceptual and numerical models of rain gardens to assess ecological outcomes and tradeoffs at a variety of spatiotemporal scales.", "source-id": "145570", "srctype": "j", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "EART"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 Author(s) 2016. As our climate changes through time there is an ever-increasing need to quantify how and where it is changing so that mitigation strategies can be implemented. Urban areas have a disproportionate amount of warming due, in part, to the conductive properties of concrete and asphalt surfaces, surface albedo, heat capacity, lack of water, etc. that make up an urban environment. The NASA Climate Adaptation Science Investigation working group at Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD, conducted a study to collect temperature and humidity data at 15min intervals from 12 sites at the center. These sites represent the major surface types at the center: asphalt, building roof, grass field, forest, and rain garden. The data show a strong distinction in the thermal properties of these surfaces at the center and the difference between the average values for the center compared to a local meteorological station. The data have been submitted to Oak Ridge National Laboratory Distributed Active Archive Center (ORNL-DAAC) for archival in comma separated value (csv) file format (Carroll et al., 2016) and can be found by following this link: &lt;a hrefCombining double low line\"http://daac.ornl.gov/cgi-bin/dsviewer.pl?ds-idCombining double low line1319\" targetCombining double low line\"-blank\"&gt;http://daac.ornl.gov/cgi-bin/dsviewer.pl?ds-idCombining double low line1319.", "grantlist": {"grant-text": {"@xml:lang": "eng", "$": "Project was provided by NASA Headquarters Earth Science Division through the Climate Adaptation Science Investigator working group. The authors would like to thank the two reviewers, whose insightful comments helped refine the text, and the Oak Ridge DAAC for hosting the data."}, "@complete": "y", "grant": {"grant-agency": "National Aeronautics and Space Administration", "grant-acronym": "NASA"}}}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.5194/essd-8-415-2016", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "612266857"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "655544808"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20161990226"}, {"@idtype": "SNGEO", "$": "2016018235"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84988672524"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84988672524"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "SNGEO"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "28", "@month": "09", "@timestamp": "BST 14:48:16", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "8", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Carroll M.L.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Carroll", "ce:initials": "M.L."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Brown M.E.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Brown", "ce:initials": "M.E."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Wooten M.R.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Wooten", "ce:initials": "M.R."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Donham J.E.", "@seq": "4", "ce:surname": "Donham", "ce:initials": "J.E."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Hubbard A.B.", "@seq": "5", "ce:surname": "Hubbard", "ce:initials": "A.B."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Ridenhour W.B.", "@seq": "6", "ce:surname": "Ridenhour", "ce:initials": "W.B."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2016"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84988593741"}}, "ref-text": "Oak Ridge, Tennessee, USA, Oak Ridge National Lab, Distributed Active Archive Center", "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "In-situ air temperature and relative humidity in greenbelt md 2013-2015"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "ORNL DAAC"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Carroll, M.
