As our climate changes through time there is an ever-increasing need to quantify how and where it is changing so that mitigation strategies can be implemented. Urban areas have a disproportionate amount of warming due, in part, to the conductive properties of concrete and asphalt surfaces, surface albedo, heat capacity, lack of water, etc. that make up an urban environment. The NASA Climate Adaptation Science Investigation working group at Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD, conducted a study to collect temperature and humidity data at 15min intervals from 12 sites at the center. These sites represent the major surface types at the center: asphalt, building roof, grass field, forest, and rain garden. The data show a strong distinction in the thermal properties of these surfaces at the center and the difference between the average values for the center compared to a local meteorological station. The data have been submitted to Oak Ridge National Laboratory Distributed Active Archive Center (ORNL-DAAC) for archival in comma separated value (csv) file format (Carroll et al., 2016) and can be found by following this link: &lt;a hrefCombining double low line\"http://daac.ornl.gov/cgi-bin/dsviewer.pl?ds-idCombining double low line1319\" targetCombining double low "classification-description": "THE ATMOSPHERE"}}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2304"}, {"$": "2312"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENVI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 Water Environment Federation. The following review presents a synthesis of 181 journal articles published during 2015 that represent progress toward better characterizing, controlling, and treating urban stormwater runoff. The review is structured by general topical areas related to (1) stormwater quality and quantity characterization; (2) engineered stormwater control and treatment practices, including erosion and sediment control, stormwater ponds, constructed stormwater wetlands, bioretention, permeable pavement, greenroofs, and rainwater harvesting systems; and (3) watershed-scale modeling and optimization of stormwater control and treatment practices. Common research themes emerging from this collection of studies include potential to enhance hydrologic and pollutant treatment performance of stormwater practices via media amendments and the use of innovative outlet control structures, as well as development of a more mechanistic understanding of hydrologic and water-quality functions to inform modeling and performance predictions. These studies serve to expand the field's knowledge base and will inform future efforts to further improve stormwater control and treatment at various spatial and temporal scales."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.2175/106143016X14696400495938", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "612887551"}, {"@idtype": "CABS", "$": "2016360472"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "657325410"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20164302947613"}, {"@idtype": "EMBASE", "$": "20160763702"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016690182"}, {"@idtype": "FLX", "$": "1238548"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "5022253"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20162171357"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84992135588"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84992135588"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CABS"}, {"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "EMBASE"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "FLX"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "26", "@month": "10", "@timestamp": "BST 06:14:20", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "182", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "04014058"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "141", "@issue": "3"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Ajmal M.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Ajmal", "ce:initials": "M."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Kim T.W.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Kim", "ce:initials": "T.W."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2015"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84923194309"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Quantifying excess stormwater using scs-cn-based rainfall runoff models and different curve number determination methods"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "J. The following review presents a synthesis of 181 journal articles published during 2015 that represent progress toward better characterizing, controlling, and treating urban stormwater runoff. The review is structured by general topical areas related to (1) stormwater quality and quantity characterization; (2) engineered stormwater control and treatment practices, including erosion and sediment control, stormwater ponds, constructed stormwater wetlands, bioretention, permeable pavement, greenroofs, and rainwater harvesting systems; and (3) watershed-scale modeling and optimization of stormwater control and treatment practices. Common research themes emerging from this collection of studies include potential to enhance hydrologic and pollutant treatment performance of stormwater practices via media amendments and the use of innovative outlet control structures, as well as development of a more mechanistic understanding of hydrologic and water-quality functions to inform modeling and performance predictions. These studies serve to expand the field's knowledge base and will inform future efforts to further improve stormwater control and treatment at various spatial and temporal scales.", "source-id": "mhhall@esf.edu"}, "ce:initials": "M.", "ce:given-name": "Myrna", "ce:surname": "Hall", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Hall M.", "ce:given-name": "Myrna", "ce:surname": "Hall", "ce:initials": "M."}, "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2303"}, {"$": "3322"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "ENVI"}, {"$": "SOCI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2013, Springer Science+Business Media New York. Green infrastructure (GI) is gaining wide popularity as a means to reduce urban stormwater runoff. The challenges to long-term success of many GI policies, however, depend on citizen understanding and willingness to be engaged in the process of GI implementation. In this study, we developed a conceptual model that incorporated human preferences and biophysical processes in a coupled manner to estimate stormwater runoff variation at the sewershed scale under different acceptable GI implementation scenarios. To investigate resident receptivity toward GI implementation, we conducted surveys in selected Syracuse sewersheds and developed the scenario of residents implementing rain barrels and rain gardens in their private properties based on the survey results. We simulated this scenario at the lot level using the model we developed within the framework of the EPA SWMM 5 model to estimate reductions in peak flow and total runoff volume for major storm events. With our model, we also tested the effect of planned government tree planting scenarios. The scenario simulations were applied in three urban sewersheds of varying socio-economic and biophysical structures in the City of Syracuse, New York. The simulation results indicated that both the \u201cgovernment participation\u201d and \u201chousehold participation\u201d scenarios, compared to pre-GI-development conditions, would contribute to a modest reduction in stormwater peak flow (&gt;4\u00a0%) and total runoff volume (&gt;5\u00a0%) across the simulated sewersheds. This study provides decision makers with a scientific methodology to quantify how human decisions can shape ecosystem function, and thus support sustainable stormwater management planning while addressing citizen preferences and needs."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1007/s11252-013-0304-5", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "52484381"}, {"@idtype": "CABS", "$": "2015917598"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "625316015"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20153201146196"}, {"@idtype": "EMBASE", "$": "2015277280"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "4728283"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84874727818"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84874727818"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CABS"}, {"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "EMBASE"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "20", "@month": "12", "@timestamp": "BST 10:38:22", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "47", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "85006017923"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Rain gardens \u2013 a how-to manual for homeowners"}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Bannerman R.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Bannerman", "ce:initials": "R."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Considine E.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Considine", "ce:initials": "E."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2003"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "The board of regents of the University of Wiscons"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Bannerman R, Considine E (2003) Rain gardens \u2013 a how-to manual for homeowners. J Hydrol 349(1\u20132):115\u2013124"}]}}}}, "subject-areas": {"subject-area": [{"@code": "2303", "@abbrev": "ENVI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Ecology"}, {"@code": "3322", "@abbrev": "SOCI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Urban Studies"}]}, "idxterms": null, "affiliation": {"affiliation-country": "United States", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60018741", "@id": "60018741", "affiliation-city": "Syracuse", "affilname": "State University of New York Upstate Medical University"}, "authkeywords": {"author-keyword": [{"@_fa": "true", "$": "Citizen preferences"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Green infrastructure"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Modeling of coupled urban human and hydrological systems"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "SWMM"}]}, "coredata": {"prism:volume": "19", "prism:coverDate": "2016-12-01", "prism:doi": "10.1007/s11252-013-0304-5", "dc:title": "Coupling human preferences with biophysical processes: modeling the effect of citizen attitudes on potential urban stormwater runoff", "prism:publicationName": "Urban Ecosystems", "dc:publisher": "Springer New York LLC barbara.b.bertram@gsk.com", "prism:issn": "15731642", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:84874727818", "prism:startingPage": "1433", "citedby-count": "0", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2013, Springer Science+Business Media New York. Green infrastructure (GI) is gaining wide popularity as a means to reduce urban stormwater runoff. The challenges to long-term success of many GI policies, however, depend on citizen understanding and willingness to be engaged in the process of GI implementation. In this study, we developed a conceptual model that incorporated human preferences and biophysical processes in a coupled manner to estimate stormwater runoff variation at the sewershed scale under different acceptable GI implementation scenarios. To investigate resident receptivity toward GI implementation, we conducted surveys in selected Syracuse sewersheds and developed the scenario of residents implementing rain barrels and rain gardens in their private properties based on the survey results. We simulated this scenario at the lot level using the model we developed within the framework of the EPA SWMM 5 model to estimate reductions in peak flow and total runoff volume for major storm events. With our model, we also tested the effect of planned government tree planting scenarios. The scenario simulations were applied in three urban sewersheds of varying socio-economic and biophysical structures in the City of Syracuse, New York. The simulation results indicated that both the \u201cgovernment participation\u201d and \u201chousehold participation\u201d scenarios, compared to pre-GI-development conditions, would contribute to a modest reduction in stormwater peak flow (&gt;4\u00a0%) and total runoff volume (&gt;5\u00a0%) across the simulated sewersheds. This study provides decision makers with a scientific methodology to quantify how human decisions can shape ecosystem function, and thus support sustainable stormwater management planning while addressing citizen preferences and needs.", "source-id": "145570", "srctype": "j", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84874727818", "@_fa": "true"}, Bioretention systems are increasingly being used in urban stormwater management systems, whereas quarry materials are used as filter media; however the use of quarry materials in this application reduces valuable natural resources. Such a novel approach of using recycled waste materials would significantly conserve valuable natural resources. A series of laboratory tests included particle size distribution, organic content, pH, specific gravity, flakiness index and hydraulic conductivity. Among the pollutants, total suspended solid (TSS), total phosphorus (TP) and total nitrogen (TN) were selected. A model for bioretention system was simulated to investigate the effectiveness of reclaimed asphalt material (RAP) and crushed brick (CB) materials in trapping selected pollutants. In terms of physical and chemical properties, RAP and CB were found to meet the stringent requirements of various environmental protection authorities. This research further indicates that recycled waste materials can be reused viably as alternative materials in bioretention systems."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": Bioretention systems are increasingly being used in urban stormwater management systems, whereas quarry materials are used as filter media; however the use of quarry materials in this application reduces valuable natural resources. Such a novel approach of using recycled waste materials would significantly conserve valuable natural resources. A series of laboratory tests included particle size distribution, organic content, pH, specific gravity, flakiness index and hydraulic conductivity. Among the pollutants, total suspended solid (TSS), total phosphorus (TP) and total nitrogen (TN) were selected. A model for bioretention system was simulated to investigate the effectiveness of reclaimed asphalt material (RAP) and crushed brick (CB) materials in trapping selected pollutants. In terms of physical and chemical properties, RAP and CB were found to meet the stringent requirements of various environmental protection authorities. This research further indicates that recycled waste materials can be reused viably as alternative materials in bioretention systems.", "source-id": "22752", "srctype": "j", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84948798207", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84948798207&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus-citedby", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84948798207&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "dc:creator": {"author": [{"@auid": "56517344300", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Rahman M.A.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/56517344300", "ce:initials": "M.A.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60030804", "@id": "60030804"}, "ce:given-name": "Md. {"affiliation": {"city": "New York", "@country": "usa", "country": "United States", "state": "NY", "@afid": "60007033", "organization": [{"$": "Economics Ph.D. Program"}, {"$": "Graduate Center-The City University of New York"}], "@dptid": "116981738", "postal-code": "10016"}, "author": {"@auid": "57190070441", "@seq": "5", "ce:indexed-name": "Yonzan N.", "ce:initials": "N.", "ce:surname": "Yonzan", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Yonzan N.", "ce:given-name": "N.", "ce:surname": "Yonzan", "ce:initials": "N."}, "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2300"}, {"$": "3305"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "ENVI"}, {"$": "SOCI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016, AESS. Green infrastructure shows promise as a \u201cbest management practice\u201d for controlling stormwater runoff, particularly in older cities with combined sewer systems. Green infrastructure systems have been used to both mitigate pollutant loading to adjacent waterways as well as to reduce burdens on municipal wastewater and stormwater collection and treatment systems during storm events. Although the electric and water/wastewater networks are closely linked, wastewater, water supply, and energy systems have been typically studied in isolation. Here, we present a hypothetical case study for applying a modular hybrid green infrastructure approach to manage stormwater in the Newtown Creek sewershed in New York City. We provide background information on current and projected stormwater flows to the Newtown Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) and evaluate how interception and storage rainwater in the Newtown Creek sewershed could offset inflows to the WWTP and how this offset of stormwater inflows might result in reduced electric grid burdens and cost savings for the city. Our assessment indicates that a 0.66\u00a0% conversion of impervious sewershed surface area to modular hybrid green infrastructure could reduce stormwater inflow volumes (i.e., for an annual median storm) to the Newtown Creek WWTP by 10\u00a0%. We estimate that this would result in a 14-MWh reduction in energy required for wastewater treatment per storm event. Collectively, our results suggest that implementation of modular hybrid green infrastructure can significantly reduce burdens on urban water and energy systems, thereby helping to mitigate water-energy nexus challenges associated with climate change and population growth."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1007/s13412-016-0379-4", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "609171928"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "647672177"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016373086"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "4897864"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "2016797941"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84977123780"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84977123780"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "30", "@month": "03", "@timestamp": "BST 23:00:34", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "56", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "267", "@last": "283"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": {"ce:indexed-name": "Ahern J.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Ahern", "ce:initials": "J."}}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2007"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "70349746449"}}, "ref-text": "Novotny V, Brown P, (eds), IWA Publishing, London, UK", "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Green infrastructure for cities: the spatial dimension"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Cities of the future towards integrated sustainable water and landscape management"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Ahern J (2007) Green infrastructure for cities: the spatial dimension. Island Press, Washington DC"}, {"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "695", "@last": "726"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "226", "@issue": "1"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Zanella A.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Zanella", "ce:initials": "A."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Camanho A.S.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Camanho", "ce:initials": "A.S."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Dias T.G.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Dias", "ce:initials": "T.G."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2015"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84939888137"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "The assessment of cities\u2019 livability integrating human wellbeing and environmental impact"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Ann Oper Res"}, "@id": "56", "ref-fulltext": "Zanella A, Camanho AS, Dias TG (2015) The assessment of cities\u2019 livability integrating human wellbeing and environmental impact. Ann Oper Res 226(1):695\u2013726"}]}}}}, "subject-areas": {"subject-area": [{"@code": "2300", "@abbrev": "ENVI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Environmental Science (all)"}, {"@code": "3305", "@abbrev": "SOCI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Geography, Planning and Development"}]}, "idxterms": null, "affiliation": {"affiliation-country": "United States", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60007033", "@id": "60007033", "affiliation-city": "New York", "affilname": "City University of New York"}, "authkeywords": {"author-keyword": [{"@_fa": "true", "$": "Electricity peak demand"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Green infrastructure"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Hybrid"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Sewershed"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Stormwater runoff"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Wastewater treatment"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Water-energy nexus"}]}, "coredata": {"prism:volume": "6", "prism:coverDate": "2016-03-01", "prism:doi": "10.1007/s13412-016-0379-4", "dc:title": "Hybrid green infrastructure for reducing demands on urban water and energy systems: a New York City hypothetical case study", "prism:publicationName": "Journal of Environmental Studies and Sciences", "dc:publisher": "Springer New York LLC barbara.b.bertram@gsk.com", "prism:issn": "21906491", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:84977123780", "prism:startingPage": "77", "citedby-count": "0", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016, AESS. Green infrastructure shows promise as a \u201cbest management practice\u201d for controlling stormwater runoff, particularly in older cities with combined sewer systems. Green infrastructure systems have been used to both mitigate pollutant loading to adjacent waterways as well as to reduce burdens on municipal wastewater and stormwater collection and treatment systems during storm events. Although the electric and water/wastewater networks are closely linked, wastewater, water supply, and energy systems have been typically studied in isolation. Here, we present a hypothetical case study for applying a modular hybrid green infrastructure approach to manage stormwater in the Newtown Creek sewershed in New York City. We provide background information on current and projected stormwater flows to the Newtown Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) and evaluate how interception and storage rainwater in the Newtown Creek sewershed could offset inflows to the WWTP and how this offset of stormwater inflows might result in reduced electric grid burdens and cost savings for the city. Our assessment indicates that a 0.66\u00a0% conversion of impervious sewershed surface area to modular hybrid green infrastructure could reduce stormwater inflow volumes (i.e., for an annual median storm) to the Newtown Creek WWTP by 10\u00a0%. We estimate that this would result in a 14-MWh reduction in energy required for wastewater treatment per storm event. Collectively, our results suggest that implementation of modular hybrid green infrastructure can significantly reduce burdens on urban water and energy systems, thereby helping to mitigate water-energy nexus challenges associated with climate change and population growth.", "source-id": "21100464902", "srctype": "j", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "G.A.", "ce:given-name": "Guna Alankarage", "ce:surname": "Hewa", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Hewa G.", "ce:given-name": "Guna Alankarage", "ce:surname": "Hewa", "ce:initials": "G.A."}, "@type": "auth"}]}, "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "403", "classification-description": "Urban and Regional Planning and Development"}, {"classification-code": "442.1", "classification-description": "Flood Control"}, {"classification-code": "722.4", "classification-description": "Digital Computers and Systems"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "79.25", "classification-description": "WATER ENGINEERING"}}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "3305"}, {"$": "1303"}, {"$": "1104"}, {"$": "2312"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "SOCI"}, {"$": "BIOC"}, {"$": "AGRI"}, {"$": "ENVI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 by the authors; licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland. Personal Computer Stormwater Management Model (PCSWMM) was applied to investigate: (1) hydrological responses in the Myponga catchment as a result of land use changes; and (2) the possibility of adopting Water Sensitive Urban Design (WSUD) technologies (bio-retention cells) to manage resulting floods. Calibrated and validated models predicted the measured data with satisfactory accuracy and reliability. Different urbanization scenarios were tested. When the level of urbanization increased from 10% to 70%, mean discharge increased from 45% to 322%. Frequency of flood at 2-year Average Recurrence Interval (ARI) increased from 1 to 44 and frequency of floods at 100-year ARI increased from none to 8. At 70% urbanisation, trialled bio-retention facilities used as WSUD measures almost completely ameliorated 2-year ARI floods by reducing the frequency of such events from 44 to 2. Floods at smaller ARIs (2, 5, 10 and 20 years) were effectively managed by WSUD measures while floods at 50- and 100-year ARIs remained unchanged. The overall results improve understanding of the severity of the impacts of land use changes on the hydrology of a catchment and the ability of bio-retention cells to alleviate the risk of small to medium floods in the Myponga catchment."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.3390/w8110511", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "613624966"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "659014087"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20165103139922"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "5056676"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20162526965"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "85005982480"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "85005982480"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "17", "@month": "12", "@timestamp": "BST 10:25:34", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "35", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "62", "@last": "81"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "529"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Elga S.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Elga", "ce:initials": "S."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Jan B.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Jan", "ce:initials": "B."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Okke B.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Okke", "ce:initials": "B."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2015"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84937779568"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Hydrological modelling of urbanized catchments: A review and future directions"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "J. "Myponga"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "PCSWMM"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "WSUD"}]}, "coredata": {"prism:volume": "8", "citedby-count": "0", "prism:coverDate": "2016-11-04", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:85005982480", "prism:issueIdentifier": "11", "dc:title": "The use of PCSWMM for assessing the impacts of land use changes on hydrological responses and performance of WSUD in managing the impacts at myponga catchment, South Australia", "prism:doi": "10.3390/w8110511", "intid": "85005982480", "source-id": "21100255400", "prism:aggregationType": "Journal", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/85005982480", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=85005982480&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus-citedby", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=85005982480&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "eid": "2-s2.0-85005982480", "prism:publicationName": "Water (Switzerland)", "dc:creator": {"author": [{"@auid": "57192372885", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Akhter M.S.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/57192372885", "ce:initials": "M.S.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60031846", "@id": "60031846"}, "ce:given-name": "Muhammad Saleem", "ce:surname": "Akhter", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Akhter M.", "ce:given-name": "Muhammad Saleem", "ce:surname": "Akhter", "ce:initials": "M.S."}}]}, "dc:publisher": "MDPI AG Postfach Basel CH-4005", "prism:issn": "20734441", "prism:url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/85005982480", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016 by the authors; licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland. Personal Computer Stormwater Management Model (PCSWMM) was applied to investigate: (1) hydrological responses in the Myponga catchment as a result of land use changes; and (2) the possibility of adopting Water Sensitive Urban Design (WSUD) technologies (bio-retention cells) to manage resulting floods. Calibrated and validated models predicted the measured data with satisfactory accuracy and reliability. Different urbanization scenarios were tested. When the level of urbanization increased from 10% to 70%, mean discharge increased from 45% to 322%. Frequency of flood at 2-year Average Recurrence Interval (ARI) increased from 1 to 44 and frequency of floods at 100-year ARI increased from none to 8. At 70% urbanisation, trialled bio-retention facilities used as WSUD measures almost completely ameliorated 2-year ARI floods by reducing the frequency of such events from 44 to 2. Floods at smaller ARIs (2, 5, 10 and 20 years) were effectively managed by WSUD measures while floods at 50- and 100-year ARIs remained unchanged. The overall results improve understanding of the severity of the impacts of land use changes on the hydrology of a catchment and the ability of bio-retention cells to alleviate the risk of small to medium floods in the Myponga catchment.", "article-number": "511", "srctype": "j"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": "57192372885", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Akhter M.S.", "author-url": response to environmental incentives for rain garden adoption", "source": {"website": {"ce:e-address": {"@type": "email", "$": "http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/(ISSN)1944-7973"}}, American Geophysical Union. All Rights Reserved. A decentralized approach to encourage the voluntary adoption of household stormwater management practices is increasingly needed to mitigate urban runoff and to comply with more stringent water quality regulations. We analyze the household response to a hypothetical rebate program to incentivize rain garden adoption using household survey data from the Baltimore-Washington corridor. We asked respondents whether the household would adopt a rain garden without a rebate or when offered a randomly assigned rebate. An interval-data model is used to estimate household demand on the willingness to pay (WTP) for a rain garden as a function of demographic factors, gardening activities, environmental attitudes, and other household characteristics. Estimation results indicate that mean WTP for a rain garden in our sample population is approximately 6.72 per square foot, corresponding to almost three-fourths of the installation cost. The expected adoption rate more than tripled when comparing no rebate versus a government rebate set at one-third of the installation cost, indicating that economic incentives matter. There is substantial heterogeneity in the WTP among households. Higher levels of WTP are estimated for households with higher environmental concern for the Chesapeake Bay and local streams, garden experience, higher income, and non-senior citizen adults. We conclude that a cost-share rebate approach is likely to significantly affect household adoption decisions, and the partial contributions paid by households can assist with lowering the substantial compliance costs for local governments to meet water quality requirements."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1002/2015WR018063", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "609111589"}, {"@idtype": "CABS", "$": "2016123685"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "647548725"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20161302166340"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016372119"}, {"@idtype": "FLX", "$": "1202235"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "4897413"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "2016793466"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84961778129"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84961778129"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CABS"}, {"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "FLX"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "30", "@month": "03", "@timestamp": "BST 10:48:43", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "20", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "W12501"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "47"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Ando A.W.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Ando", "ce:initials": "A.W."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Freitas L.C.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Freitas", "ce:initials": "L.C."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2011"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "82955173796"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Consumer demand for green stormwater management technology in an urban setting: The case of Chicago rain barrels"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Water Resour. Econ., 86 (1), 26-41."}]}}}}, "subject-areas": {"subject-area": [{"@code": "2312", "@abbrev": "ENVI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Water Science and Technology"}]}, "idxterms": null, "affiliation": {"affiliation-country": "United States", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60020304", "@id": "60020304", "affiliation-city": "College Park", "affilname": "University of Maryland"}, "authkeywords": {"author-keyword": [{"@_fa": "true", "$": "green infrastructure"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "impervious surface"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "stormwater management"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "urban runoff"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "water quality"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "willingness to pay"}]}, "coredata": {"prism:volume": "52", "prism:coverDate": "2016-02-01", "prism:doi": "10.1002/2015WR018063", "dc:title": "Household response to environmental incentives for rain garden adoption", "prism:publicationName": "Water Resources Research", "dc:publisher": "Blackwell Publishing Ltd customerservices@oxonblackwellpublishing.com", "prism:issn": "19447973", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:84961778129", "prism:startingPage": "1345", "citedby-count": "0", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016. American Geophysical Union. All Rights Reserved. A decentralized approach to encourage the voluntary adoption of household stormwater management practices is increasingly needed to mitigate urban runoff and to comply with more stringent water quality regulations. We analyze the household response to a hypothetical rebate program to incentivize rain garden adoption using household survey data from the Baltimore-Washington corridor. We asked respondents whether the household would adopt a rain garden without a rebate or when offered a randomly assigned rebate. An interval-data model is used to estimate household demand on the willingness to pay (WTP) for a rain garden as a function of demographic factors, gardening activities, environmental attitudes, and other household characteristics. Estimation results indicate that mean WTP for a rain garden in our sample population is approximately 6.72 per square foot, corresponding to almost three-fourths of the installation cost. The expected adoption rate more than tripled when comparing no rebate versus a government rebate set at one-third of the installation cost, indicating that economic incentives matter. There is substantial heterogeneity in the WTP among households. Higher levels of WTP are estimated for households with higher environmental concern for the Chesapeake Bay and local streams, garden experience, higher income, and non-senior citizen adults. We conclude that a cost-share rebate approach is likely to significantly affect household adoption decisions, and the partial contributions paid by households can assist with lowering the substantial compliance costs for local governments to meet water quality requirements.", "source-id": "18854", "srctype": "j", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": "2300"}, {"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "403.1", "classification-description": "Urban Planning and Development"}, {"classification-code": "405.3", "classification-description": "Surveying"}, {"classification-code": "443.3", "classification-description": "Precipitation"}, {"classification-code": "444", "classification-description": "Water Resources"}, {"classification-code": "446", "classification-description": "Waterworks"}, {"classification-code": "446.1", "classification-description": "Water {"classification-code": "971", "classification-description": "Social Sciences"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "79.25", "classification-description": "WATER ENGINEERING"}}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENVI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016, Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg. Low-impact development (LID) technologies, such as bioretention areas, rooftop rainwater harvesting, and xeriscaping can control stormwater runoff, supply non-potable water, and landscape open space. This study examines a hybrid system (HS) that combines LID technologies with a centralized water system to lessen the burden on a conventional system (CS). CS is defined as the stormwater collection and water supply infrastructure, and the conventional landscaping choices in the City of Atlanta. The study scope is limited to five single-family residential zones (SFZs), classified R-1 through R-5, and four multi-family residential zones (MFZs), classified RG-2 through RG-5. Population density increases from 0.4 (R-1) to 62.2 (RG-5) persons per 1,000 m2. We performed a life cycle assessment (LCA) comparison of CS and HS using TRACI 2.1 to simulate impacts on the ecosystem, human health, and natural resources.We quantified the impact of freshwater consumption using the freshwater ecosystem impact (FEI) indicator. Test results indicate that HS has a higher LCA single score than CS in zones with a low population density; however, the difference becomes negligible as population density increases. Incorporating LID in SFZs and MFZs can reduce potable water use by an average of 50% and 25%, respectively; however, water savings are negligible in zones with high population density (i.e., RG-5) due to the diminished surface area per capita available for LID technologies. The results demonstrate that LID technologies effectively reduce outdoor water demand and therefore would be a good choice to decrease the water consumption impact in the City of Atlanta.[Figure not available: see fulltext.]"}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1007/s11783-016-0851-0", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "610910114"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "651785317"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20162602547585"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016507328"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20161444400"}, {"@idtype": "SNCPX", "$": "2016054225"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84975806633"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84975806633"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "SNCPX"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "30", "@month": "06", "@timestamp": "BST 08:55:30", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "54", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-sourcetitle": "Water and Sustainability (Volume 4): U.S. Electricity Consumption for Water Supply &amp; Treatment\u2014The Next Half Century", "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "77953741505"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Goldstein R.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Goldstein", "ce:initials": "R."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Smith W.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Smith", "ce:initials": "W."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2002"}}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Goldstein R, Smith W. "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/36809617800", "ce:initials": "H.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60018394", "@id": "60018394"}, "ce:given-name": "Hyunju", "ce:surname": "Jeong", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Jeong H.", "ce:given-name": "Hyunju", "ce:surname": "Jeong", "ce:initials": "H."}}]}, "dc:publisher": "Higher Education Press", "prism:issn": "2095221X", "prism:url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84975806633", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016, Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg. Low-impact development (LID) technologies, such as bioretention areas, rooftop rainwater harvesting, and xeriscaping can control stormwater runoff, supply non-potable water, and landscape open space. This study examines a hybrid system (HS) that combines LID technologies with a centralized water system to lessen the burden on a conventional system (CS). CS is defined as the stormwater collection and water supply infrastructure, and the conventional landscaping choices in the City of Atlanta. The study scope is limited to five single-family residential zones (SFZs), classified R-1 through R-5, and four multi-family residential zones (MFZs), classified RG-2 through RG-5. Population density increases from 0.4 (R-1) to 62.2 (RG-5) persons per 1,000 m2. We performed a life cycle assessment (LCA) comparison of CS and HS using TRACI 2.1 to simulate impacts on the ecosystem, human health, and natural resources.We quantified the impact of freshwater consumption using the freshwater ecosystem impact (FEI) indicator. Test results indicate that HS has a higher LCA single score than CS in zones with a low population density; however, the difference becomes negligible as population density increases. Incorporating LID in SFZs and MFZs can reduce potable water use by an average of 50% and 25%, respectively; however, water savings are negligible in zones with high population density (i.e., RG-5) due to the diminished surface area per capita available for LID technologies. The results demonstrate that LID technologies effectively reduce outdoor water demand and therefore would be a good choice to decrease the water consumption impact in the City of Atlanta.[Figure not available: see fulltext.]", "article-number": "1", "srctype": "j"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": "36809617800", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Jeong H.", "author-url": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2303"}, {"$": "2309"}, {"$": "2308"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENVI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 International Consortium of Landscape and Ecological Engineering and Springer Japan Ecosystem services in urban areas have deteriorated year on year due to increased urbanization. As a consequence of increased urbanization, floods threaten inhabitants of various cities in Japan. Although a conventional way of treating urban flooding is to construct sewage systems, alternative approaches have to be developed because of their expense in the context of the current financial crisis, especially in local governments. Rain gardens, a type of low-impact development, have recently been recommended as a best management practice for the treatment of stormwater runoff in Northern European countries, the USA, etc. While demand for rain gardens has been increasing in Japan, there is a lack of knowledge about their functions and characteristics. The present study aims to explain the function of rain gardens through a verification experiment and field survey. This study shows that rain gardens are suitable for dealing with low flow volumes of rainwater, although their suitability could be slightly changed by soil properties and catchment area. Our field survey indicated that rain gardens must be connected to a sewage system. In addition, like other green infrastructure, rain gardens require maintenance. The most frequent type of maintenance is the disposal of garbage, as garbage can block channels running between a rain garden and a conventional sewage system. Moreover, garbage build up can lead to the retention of rain water for more than 36 h, and this water can become a habitat for mosquito larvae."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1007/s11355-016-0309-3", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "612271045"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "655549735"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016639230"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20161962095"}, {"@idtype": "SNCABS", "$": "2016057376"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84988344428"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84988344428"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "dc:publisher": "Springer-Verlag Tokyo orders@springer.jp", "prism:issn": "1860188X", "prism:url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84988344428", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84988344428&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016 International Consortium of Landscape and Ecological Engineering and Springer Japan Ecosystem services in urban areas have deteriorated year on year due to increased urbanization. As a consequence of increased urbanization, floods threaten inhabitants of various cities in Japan. Although a conventional way of treating urban flooding is to construct sewage systems, alternative approaches have to be developed because of their expense in the context of the current financial crisis, especially in local governments. Rain gardens, a type of low-impact development, have recently been recommended as a best management practice for the treatment of stormwater runoff in Northern European countries, the USA, etc. While demand for rain gardens has been increasing in Japan, there is a lack of knowledge about their functions and characteristics. The present study aims to explain the function of rain gardens through a verification experiment and field survey. This study shows that rain gardens are suitable for dealing with low flow volumes of rainwater, although their suitability could be slightly changed by soil properties and catchment area. Our field survey indicated that rain gardens must be connected to a sewage system. In addition, like other green infrastructure, rain gardens require maintenance. The most frequent type of maintenance is the disposal of garbage, as garbage can block channels running between a rain garden and a conventional sewage system. Moreover, garbage build up can lead to the retention of rain water for more than 36 h, and this water can become a habitat for mosquito larvae.", "source-id": "4700152496", "srctype": "j"}, "authors": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "525.2", "classification-description": "Energy Conservation"}, {"classification-code": "525.5", "classification-description": "Energy Conversion"}, {"classification-code": "641.2", "classification-description": "Heat Transfer"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "78.24", "classification-description": "HEAT EXCHANGE"}}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "3106"}, {"$": "2500"}, {"$": "2104"}, {"$": "2213"}, {"$": "2311"}, {"$": "2210"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "PHYS"}, {"$": "MATE"}, {"$": "ENER"}, {"$": "ENGI"}, {"$": "ENVI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. In this paper, the capacity of a natural circulation loop for transferring heat from a heat source to a heat sink has been analyzed. It is concluded that the capacity of the natural circulation loop depends on the conversion efficiency of the thermal energy from the heat source to the driving force for the circulation of the flow. The low conversion efficiency leading to weak driving force in such loops has been demonstrated analytically and validated through simulation results. This issue has resulted in a low heat transfer capacity in the circulation loop. To increase the heat transfer capacity, one has to improve this efficiency. To meet such a need, a novel efficiency booster has been developed in this paper. The booster essentially increases the flow driving force and hence significantly improves the overall heat transfer capacity. Design and analysis of this booster have been performed in detail. The performance has been examined through extensive computer simulations. It is concluded that the booster can indeed drastically improve the heat transfer capacity of the natural circulation loop.", "grantlist": {"grant-text": {"@xml:lang": "eng", "$": "The authors acknowledge the financial supports from National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC) No. 61174110. Thermal hydraulics"}]}, "coredata": {"pii": "S0029549316300656", "prism:coverDate": "2016-08-01", "prism:volume": "304", "dc:title": "An efficiency booster for energy conversion in natural circulation loops", "prism:publicationName": "Nuclear Engineering and Design", "dc:publisher": "Elsevier Ltd", "prism:issn": "00295493", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:84968756904", "prism:startingPage": "30", "citedby-count": "0", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. In this paper, the capacity of a natural circulation loop for transferring heat from a heat source to a heat sink has been analyzed. It is concluded that the capacity of the natural circulation loop depends on the conversion efficiency of the thermal energy from the heat source to the driving force for the circulation of the flow. The low conversion efficiency leading to weak driving force in such loops has been demonstrated analytically and validated through simulation results. This issue has resulted in a low heat transfer capacity in the circulation loop. To increase the heat transfer capacity, one has to improve this efficiency. To meet such a need, a novel efficiency booster has been developed in this paper. The booster essentially increases the flow driving force and hence significantly improves the overall heat transfer capacity. Design and analysis of this booster have been performed in detail. The performance has been examined through extensive computer simulations. It is concluded that the booster can indeed drastically improve the heat transfer capacity of the natural circulation loop.", "source-id": "17882", "srctype": "j", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": {"classification-code": "79.25", "classification-description": "WATER ENGINEERING"}}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "3305"}, {"$": "1303"}, {"$": "1104"}, {"$": "2312"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "SOCI"}, {"$": "BIOC"}, {"$": "AGRI"}, {"$": "ENVI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 by the authors. Low impact development (LID) best management practices (BMPs) collect, infiltrate, and treat stormwater runoff, and increase recharge to aquifers. Understanding the controls on reduction/oxidation (redox) conditions within LID BMPs is important for groundwater management because outflow from some LID BMPs can recharge aquifers and affect groundwater quality. Here we evaluate redox conditions of urban stormwater runoff in a LID infiltration trench in San Francisco, California, and quantify the relation between water saturation (%) and temperature (\u00b0C) and resulting dissolved oxygen (DO) concentrations, redox dynamics, and O2 reduction rates. The DO fluctuations have an inverse response to the duration of saturation of the trench. Anoxic (&lt; 0.5 mg/L) conditions often occurred within hours of stormwater events and persisted from a few hours to two days, which indicate that microbial respiration can be a limiting factor for DO. Temperature of stormwater runoff was not a statistically significant control on DO. The estimated O2 reduction rate is 0.003 mg\u00b7L-1\u00b7min-1, which is two to five orders of magnitude higher than in groundwater from previous studies. Higher rates of O2 reduction are a function of the more oxic and organic-rich stormwater runoff that drives faster microbial O2 reduction. Our findings have important implications for the design of infiltration trenches and other LID BMPs to achieve desired redox conditions for infiltrating stormwater toward minimizing groundwater contamination.", "grantlist": {"grant-text": {"@xml:lang": "eng", "$": "Funding for this research was provided by the Dawdy Hydrology Research Grant at San Francisco State University; G.A. Harris Research Instrumentation Grant from Decagon Devices, Inc.; and San Francisco State University ORSP-FOA 2010-2011. We thank Leonard Sklar and Bruce Manning (SFSU) for constructive comments on previous versions of this paper."}, "@complete": "y", "grant": {"grant-agency": "San Francisco State University", "grant-acronym": "SF State"}}}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.3390/w8100435", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "612980221"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "657608048"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20164603007534"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "5032690"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20162286661"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84994607833"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84994607833"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "12", "@month": "11", "@timestamp": "BST 12:25:46", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "58", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "333", "@last": "365"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "32"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Paul M.J.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Paul", "ce:initials": "M.J."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Meyer J.L.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Meyer", "ce:initials": "J.L."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2001"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "0035673406"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Streams in the urban landscape"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Annu. "dc:creator": {"author": [{"@auid": "57191905042", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Danfoura M.N.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/57191905042", "ce:initials": "M.N.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60027627", "@id": "60027627"}, "ce:given-name": "Mays N.", "ce:surname": "Danfoura", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Danfoura M.", "ce:given-name": "Mays N.", "ce:surname": "Danfoura", "ce:initials": "M.N."}}]}, "dc:publisher": "MDPI AG Postfach Basel CH-4005", "prism:issn": "20734441", "prism:url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84994607833", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016 by the authors. Low impact development (LID) best management practices (BMPs) collect, infiltrate, and treat stormwater runoff, and increase recharge to aquifers. Understanding the controls on reduction/oxidation (redox) conditions within LID BMPs is important for groundwater management because outflow from some LID BMPs can recharge aquifers and affect groundwater quality. Here we evaluate redox conditions of urban stormwater runoff in a LID infiltration trench in San Francisco, California, and quantify the relation between water saturation (%) and temperature (\u00b0C) and resulting dissolved oxygen (DO) concentrations, redox dynamics, and O2 reduction rates. The DO fluctuations have an inverse response to the duration of saturation of the trench. Anoxic (&lt; 0.5 mg/L) conditions often occurred within hours of stormwater events and persisted from a few hours to two days, which indicate that microbial respiration can be a limiting factor for DO. Temperature of stormwater runoff was not a statistically significant control on DO. The estimated O2 reduction rate is 0.003 mg\u00b7L-1\u00b7min-1, which is two to five orders of magnitude higher than in groundwater from previous studies. Higher rates of O2 reduction are a function of the more oxic and organic-rich stormwater runoff that drives faster microbial O2 reduction. Our findings have important implications for the design of infiltration trenches and other LID BMPs to achieve desired redox conditions for infiltrating stormwater toward minimizing groundwater contamination.", "article-number": "435", "srctype": "j"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": "57191905042", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Danfoura M.N.", "author-url": "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2404"}, {"$": "2402"}, {"$": "2303"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "IMMU"}, {"$": "ENVI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 FEMS 2016. Nitrogen (N) pollution of freshwater, estuarine and marine ecosystems is widespread and has numerous environmental and economic impacts. A portion of this excess N comes from urban watersheds comprised of natural and engineered ecosystems that can alter downstream N export. Studies of urban N cycling have focused on either specific ecosystems or on watershed-scale mass balances. Comparisons of specific N transformations across ecosystems are required to contextualize rates from individual studies. Here we reviewed urban N cycling in terrestrial, aquatic and engineered ecosystems, and compared N processing in these urban ecosystem types to native reference ecosystems. We found that net N mineralization and net nitrification rates were enhanced in urban forests and riparian zones relative to reference ecosystems. Denitrification was highly variable across urban ecosystem types, but no significant differences were found between urban and reference denitrification rates. When focusing on urban streams, ammonium uptake was more rapid than nitrate uptake in urban streams. Additionally, reduction of stormwater runoff coupled with potential decreases in N concentration suggests that green infrastructure may reduce downstream N export. Despite multiple environmental stressors in urban environments, ecosystems within urban watersheds can process and transform N at rates similar to or higher than reference ecosystems.", "grantlist": {"grant-text": {"@xml:lang": "eng", "$": "We thank A. Schuler for help acquiring multiple obscure references, and S. Lee translated results of a paper into English for our analysis. Conversations with co-PIs and participants in theCoastal SEES 'sweet spots' grant helped develop ideas included in this manuscript. We would also like to thank Max H\u00e4ggblom for inviting us to contribute this minireview. This manuscript was greatly improved by comments from G. Muyzer and two anonymous reviewers This project was supported by the National Science Foundation Coastal Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability (SEES) grant EAR-1426819: 'Effects of restoration and redevelopment on nitrogen dynamics in an urban coastal watershed' awarded to PG (PI) and ER (Co-PI), aswell as support fromthe Baltimore Ecosystem Study (http://www.beslter.org), a Long-term Ecological Research Station (LTER) in Baltimore, MD (NSF grant DEB-1027188)."}, "@complete": "y", "grant": {"grant-id": "DEB-1027188", "grant-agency": "Norsk Sykepleierforbund", "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84995743800&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "eid": "2-s2.0-84995743800", "prism:publicationName": "FEMS Microbiology Ecology", "dc:creator": {"author": [{"@auid": "56702419200", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Reisinger A.J.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/56702419200", "ce:initials": "A.J.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60017474", "@id": "60017474"}, "ce:given-name": "Alexander J.", "ce:surname": "Reisinger", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Reisinger A.", "ce:given-name": "Alexander J.", "ce:surname": "Reisinger", "ce:initials": "A.J."}}]}, "dc:publisher": "Oxford University Press jnl.info@oup.co.uk", "prism:issn": "15746941", "prism:url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84995743800", "dc:description": "\u00a9 FEMS 2016. Nitrogen (N) pollution of freshwater, estuarine and marine ecosystems is widespread and has numerous environmental and economic impacts. A portion of this excess N comes from urban watersheds comprised of natural and engineered ecosystems that can alter downstream N export. Studies of urban N cycling have focused on either specific ecosystems or on watershed-scale mass balances. Comparisons of specific N transformations across ecosystems are required to contextualize rates from individual studies. Here we reviewed urban N cycling in terrestrial, aquatic and engineered ecosystems, and compared N processing in these urban ecosystem types to native reference ecosystems. We found that net N mineralization and net nitrification rates were enhanced in urban forests and riparian zones relative to reference ecosystems. Denitrification was highly variable across urban ecosystem types, but no significant differences were found between urban and reference denitrification rates. When focusing on urban streams, ammonium uptake was more rapid than nitrate uptake in urban streams. Additionally, reduction of stormwater runoff coupled with potential decreases in N concentration suggests that green infrastructure may reduce downstream N export. Despite multiple environmental stressors in urban environments, ecosystems within urban watersheds can process and transform N at rates similar to or higher than reference ecosystems.", "article-number": "fiw198", "srctype": "j"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": "56702419200", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Reisinger A.J.", "author-url": "ASJC", "classification": "3304"}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "SOCI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 by Extension Journal, Inc. As part of an urban Extension initiative that focuses on reducing storm water runoff from impervious surfaces, Rutgers Cooperative Extension installed 5,000-gal cisterns at the Department of Public Works (DPW) facilities in Clark Township and the Township of Parsippany-Troy Hills, New Jersey, to harvest rainwater from the rooftops of the garages at these facilities. This project intercepts rooftop runoff before it can carry nonpoint source pollutants from the land surrounding the DPW garages. The harvested rainwater is used to fill street sweepers, wash municipal vehicles, and supply water for a \"green car wash\" to support volunteer groups."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "608855403"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "646909887"}, {"@idtype": "SNSOC", "$": "2016027921"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84959528991"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84959528991"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "SNSOC"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "10", "@month": "03", "@timestamp": "BST 13:44:32", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "3", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"voliss": {"@volume": "51", "@issue": "3"}}, "ref-website": {"ce:e-address": {"@type": "email", "$": "http://www.joe.org/joe/2013june/rb6.php"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Bakacs M.E.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Bakacs", "ce:initials": "M.E."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Haberland M.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Haberland", "ce:initials": "M."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Mangiafico S.S.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Mangiafico", "ce:initials": "S.S."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Winquist A.", "@seq": "4", "ce:surname": "Winquist", "ce:initials": "A."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Obropta C.C.", "@seq": "5", "ce:surname": "Obropta", "ce:initials": "C.C."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Boyajian A.", "@seq": "6", "ce:surname": "Boyajian", "ce:initials": "A."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Mellor S.", "@seq": "7", "ce:surname": "Mellor", "ce:initials": "S."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2013"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84884396694"}}, "ref-text": "[OnLine], Article 3RIB6. A.", "ce:surname": "Pomeroy", "ce:initials": "C.A."}, "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2210"}, {"$": "1100"}]}, {"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "443.3", "classification-description": "Precipitation"}, {"classification-code": "444.1", "classification-description": "Surface Water"}, {"classification-code": "444.2", "classification-description": "Groundwater"}, {"classification-code": "452.1", "classification-description": "Sewage"}, {"classification-code": "454.3", "classification-description": "Ecology and Ecosystems"}, {"classification-code": "483.1", "classification-description": "Soils and Soil Mechanics"}, {"classification-code": "694.4", "classification-description": "Storage"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "79.25", "classification-description": "WATER ENGINEERING"}}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "ENGI"}, {"$": "AGRI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016, Chinese Society of Agricultural Machinery. All right reserved. Urbanization caused hydrological change and increased stormwater runoff volumes, which led to flooding, erosion and the degradation of instream ecosystem health. Low impact development (LID) options had been proposed as an alternative approach to mimic the natural flow regime by using decentralized designs to control stormwater runoff at the source, rather than at a centralized location in the watershed. Hydrological regulation performances of these LID practices can be influenced by rainfall characteristics, such as rainfall intensity and duration. To evaluate the impacts of different rainfall reappearance periods, rainfall analysis was conducted to determine the rainfall characteristics and SCS II type was selected for the analysis. A modeling approach based on SWMM was described to incorporate these LID practices into an existing hydrological model to estimate the impacts of LID practices on the surface runoff. Results demonstrated that the LID practices led to significant stormwater control for different rainfall reappearance periods. Hydrological regulation performances of the LID practices were varied with rainfall reappearance periods. For LID practices with the same surface area, the detention pond performed the best in reducing peak flow rate, which was followed by infiltration trench, bioretention cell and porous pavement. Detention pond was capable to reduce the peak flow rate of 100-year storm to the value of 10-year storm, indicating significant performances. Differences in peak flow reduction were due to structure differences in the LID practices. For the infiltration regulation performances, infiltration trench had the highest recharge ratio for all the rainfall reappearance periods, followed by bioretention cell and porous pavement. Porous pavement, though made of 100% pervious material, infiltrated small runoff which was limited by the native soil infiltration rate when the rainfall volume exceeded the storage capacity. Deep analysis was conducted to determine the reasons that the LID practices performed differently when they had the same surface area. Results showed that the \"effective storage\", which was the water volume that a facility can contain, was the crucial factor. When rainfall intensity was larger than native soil infiltration rate, the excessive water was stored in the facility, and then it was released or infiltrated to the groundwater, depending on the facility structure. Consequently, the water exceeded the \"effective storage\" was flowed over the LID practices and made contribution to the surface runoff directly. Calculation results showed that the \"effective storage\" for the detention pond was 1861.20 m3, which was the largest among the four LID practices, and it explained the reason that detention pond worked the best in peak flow reduction. The \"effective storage\" for the infiltration trench, porous pavement and bioretention cell were 744.48 m3, 80.37 m3 and 565.14 m3, respectively."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.6041/j.issn.1000-1298.2016.06.023", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "610956814"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "651956796"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20162602544375"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20161438767"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84975691124"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84975691124"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "29", "@month": "06", "@timestamp": "BST 10:36:22", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "24", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "1438", "@last": "1448"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "92", "@issue": "6"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": {"ce:indexed-name": "Jacobson C.R.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Jacobson", "ce:initials": "C.R."}}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2011"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "79952438362"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Identification and quantification of the hydrological impacts of imperviousness in urban catchments: A review"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Journal of Environmental Management"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "JACOBSON C R. Landscape and Urban Planning, 2006, 74(2): 125-138."}, {"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "4413", "@last": "4426"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "29", "@issue": "20"}}, "ref-authors": {"et-al": null, "author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Rhea L.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Rhea", "ce:initials": "L."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Jarnagin T.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Jarnagin", "ce:initials": "T."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Hogan D.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Hogan", "ce:initials": "D."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2015"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84940791800"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Effects of urbanization and stormwater control measures on streamflows in the vicinity of Clarksburg, Maryland, USA"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Hydrological Processes"}, "@id": "3", "ref-fulltext": "RHEA L, JARNAGIN T, HOGAN D, et al. Transactions of the Chinese Society for Agricultural Machinery, 2015, 46(4): 147-154, 182.(in Chinese)"}, {"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "169", "@last": "175"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "45", "@issue": "2"}}, "ref-authors": {"et-al": null, "author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Yan Q.", "@seq": "1", "ce:given-name": "Qinghong", "ce:surname": "Yan", "ce:initials": "Q."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Yuan C.", "@seq": "2", "ce:given-name": "Cuiping", "ce:surname": "Yuan", "ce:initials": "C."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Lei T.", "@seq": "3", "ce:given-name": "Tingwu", "ce:surname": "Lei", "ce:initials": "T."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2014"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84897723818"}}, "ref-text": "in Chinese", "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Effect of rainstorm patterns and soil erosion control practices on soil and water loss in small watershed on loess plateau"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Transactions of the Chinese Society for Agricultural Machinery"}, "@id": "24", "ref-fulltext": "YAN Qinghong, YUAN Cuiping, LEI Tingwu, et al. Effect of rainstorm patterns and soil erosion control practices on soil and water loss in small watershed on loess plateau[J]. Transactions of the Chinese Society for Agricultural Machinery, 2014, 45(2): 169-175.(in Chinese)"}]}}}}, "subject-areas": {"subject-area": [{"@code": "2210", "@abbrev": "ENGI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Mechanical Engineering"}, {"@code": "1100", "@abbrev": "AGRI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Agricultural and Biological Sciences (all)"}]}, "idxterms": {"mainterm": [{"$": "Decentralized design"}, {"$": "Hydrological changes"}, {"$": "Hydrological modeling"}, {"$": "Low impact development"}, {"$": "Rainfall characteristics"}, {"$": "Return periods"}, {"$": "Structure difference"}, {"$": "SWMM"}], "@candidate": "n", "@weight": "b"}, "affiliation": [{"affiliation-country": "China", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60103148", "@id": "60103148", "affiliation-city": "Zhengzhou", "affilname": "North China University of Water Conservancy and Electric Power"}, {"affiliation-country": "United States", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60025488", "@id": "60025488", "affiliation-city": "Salt Lake City", "affilname": "University of Utah"}], "authkeywords": {"author-keyword": [{"@_fa": "true", "$": "Low impact development"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Return period"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Runoff"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "SWMM"}]}, "coredata": {"prism:volume": "47", "prism:coverDate": "2016-06-25", "prism:doi": "10.6041/j.issn.1000-1298.2016.06.023", "dc:title": "Hydrological regulation performances of LID practices based on different rainfall reappearance periods", "prism:publicationName": "Nongye Jixie Xuebao/Transactions of the Chinese Society for Agricultural Machinery", "dc:publisher": "Chinese Society of Agricultural Machinery", "prism:issn": "10001298", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:84975691124", "prism:startingPage": "178", "citedby-count": "0", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016, Chinese Society of Agricultural Machinery. All right reserved. Urbanization caused hydrological change and increased stormwater runoff volumes, which led to flooding, erosion and the degradation of instream ecosystem health. Low impact development (LID) options had been proposed as an alternative approach to mimic the natural flow regime by using decentralized designs to control stormwater runoff at the source, rather than at a centralized location in the watershed. Hydrological regulation performances of these LID practices can be influenced by rainfall characteristics, such as rainfall intensity and duration. To evaluate the impacts of different rainfall reappearance periods, rainfall analysis was conducted to determine the rainfall characteristics and SCS II type was selected for the analysis. A modeling approach based on SWMM was described to incorporate these LID practices into an existing hydrological model to estimate the impacts of LID practices on the surface runoff. Results demonstrated that the LID practices led to significant stormwater control for different rainfall reappearance periods. Hydrological regulation performances of the LID practices were varied with rainfall reappearance periods. For LID practices with the same surface area, the detention pond performed the best in reducing peak flow rate, which was followed by infiltration trench, bioretention cell and porous pavement. Detention pond was capable to reduce the peak flow rate of 100-year storm to the value of 10-year storm, indicating significant performances. Differences in peak flow reduction were due to structure differences in the LID practices. For the infiltration regulation performances, infiltration trench had the highest recharge ratio for all the rainfall reappearance periods, followed by bioretention cell and porous pavement. Porous pavement, though made of 100% pervious material, infiltrated small runoff which was limited by the native soil infiltration rate when the rainfall volume exceeded the storage capacity. Deep analysis was conducted to determine the reasons that the LID practices performed differently when they had the same surface area. Results showed that the \"effective storage\", which was the water volume that a facility can contain, was the crucial factor. When rainfall intensity was larger than native soil infiltration rate, the excessive water was stored in the facility, and then it was released or infiltrated to the groundwater, depending on the facility structure. Consequently, the water exceeded the \"effective storage\" was flowed over the LID practices and made contribution to the surface runoff directly. Calculation results showed that the \"effective storage\" for the detention pond was 1861.20 m3, which was the largest among the four LID practices, and it explained the reason that detention pond worked the best in peak flow reduction. The \"effective storage\" for the infiltration trench, porous pavement and bioretention cell were 744.48 m3, 80.37 m3 and 565.14 m3, respectively.", "source-id": "59863", "srctype": "j", "link":
