Processes", "issn": [{"@type": "electronic", "$": "10991085"}, {"@type": "print", "$": "08856087"}], "@srcid": "29467", "translated-sourcetitle": {"@xml:lang": "eng", "$": "Hydrological Processes"}, "publicationdate": {"month": "04", "day": "15", "date-text": {"@xfab-added": "true", "$": "15 April 2016"}, "year": "2016"}, "volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "1251", "@last": "1264"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "30", "@issue": "8"}}, "@type": "j"}, "author-group": [{"affiliation": {"city": "Lule\u00e5", "@country": "swe", "country": "Sweden", "@afid": "60007183", "organization": [{"$": "Department of Civil"}, {"$": "Environmental and Natural Resources Engineering"}, {"$": "Lule\u00e5 University of Technology"}], "@dptid": "105731521", "postal-code": "97187"}, "author": [{"@auid": "56567889600", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Moghadas S.", "ce:e-address": {"@type": "email", "$": "shahab.moghadas@ltu.se"}, "ce:initials": "S.", "ce:surname": "Moghadas", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Moghadas S.", "ce:given-name": "S.", "ce:surname": "Moghadas", "ce:initials": "S."}, "@type": "auth"}, {"@auid": "57132248700", "@seq": "2", "ce:indexed-name": "Gustafsson A.-M.", "ce:initials": "A.-M.", "ce:surname": "Gustafsson", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Gustafsson A.", "ce:given-name": "A. M.", "ce:surname": "Gustafsson", "ce:initials": "A.M."}, "@type": "auth"}, {"@auid": "6506775335", "@seq": "3", "ce:indexed-name": "Viklander P.", "ce:initials": "P.", "ce:surname": "Viklander", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Viklander P.", "ce:given-name": "P.", "ce:surname": "Viklander", "ce:initials": "P."}, "@type": "auth"}, {"@auid": "6603188755", "@seq": "5", "ce:indexed-name": "Viklander M.", "ce:initials": "M.", "ce:surname": "Viklander", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Viklander M.", "ce:given-name": "M.", "ce:surname": "Viklander", "ce:initials": "M."}, "@type": "auth"}]}, {"affiliation": {"city": "Burlington", "@country": "can", "country": "Canada", "state": "ON", "address-part": "867 Lakeshore Rd.", "@afid": "60011990", "organization": [{"$": "National Water Research Institute"}, {"$": "Environment Canada"}], "postal-code": "L7R 4A6"}, "author": {"@auid": "7006156676", "@seq": "4", "ce:indexed-name": "Marsalek J.", "ce:initials": "J.", "ce:surname": "Marsalek", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Marsalek J.", "ce:given-name": "J.", "ce:surname": "Marsalek", "ce:initials": "J."}, "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": "2312"}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENVI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 John Wiley &amp; Sons, Ltd. Infiltration of water into two frozen engineered soils of different gradation was studied in laboratory soil columns 1.2m long and 0.1m in diameter. Prior to testing, the soil moisture was adjusted to two levels, described by the gravimetric water content of 5% or 10%, and soils were compacted to about 80-90% of the maximum dry density and refrigerated to temperatures ranging from -8 to -2\u00b0C. Water with temperatures 8-9\u00b0C was thereafter fed on the top of columns at a constant head, and the times of water breakthrough in the column and reaching a steady percolation rate, as well as the percolation rate, were recorded. The soil water content was a critical factor affecting the thawing process; during freezing, soil moisture was converted into ice, which blocked pores, and its melting required high amounts of energy supplied by infiltrating water. Hence, the thawing of soils with higher initial water content was much slower than in lower moisture soils, and water breakthrough and the attainment of steady percolation required much longer times in higher moisture soils. Heat transfer between infiltrating water, soil ice, and frozen soil particles was well described by the energy budget equations, which constitute a parsimonious model of the observed processes. The finer grained soil and more compacted soil columns exhibited reduced porosity and required longer times for soil thawing. Practical implications of study results for design of bioretention facilities (BFs) in cold climate include the use of coarse engineered soils and fitting bioretention facilities with a drain facilitating soil drainage before the onset of freezing weather."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1002/hyp.10711", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "607045459"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", Canadian Journal of Soil Science 41(1): 115-123."}, {"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "1084", "@last": "1088"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "46", "@issue": "5"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Winterberg M.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Winterberg", "ce:initials": "M."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Tsotsas E.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Tsotsas", "ce:initials": "E."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2000"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "0033627530"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Impact of tube-to-particle-diameter ratio on pressure drop in packed beds"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "AIChE Journal"}, "@id": "39", "ref-fulltext": "Winterberg M, Tsotsas E. 2000. AIChE Journal 46(5): 1084-1088."}]}}}}, "subject-areas": {"subject-area": [{"@code": "2312", "@abbrev": "ENVI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Water Science and Technology"}]}, "idxterms": {"mainterm": [{"$": "Bioretention"}, {"$": "Different gradations"}, {"$": "Initial water contents"}, {"$": "Laboratory testing"}, {"$": "Maximum dry density"}, {"$": "Parsimonious modeling"}, {"$": "Snowmelt"}, {"$": "Soil water content"}], "@candidate": "n", "@weight": "b"}, "affiliation": [{"affiliation-country": "Canada", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60011990", "@id": "60011990", "affiliation-city": "Burlington", "affilname": "National Water Research Institute"}, {"affiliation-country": "Sweden", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60007183", "@id": "60007183", "affiliation-city": "Lulea", "affilname": "Lulea tekniska Universitet"}], "authkeywords": {"author-keyword": [{"@_fa": "true", "$": "Bioretention"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Frozen soils"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Infiltration"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Laboratory testing"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Snowmelt"}]}, "coredata": {"prism:volume": "30", "prism:coverDate": "2016-04-15", "prism:doi": "10.1002/hyp.10711", "dc:title": "Laboratory study of infiltration into two frozen engineered (sandy) soils recommended for bioretention", "prism:publicationName": "Hydrological Processes", "dc:publisher": "John Wiley and Sons Ltd Southern Gate Chichester, West Sussex PO19 8SQ", "prism:issn": "10991085", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:84947996817", "prism:startingPage": "1251", "citedby-count": "0", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016 John Wiley &amp; Sons, Ltd. Infiltration of water into two frozen engineered soils of different gradation was studied in laboratory soil columns 1.2m long and 0.1m in diameter. Prior to testing, the soil moisture was adjusted to two levels, described by the gravimetric water content of 5% or 10%, and soils were compacted to about 80-90% of the maximum dry density and refrigerated to temperatures ranging from -8 to -2\u00b0C. Water with temperatures 8-9\u00b0C was thereafter fed on the top of columns at a constant head, and the times of water breakthrough in the column and reaching a steady percolation rate, as well as the percolation rate, were recorded. The soil water content was a critical factor affecting the thawing process; during freezing, soil moisture was converted into ice, which blocked pores, and its melting required high amounts of energy supplied by infiltrating water. Hence, the thawing of soils with higher initial water content was much slower than in lower moisture soils, and water breakthrough and the attainment of steady percolation required much longer times in higher moisture soils. Heat transfer between infiltrating water, soil ice, and frozen soil particles was well described by the energy budget equations, which constitute a parsimonious model of the observed processes. The finer grained soil and more compacted soil columns exhibited reduced porosity and required longer times for soil thawing. Practical implications of study results for design of bioretention facilities (BFs) in cold climate include the use of coarse engineered soils and fitting bioretention facilities with a drain facilitating soil drainage before the onset of freezing weather.", "source-id": "29467", "srctype": "j", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "1705"}, {"$": "1706"}, {"$": "1710"}, {"$": "3311"}, {"$": "3313"}, {"$": "3322"}]}, {"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "443.3", "classification-description": "Precipitation"}, {"classification-code": "452.1", "classification-description": "Sewage"}, "classification": {"classification-code": "902", "classification-description": "FLUIDEX; Related Topics"}}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "COMP"}, {"$": "SOCI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 IEEE. The target of villages rainwater harvesting is to trap impermeable pavement and prevent rainwater runoff, and rainwater accumulated is mainly used for domestic miscellaneous water, environmental and ecological water. Low Impact Development (LID) is an analog of natural stormwater management. The rainwater collection system, which is based on the concept of LID stormwater control, is easy to operate and inexpensive. According to the characteristics of village rainwater harvesting, towns rainwater collection system will be divided into five parts: roof rainwater harvesting, courtyard rainwater harvesting, street rainwater harvesting, green rainwater harvesting and landscape rainwater storage pond. We summarize the principles of rainwater collection systems in towns and villages landscape applications: low-impact, low-maintenance, low-cost; design with nature, design to life; the overall planning, collaborative implementation. Provide reference for the ecological and circular village rainwater resource utilization."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1109/ICITBS.2015.24", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "610013505"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "649369723"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20161702294254"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84963800499"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84963800499"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "25", "@month": "04", "@timestamp": "BST 05:59:36", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "5", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-sourcetitle": "Typical Rainwater Utilization Mode of the Village [A]", "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84963796475"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Yong C.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Yong", "ce:initials": "C."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Shiming Z.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Shiming", "ce:initials": "Z."}]}, "ref-text": "Chinese Society for Environmental Sciences, Sichuan University. 2014 Chinese Academic Symposium Institute of Environmental Sciences (Chapter II) [C]. "scopus", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84963800499&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus-citedby", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84963800499&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016 IEEE. The target of villages rainwater harvesting is to trap impermeable pavement and prevent rainwater runoff, and rainwater accumulated is mainly used for domestic miscellaneous water, environmental and ecological water. Low Impact Development (LID) is an analog of natural stormwater management. The rainwater collection system, which is based on the concept of LID stormwater control, is easy to operate and inexpensive. According to the characteristics of village rainwater harvesting, towns rainwater collection system will be divided into five parts: roof rainwater harvesting, courtyard rainwater harvesting, street rainwater harvesting, green rainwater harvesting and landscape rainwater storage pond. We summarize the principles of rainwater collection systems in towns and villages landscape applications: low-impact, low-maintenance, low-cost; design with nature, design to life; the overall planning, collaborative implementation. Provide reference for the ecological and circular village rainwater resource utilization.", "article-number": "7383970", "srctype": "p"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": "57188861401", "@seq": "1", ABSTRACT: Low-impact development (LID) and green infrastructure (GI) have recently become well-known methods to capture, collect, retain, and remove pollutants in stormwater runoff. The research was conducted to assess the efficiency of LID/GI systems applied in removing the particulate and dissolved heavy metals (Zn, Pb, Cu, Ni, Cr, Cd, and Fe) from urban stormwater runoff. A total of 82 storm events were monitored over a four-year period (2010\u20132014) on six LID/GI systems including infiltration trenches, tree box filter, rain garden, and hybrid constructed wetlands employed for the management of road, parking lot, and roof runoff. It was observed that the heavy metal concentration increased proportionally with the total suspended solids concentration. Among the heavy metal constituents, Fe appeared to be highly particulate-bound and was the easiest to remove followed by Zn and Pb; while metals such as Cr, Ni, Cu, and Cd were mostly dissolved and more difficult to remove. The mass fraction ratios of metal constituents at the effluent were increased relative to the influent. All the systems performed well in the removal of particulate-bound metals and were more efficient for larger storms greater than 15\u2005mm wherein more particulate-bound metals were generated compared to smaller storms less than 5\u2005mm that produced more dissolved metals. The efficiency of the systems in removing the particulate-bound metals was restricted during high average/peak flows; that is, high-intensity storms events and when heavy metals have low concentration levels."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1080/09593330.2016.1147610", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "609151210"}, {"@idtype": "CABS", "$": "2016117601"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "647624417"}, {"@idtype": "EMBASE", "$": "20160233228"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016364645"}, {"@idtype": "FLX", "$": "1201158"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "4894326"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "2016759690"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84961207206"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84961207206"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CABS"}, {"$": "EMBASE"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "FLX"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "24", "@month": "03", "@timestamp": "BST 22:11:30", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "35", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "123", "@last": "138"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "227"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Birch G.F.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Birch", "ce:initials": "G.F."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Taylor S.E.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Taylor", "ce:initials": "S.E."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "1999"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "0032958048"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Source of heavy metals in sediments of the Port Jackson estuary, Australia"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Sci Tot Environ"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "G.F.Birch, S.E.Taylor. ABSTRACT: Low-impact development (LID) and green infrastructure (GI) have recently become well-known methods to capture, collect, retain, and remove pollutants in stormwater runoff. The research was conducted to assess the efficiency of LID/GI systems applied in removing the particulate and dissolved heavy metals (Zn, Pb, Cu, Ni, Cr, Cd, and Fe) from urban stormwater runoff. A total of 82 storm events were monitored over a four-year period (2010\u20132014) on six LID/GI systems including infiltration trenches, tree box filter, rain garden, and hybrid constructed wetlands employed for the management of road, parking lot, and roof runoff. It was observed that the heavy metal concentration increased proportionally with the total suspended solids concentration. Among the heavy metal constituents, Fe appeared to be highly particulate-bound and was the easiest to remove followed by Zn and Pb; while metals such as Cr, Ni, Cu, and Cd were mostly dissolved and more difficult to remove. The mass fraction ratios of metal constituents at the effluent were increased relative to the influent. All the systems performed well in the removal of particulate-bound metals and were more efficient for larger storms greater than 15\u2005mm wherein more particulate-bound metals were generated compared to smaller storms less than 5\u2005mm that produced more dissolved metals. The efficiency of the systems in removing the particulate-bound metals was restricted during high average/peak flows; that is, high-intensity storms events and when heavy metals have low concentration Compost based materials arv e widely used in filter media for improving soil capability and plant growth. The aim of this paper is to evaluate different types of compost materials used in engineered soil media through soil column investigation. Three (3) column, namely C1 (control), C2 and C3 had different types compost (10%) which were, commercial compost namely PEATGRO, Compost A and Compost B were prepared with 60% medium sand and 30% of topsoil. The diluted stormwater runoff was flushed to the columns and it was run for six (6) hour experiment. The influent and effluent samples were collected and tested for Water Quality Index (WQI) parameters. The results deduced that C3 with Elaeis Guineensis leaves compost (Compost B) achieved 90.45 (Class II) better than control condition which accomplished 84 (Class II) based on WQI Classification. C3 with Compost A (African Mahogany Leaves Compost) obtained only 59.39 (Class III). C3 with the composition of Compost B effectively removed most pollutants, including Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD, Ammoniacal Nitrogen (NH3-N), were reduced by 89\u00b14% and 96.6\u00b10.9%, respectively. The result concluded that Elaeis Guineensis leaves compost is recommended to be used as part of engineered soil media due to its capabilities in eliminating stormwater pollutants."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1088/1757-899X/136/1/012049", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "612503647"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "656211234"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20164102881118"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20162043909"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84989348364"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84989348364"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "07", "@month": "10", "@timestamp": "BST 12:08:59", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "16", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "3991", "@last": "3996"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "100", "@issue": "17"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Alcala M.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Alcala", "ce:suffix": "Jr.", "ce:initials": "M."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Jones K.D.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Jones", "ce:initials": "K.D."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Ren J.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Ren", "ce:initials": "J."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Andreassen T.E.", "@seq": "4", "ce:surname": "Andreassen", "ce:initials": "T.E."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2009"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "67349261992"}}, "ref-text": "Alcala M. "prism:url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84989348364", "dc:description": "\u00a9 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd. Compost based materials arv e widely used in filter media for improving soil capability and plant growth. The aim of this paper is to evaluate different types of compost materials used in engineered soil media through soil column investigation. Three (3) column, namely C1 (control), C2 and C3 had different types compost (10%) which were, commercial compost namely PEATGRO, Compost A and Compost B were prepared with 60% medium sand and 30% of topsoil. The diluted stormwater runoff was flushed to the columns and it was run for six (6) hour experiment. The influent and effluent samples were collected and tested for Water Quality Index (WQI) parameters. The results deduced that C3 with Elaeis Guineensis leaves compost (Compost B) achieved 90.45 (Class II) better than control condition which accomplished 84 (Class II) based on WQI Classification. C3 with Compost A (African Mahogany Leaves Compost) obtained only 59.39 (Class III). C3 with the composition of Compost B effectively removed most pollutants, including Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD, Ammoniacal Nitrogen (NH3-N), were reduced by 89\u00b14% and 96.6\u00b10.9%, respectively. The result concluded that Elaeis Guineensis leaves compost is recommended to be used as part of engineered soil media due to its capabilities in eliminating stormwater pollutants.", "article-number": "012049", "srctype": "p"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": "55347512100", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Takaijudin H.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/55347512100", "ce:initials": "H.", "affiliation": [{"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60000906", "@id": "60000906"}, {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60001278", "@id": "60001278"}], "ce:surname": "Takaijudin", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Takaijudin H.", "ce:given-name": "H.", "ce:surname": "Takaijudin", "ce:initials": "H."}}, {"@auid": "7006814462", "@seq": "2", "ce:indexed-name": "Ghani A.A.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/7006814462", "ce:initials": "A.A.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60000906", "@id": "60000906"}, "ce:surname": "Ghani", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Ghani A.", "ce:given-name": "A. X.", "ce:surname": "Lu", "ce:initials": "X.X."}, "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "403.2", "classification-description": "Regional Planning and Development"}, {"classification-code": "443", "classification-description": "Meteorology"}, {"classification-code": "443.3", "classification-description": "Precipitation"}, {"classification-code": "445.2", "classification-description": "Water Analysis"}, {"classification-code": "452.1", "classification-description": "Sewage"}, {"classification-code": "913.3", "classification-description": "Quality Assurance and Control"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "79.26", "classification-description": "WASTEWATER AND OTHER EFFLUENT/LIQUID WASTE ENGIN."}}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": "2312"}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENVI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 Elsevier B.V. The Active Beautiful Clean (ABC) Waters Program was implemented in 2006 as part of Singapore's stormwater management strategy and reflects the country's move towards Water Sensitive Urbanism through the adoption of Low-Impact Development (LID) ideology and practices. It is the first holistic and comprehensive LID program in the tropics and holds promise for extension to other tropical cities. This paper presents a comprehensive summary of the goals, LID practices (ABC design features) and design considerations as well as results of several monitored sites, including a constructed wetland, two rain gardens, green roofs and three canal restoration projects. We evaluate the ABC Waters Program based on these initial results and consider the challenges, issues and the research needs for it to meet its hydrological and water quality remediation goals. So far, the ABC design features evaluated perform well in removing particulates. Performance in nutrient removal is poor. With over 60 projects completed within 10 years, post-project monitoring and evaluation is necessary and complements on-going laboratory and modelling research projects conducted by local academic institutions."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1016/j.jhydrol.2016.04.063", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "610491137"}, {"@idtype": "CABS", "$": "2016190627"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "650724580"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20162202440289"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016458627"}, {"@idtype": "FLX", "$": "1213568"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "4932449"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20161241893"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84969850450"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84969850450"}], "ce:pii": "S0022169416302566"}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CABS"}, {"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "FLX"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "30", "@month": "05", "@timestamp": "BST 11:58:21", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "150", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "72"}}, "ref-authors": {"collaboration": {"ce:indexed-name": "ANZECC and ARMCANZ", "@seq": "1", "ce:text": "ANZECC and ARMCANZ"}}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2000"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "33845738098"}}, "ref-text": "Commonwealth of Australia, Canberra, Australia", "ref-sourcetitle": "Australian Guidelines for Urban Stormwater Management"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "ANZECC and ARMCANZ Australian Guidelines for Urban Stormwater Management 2000, 72. The Active Beautiful Clean (ABC) Waters Program was implemented in 2006 as part of Singapore's stormwater management strategy and reflects the country's move towards Water Sensitive Urbanism through the adoption of Low-Impact Development (LID) ideology and practices. It is the first holistic and comprehensive LID program in the tropics and holds promise for extension to other tropical cities. This paper presents a comprehensive summary of the goals, LID practices (ABC design features) and design considerations as well as results of several monitored sites, including a constructed wetland, two rain gardens, green roofs and three canal restoration projects. We evaluate the ABC Waters Program based on these initial results and consider the challenges, issues and the research needs for it to meet its hydrological and water quality remediation goals. So far, the ABC design features evaluated perform well in removing particulates. Performance in nutrient removal is poor. With over 60 projects completed within 10 years, post-project monitoring and evaluation is necessary and complements on-going laboratory and modelling research projects conducted by local academic institutions.", "source-id": "50089", "srctype": "j", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84969850450", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84969850450&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus-citedby", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84969850450&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "dc:creator": {"author": [{"@auid": "57189372885", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Lim H.S.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/57189372885", "ce:initials": "H.S.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60019870", "@id": "60019870"}, "ce:surname": "Lim", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Lim H.", "ce:given-name": "H. {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": "3304"}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "SOCI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 by Extension Journal, Inc. The delivery of wet grain during harvest is a complex and constantly changing problem about which Extension professionals have been unable to offer more than general advice. By capitalizing on important characteristics of mobile devices, a new app enables producers to fully benefit from detailed information universities have generated on grain drying and costs associated with delivery of grain to different locales. Development of such an app demonstrates the power of apps and mobile devices in allowing Extension to deliver previously unattainable services to its clientele.", "grantlist": {"grant-text": {"@xml:lang": "eng", "$": "This is publication No. 15-05-093 of the Kentucky Agricultural Experiment Station and is published with the approval of the Director. "@type": "auth"}]}, {"affiliation": {"city": "Chongqing", "@country": "chn", "country": "China", "@afid": "116219466", "organization": "Pengxi River Wetland Scientific Station in the Three Gorges Reservoir", "postal-code": "405400"}, "author": {"@auid": "57045296900", "@seq": "6", "ce:indexed-name": "Xiong S.", "ce:initials": "S.", "ce:given-name": "Sen", "ce:surname": "Xiong", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Xiong S.", "ce:given-name": "Sen", "ce:surname": "Xiong", "ce:initials": "S."}, "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "CABSCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "91.8.7", "classification-description": "ECOLOGICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; APPLIED ECOLOGY/POLLUTION; Aquatic Pollution"}}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "1105"}, {"$": "2303"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "AGRI"}, {"$": "ENVI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2015, Ecological Society of China. All rights reserved.For the first time in history, the majority of the world\u2019s population is located in urban areas. This milestone marks a critical turning point that will dramatically affect land and water environments. Increasingly, our cities need to be designed for adaptability and resilience to the impacts of population growth, urban densification, and increase in impervious areas, on the urban water environment. The water sensitive urban design (WSUD) has evolved from its early association with stormwater management to provide a broader framework for sustainable design and urban water management. It provides a common and unified method for integrating the interactions between the urban built form and the urban water cycle environment. This paper presents an overview of theory meaning, key principles, and technical architecture of WSUD, and at the same time, ecological ideas of WSUD has been summarized combined with the traditional ecological wisdom, which comprises the \u201call things together\u201dtheory, the idea of \u201cdaofaziran\u201d(following nature\u2019s lead), \u201cdesign with nature\u201d, and the idea of \u201cecological systems\u201d. WSUD technologies include green roofs, rain gardens, bioswales, soakaways, wet basins, dry basins, etc. However, to date, few studies have been conducted on the classification of all of the current technologies. In this paper, the WSUD technologies are categorized into three types according to the functions of different technologies: Water Balance, Water Quality, and Water Conservation. For the development of the WSUD worldwide, especially in China, which faces a more serious challenge because of rapid urbanization, further studies on creating technical architecture and summarizing ecological ideas are required. Kaixian Country located in the Three Gorges Reservoir area has become a representative water-sensitive urban area because of the water level control, splitting urbanization speed, and accompanying potential water environment crisis. In order to explore an fitting ecological restoration model to overcome the contradiction between high-speed urbanization and water environment security, this paper employs Kaixian as the example to design the urban water environmental pollution control system, based on the understanding of the ecological ideas of WSUD and the application of the WSUD technology. The whole design was divided into three parts: source control, process control, and receiving water control. The source control mainly used the green roof-ecological wall-rain garden system to decrease the source of pollutants; the process control was divided into four belts: recreation belt, ecological slope belt, landscape dick- pond belt, and natural drawdown belt, different WSUD strategies were implemented for every belt and some possible solutions were proposed for the contaminated urban water bodies. This design includes multi-stripe and multi-function modes that consider not only the physical elements of a place that provide the functional value, but also those elements that create a congenial atmosphere by enhancing the \u2018sense of place\u2019 (psychological value). The \u201cmulti-tape mode\u201d will provide a good example of controlling water pollution for other urban areas located in the TGR region."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.5846/stxb201408311727", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "607690353"}, {"@idtype": "CABS", "$": "2016014994"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "644124731"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016241252"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "4830161"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "2016193832"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84953875539"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84953875539"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CABS"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "18", "@month": "01", "@timestamp": "BST 14:57:28", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "82", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "6103", "@last": "6108"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "41", "@issue": "17"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Beck A.J.", "@seq": "1", "ce:given-name": "Aaron J.", "ce:surname": "Beck", "ce:initials": "A.J."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Sanudo-Wilhelmy S.A.", "@seq": "2", "ce:given-name": "Sergio A.", "ce:surname": "Sa\u00f1udo-Wilhelmy", "ce:initials": "S.A."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2007"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "34548572956"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Impact of water temperature and dissolved oxygen on copper cycling in an urban estuary"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Environmental Science &amp; Technology"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Aaron J Beck, Sergio A Sa\u00f1udo-Wilhelmy. Ecological Engineering, 2011, 37(11): 1718-1725."}, {"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "1", "@last": "11"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "61"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Li B.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Li", "ce:initials": "B."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Xiao H.Y.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Xiao", "ce:initials": "H.Y."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Yuan X.Z.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Yuan", "ce:initials": "X.Z."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Willison J.", "@seq": "4", "ce:surname": "Willison", "ce:initials": "J."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Liu H.", "@seq": "5", "ce:surname": "Liu", "ce:initials": "H."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Chen Z.L.", "@seq": "6", "ce:surname": "Chen", "ce:initials": "Z.L."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Zhang Y.W.", "@seq": "7", "ce:surname": "Zhang", "ce:initials": "Y.W."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Deng W.", "@seq": "8", "ce:surname": "Deng", "ce:initials": "W."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Yue J.S.", "@seq": "9", "ce:surname": "Yue", "ce:initials": "J.S."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2013"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84886305091"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Analysis of ecological and commercial benefits of a dike-pond project in the drawdown zone of the Three Gorges Reservoir"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Ecological Engineering"}, "@id": "82", "ref-fulltext": "Li B, Xiao H Y, Yuan X Z, Willison J H M, Liu H, Chen Z L, Zhang Y W, Deng W, Yue J S. Analysis of ecological and commercial benefits of a dike-pond project in the drawdown zone of the Three Gorges Reservoir. Ecological Engineering, 2013, 61(Part A): 1-11."}]}}}}, "subject-areas": {"subject-area": [{"@code": "1105", "@abbrev": "AGRI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Ecology, Evolution, Behavior and Systematics"}, {"@code": "2303", "@abbrev": "ENVI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Ecology"}]}, "idxterms": null, "affiliation": [{"affiliation-country": "China", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60023380", "@id": "60023380", "affiliation-city": "Chongqing", "affilname": "Chongqing University"}, {"affiliation-country": "China", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/116219466", "@id": "116219466", "affiliation-city": "Chongqing", "affilname": "Pengxi River Wetland Scientific Station in the Three Gorges Reservoir"}], "authkeywords": {"author-keyword": [{"@_fa": "true", "$": "Ecological ideas"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Pollution control system"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Urban water environment"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Water sensitive urban design"}]}, "coredata": {"prism:volume": "36", "prism:coverDate": "2016-01-01", "prism:doi": "10.5846/stxb201408311727", "dc:title": "Construction of the urban water environmental pollution control system based on the ecological ideas of water sensitive urban design", "prism:publicationName": "Shengtai Xuebao/ Acta Ecologica Sinica", "dc:publisher": "Ecological Society of Chinashengtaixuebao@mail.rcees.ac.cn", "prism:issn": "18722032", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:84953875539", "prism:startingPage": "30", "citedby-count": "0", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2015, Ecological Society of China. All rights reserved.For the first time in history, the majority of the world\u2019s population is located in urban areas. This milestone marks a critical turning point that will dramatically affect land and water environments. Increasingly, our cities need to be designed for adaptability and resilience to the impacts of population growth, urban densification, and increase in impervious areas, on the urban water environment. The water sensitive urban design (WSUD) has evolved from its early association with stormwater management to provide a broader framework for sustainable design and urban water management. It provides a common and unified method for integrating the interactions between the urban built form and the urban water cycle environment. This paper presents an overview of theory meaning, key principles, and technical architecture of WSUD, and at the same time, ecological ideas of WSUD has been summarized combined with the traditional ecological wisdom, which comprises the \u201call things together\u201dtheory, the idea of \u201cdaofaziran\u201d(following nature\u2019s lead), \u201cdesign with nature\u201d, and the idea of \u201cecological systems\u201d. WSUD technologies include green roofs, rain gardens, bioswales, soakaways, wet basins, dry basins, etc. However, to date, few studies have been conducted on the classification of all of the current technologies. In this paper, the WSUD technologies are categorized into three types according to the functions of different technologies: Water Balance, Water Quality, and Water Conservation. For the development of the WSUD worldwide, especially in China, which faces a more serious challenge because of rapid urbanization, further studies on creating technical architecture and summarizing ecological ideas are required. Kaixian Country located in the Three Gorges Reservoir area has become a representative water-sensitive urban area because of the water level control, splitting urbanization speed, and accompanying potential water environment crisis. In order to explore an fitting ecological restoration model to overcome the contradiction between high-speed urbanization and water environment security, this paper employs Kaixian as the example to design the urban water environmental pollution control system, based on the understanding of the ecological ideas of WSUD and the application of the WSUD technology. The whole design was divided into three parts: source control, process control, and receiving water control. The source control mainly used the green roof-ecological wall-rain garden system to decrease the source of pollutants; the process control was divided into four belts: recreation belt, ecological slope belt, landscape dick- pond belt, and natural drawdown belt, different WSUD strategies were implemented for every belt and some possible solutions were proposed for the contaminated urban water bodies. This design includes multi-stripe and multi-function modes that consider not only the physical elements of a place that provide the functional value, but also those elements that create a congenial atmosphere by enhancing the \u2018sense of place\u2019 (psychological value). The \u201cmulti-tape mode\u201d will provide a good example of controlling water pollution for other urban areas located in the TGR region.", "source-id": "130109", "srctype": "j", "link": [{"@rel": Y.", "ce:surname": "Testik", "ce:initials": "F.Y."}, "ce:degrees": "A.M.ASCE", "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "406", "classification-description": "Highway Engineering"}, {"classification-code": "443.3", "classification-description": "Precipitation"}, {"classification-code": "619.1", "classification-description": "Pipe, Piping and Pipelines"}, {"classification-code": "723.5", "classification-description": "Computer Applications"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "78.22", "classification-description": "PROCESS EQUIPMENT"}, {"classification-code": "79.21", "classification-description": "FLUID MECHANICS"}]}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2205"}, {"$": "2312"}, {"$": "2210"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "ENGI"}, {"$": "ENVI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 American Society of Civil Engineers. A detailed computational parametric study of a perforated pipe underdrain surrounded by loose aggregate has been conducted. Several controlling geometric parameters (i.e., trench width, head, aggregate depth over the pipe, pipe wall perforation area per unit length of pipe, and the area of individual perforations) were considered and the variation of pipe discharge characteristics as a function of these parameters has been quantified. Results indicate that, for each combination of these parameters, there is a finite pipe length after which discharge does not increase with increasing pipe length. This pipe length depends on the pipe wall perforation area per unit length of pipe, pipe cross-sectional area, and losses associated with them. It was found that the effective pipe system discharge coefficient is independent of the channel width, aggregate depth, and head over the pipe for the range of parameters tested. The computational fluid dynamics (CFD) results were used to develop an equation for the system discharge coefficient as a function of the pipe geometry. This equation can be used for sizing underdrains in low-impact development (LID) best management practice (BMP) stormwater systems. These results have practical applications in many stormwater LID/BMPs of similar setup to that used in this study (e.g., porous pavements and infiltration trenches) for sizing and analyzing the hydraulic behavior of the underdrains. This allows design engineers to quantify the peak outflow from the underdrain when the systems are flooded."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1061/(ASCE)HY.1943-7900.0001214", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "613450813"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "658609213"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20164803072593"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016749025"}, {"@idtype": "FLX", "$": "1245082"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "5044524"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20162415103"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84997344189"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84997344189"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "FLX"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "30", "@month": "11", "@timestamp": "BST 12:41:09", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "31", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84978734742"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "\"Numerical model for hydraulic performance of perforated pipe under-drain surrounded by loose aggregate\""}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Afrin T.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Afrin", "ce:initials": "T."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Khan A.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Khan", "ce:initials": "A."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Kaye N.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Kaye", "ce:initials": "N."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Testik F.", "@seq": "4", "ce:surname": "Testik", "ce:initials": "F."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2016"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "J. "coredata": {"prism:volume": "142", "citedby-count": "0", "prism:coverDate": "2016-12-01", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:84997344189", "prism:issueIdentifier": "12", "dc:title": "Parametric study of perforated pipe underdrains surrounded by loose aggregate", "prism:doi": "10.1061/(ASCE)HY.1943-7900.0001214", "intid": "84997344189", "source-id": "16283", "prism:aggregationType": "Journal", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84997344189", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84997344189&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus-citedby", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84997344189&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "eid": "2-s2.0-84997344189", "prism:publicationName": "Journal of Hydraulic Engineering", "dc:creator": {"author": [{"@auid": "57190251263", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Afrin T.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/57190251263", "ce:initials": "T.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60026610", "@id": "60026610"}, "ce:surname": "Afrin", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Afrin T.", "ce:given-name": "T.", "ce:surname": "Afrin", "ce:initials": "T."}, "ce:degrees": "S.M.ASCE"}]}, "dc:publisher": "American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) onlinejls@asce.org", "prism:issn": "19437900", "prism:url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84997344189", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016 American Society of Civil Engineers. A detailed computational parametric study of a perforated pipe underdrain surrounded by loose aggregate has been conducted. Several controlling geometric parameters (i.e., trench width, head, aggregate depth over the pipe, pipe wall perforation area per unit length of pipe, and the area of individual perforations) were considered and the variation of pipe discharge characteristics as a function of these parameters has been quantified. Results indicate that, for each combination of these parameters, there is a finite pipe length after which discharge does not increase with increasing pipe length. This pipe length depends on the pipe wall perforation area per unit length of pipe, pipe cross-sectional area, and losses associated with them. It was found that the effective pipe system discharge coefficient is independent of the channel width, aggregate depth, and head over the pipe for the range of parameters tested. The computational fluid dynamics (CFD) results were used to develop an equation for the system discharge coefficient as a function of the pipe geometry. This equation can be used for sizing underdrains in low-impact development (LID) best management practice (BMP) stormwater systems. These results have practical applications in many stormwater LID/BMPs of similar setup to that used in this study (e.g., porous pavements and infiltration trenches) for sizing and analyzing the hydraulic behavior of the underdrains. This allows design engineers to quantify the peak outflow from the underdrain when the systems are flooded.", "article-number": "04016066", "srctype": "j"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": "57190251263", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Afrin T.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/57190251263", "ce:initials": "T.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60026610", "@id": "60026610"}, "ce:surname": "Afrin", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Afrin T.", "ce:given-name": "T.", "ce:surname": "Afrin", "ce:initials": "T."}, "ce:degrees": "S.M.ASCE"}, {"@auid": "8242578000", "@seq": "2", "ce:indexed-name": "Kaye N.B.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/8242578000", "ce:initials": "N.B.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60026610", "@id": "60026610"}, "ce:surname": "Kaye", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Kaye N.", "ce:given-name": "N. {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "443.3", "classification-description": "Precipitation"}, {"classification-code": "483.1", "classification-description": "Soils and Soil Mechanics"}, {"classification-code": "632.1", "classification-description": "Hydraulics"}, {"classification-code": "911.2", "classification-description": "classification-description": "WATER ENGINEERING"}]}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2205"}, {"$": "2216"}, {"$": "2215"}, {"$": "1909"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "ENGI"}, {"$": "EART"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "Sustainable infrastructure research has led to an increase in the use of stormwater control measures (SCM). Rain gardens are vegetated SCMs which promote infiltration, evapotranspiration, or both. As the use of rain gardens and other sustainable practices becomes more common, cost effective techniques are needed to determine site properties for design and to assess their performance after construction. A major component of rain garden performance is hydraulic conductivity, which can be determined by infiltration testing. The double-ring infiltrometer test, while commonly used in practice, can take long periods of time to complete. Single-ring infiltrometer tests often use less water and are require less time to implement, enabling more tests to be completed in the same period of time. Seven small single ring infiltrometer tests were performed at a rain garden on Villanova's campus in Fall 2014 to determine the field hydraulic conductivity of surficial soil in the SCM. The instrumentation at the site used in the field study has been recording the recession rate in the pond over the past twelve years. Comparing the pond recession rate to the field hydraulic conductivity, it was found that the less commonly used single-ring infiltrometer method can be an accurate predictor of SCM performance."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1061/9780784480151.051", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "612013053"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "654881300"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20163702784080"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20161874298"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84985027777"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84985027777"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "09", "@month": "09", "@timestamp": "BST 05:47:13", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "16", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "77949339996"}}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Standard Test Method For Infiltration Rate Of Soils In Field Using Double-ring Infiltrometer", "ref-text": "American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) , West Conshohocken, Pa D3385-09", "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2009"}}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM). "dc:title": "Evaluation of Field Hydraulic Conductivity Data: Comparing Spot Infiltrometer Test Data to Continuous Recession Data", "prism:publicationName": "Geotechnical Special Publication", "dc:publisher": "American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) onlinejls@asce.org", "prism:issn": "08950563", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:84985027777", "prism:startingPage": "517", "citedby-count": "0", "dc:description": "Sustainable infrastructure research has led to an increase in the use of stormwater control measures (SCM). Rain gardens are vegetated SCMs which promote infiltration, evapotranspiration, or both. As the use of rain gardens and other sustainable practices becomes more common, cost effective techniques are needed to determine site properties for design and to assess their performance after construction. A major component of rain garden performance is hydraulic conductivity, which can be determined by infiltration testing. The double-ring infiltrometer test, while commonly used in practice, can take long periods of time to complete. Single-ring infiltrometer tests often use less water and are require less time to implement, enabling more tests to be completed in the same period of time. Seven small single ring infiltrometer tests were performed at a rain garden on Villanova's campus in Fall 2014 to determine the field hydraulic conductivity of surficial soil in the SCM. The instrumentation at the site used in the field study has been recording the recession rate in the pond over the past twelve years. Comparing the pond recession rate to the field hydraulic conductivity, it was found that the less commonly used single-ring infiltrometer method can be an accurate predictor of SCM performance.", "auth"}]}, "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "442.1", "classification-description": "Flood Control"}, {"classification-code": "443.3", "classification-description": "Precipitation"}, {"classification-code": "452.1", "classification-description": "Sewage"}, {"classification-code": "483.1", "classification-description": "Soils and Soil Mechanics"}, {"classification-code": "632.1", "classification-description": "Hydraulics"}, {"classification-code": "803", "classification-description": "Chemical Agents and Basic Industrial Chemicals"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "79.25", "classification-description": "WATER ENGINEERING"}}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2216"}, {"$": "2205"}, {"$": "2215"}, {"$": "1909"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "ENGI"}, {"$": "EART"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 ASCE. Rain gardens are stormwater control measures (SCMs) that control runoff volume and mitigate pollutants through infiltration and evapotranspiration. Many states have developed manuals to aid in the design and construction of SCMs, including rain gardens. Delaware's manual, the Delaware urban runoff management model, recommends that the following soil mixture be used in rain gardens to achieve percolation within 48 hours of the rain event: 50% construction sand, 20-30% topsoil, and 20-30% mulch. The engineered soils that were designed to meet the Delaware soil mix criterion in two failed rain gardens and two samples of native soils in a tract development in Glasgow, Delaware were examined for this paper. The soils were classified according to the USDA (common in stormwater design) and USCS (common in geotechnical design) classification systems. In addition, the saturated hydraulic conductivity and the soil water characteristic curves were determined. Soil samples from both failed rain gardens were classified as clayey sands (SC), while the native soil samples were classified as silty sands (SM). Soils in the failed rain gardens also had lower hydraulic conductivities compared to the native soils. The presence of clays in the engineered soils of the failed rain gardens impaired their ability to infiltrate, resulting in an unusually long residence time of the captured stormwater. This case study highlights the importance of testing native soils at a proposed site and re-using them if their infiltration capacity is appropriate. In this case, the acceptable native soils were replaced with an inadequate soil mixture resulting in an inferior performance and added expense."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1061/9780784480175.005", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "612312483"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "655627488"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20163902848350"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20161978595"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84988476337"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84988476337"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "27", "@month": "09", "@timestamp": "BST 06:10:22", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "23", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"voliss": {"@volume": "13", "@issue": "10"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Ahmed F.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Ahmed", "ce:initials": "F."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Nestingen R.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Nestingen", "ce:initials": "R."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Nieber J.L.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Nieber", "ce:initials": "J.L."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Gulliver J.S.", "@seq": "4", "ce:surname": "Gulliver", "ce:initials": "J.S."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Hozalski R.M.", "@seq": "5", "ce:surname": "Hozalski", "ce:initials": "R.M."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2014"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84907969816"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "A modified Philip-Dunne infiltrometer for measuring the field-saturated hydraulic conductivity of surface soil"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "The Vadose Zone Journal"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Ahmed, F., Nestingen, R., Nieber, J. Rain gardens are stormwater control measures (SCMs) that control runoff volume and mitigate pollutants through infiltration and evapotranspiration. Many states have developed manuals to aid in the design and construction of SCMs, including rain gardens. Delaware's manual, the Delaware urban runoff management model, recommends that the following soil mixture be used in rain gardens to achieve percolation within 48 hours of the rain event: 50% construction sand, 20-30% topsoil, and 20-30% mulch. The engineered soils that were designed to meet the Delaware soil mix criterion in two failed rain gardens and two samples of native soils in a tract development in Glasgow, Delaware were examined for this paper. The soils were classified according to the USDA (common in stormwater design) and USCS (common in geotechnical design) classification systems. In addition, the saturated hydraulic conductivity and the soil water characteristic curves were determined. Soil samples from both failed rain gardens were classified as clayey sands (SC), while the native soil samples were classified as silty sands (SM). Soils in the failed rain gardens also had lower hydraulic conductivities compared to the native soils. The presence of clays in the engineered soils of the failed rain gardens impaired their ability to infiltrate, resulting in an unusually long residence time of the captured stormwater. This case study highlights the importance of testing native soils at a proposed site and re-using them if their infiltration capacity is appropriate. In this case, the acceptable native soils were replaced with an inadequate soil mixture resulting in an inferior performance and added expense.", "source-id": "27028", "srctype": "p", "link": Alex", "ce:surname": "Breitzke", "ce:initials": "E.A."}, "@type": "auth"}]}, "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2305"}, {"$": "2312"}]}, {"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "443.3", "classification-description": "Precipitation"}, {"classification-code": "444", "classification-description": "Water Resources"}, {"classification-code": "444.1", "classification-description": "Surface Water"}, {"classification-code": "452.1", "classification-description": "Sewage"}, {"classification-code": "545.1", "classification-description": "Iron"}, {"classification-code": "802.3", "classification-description": "Chemical Operations"}, {"classification-code": "804", "classification-description": "Chemical Products Generally"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "78.23", "classification-description": "MIXING AND SEPARATION"}, {"classification-code": "79.25", "classification-description": "WATER ENGINEERING"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENVI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 ASCE. As a stormwater management technique, rain gardens can reduce runoff volume and retain contaminants such as metals found in urban stormwater runoff. Due to organic material in rain gardens such as plants, mulch, and compost, however, rain gardens have been shown to release dissolved phosphorus, which is typically targeted for removal from stormwater. As a result, rain gardens can act as a source of dissolved phosphorus and cause a corresponding increase in the dissolved phosphorus concentration in runoff. This project assesses the performance of an iron-enhanced rain garden with regards to its ability to retain dissolved phosphorus. Studies have shown that iron-enhanced sand filtration has the ability to remove over 90% of dissolved phosphorus from stormwater runoff. A new rain garden design incorporating a layer of sand mixed with iron shavings at 5% (by weight) beneath typical rain garden media was tested under laboratory conditions for its ability to retain dissolved phosphorus. Performance was compared to a control rain garden that contained a layer of only sand beneath typical rain garden media. Preliminary results indicated that the iron-enhanced rain garden consistently retained approximately 90% or more of the dissolved phosphorus load after more than 61 m of water had infiltrated. The control rain garden initially retained over 50% of the dissolved phosphorus load. However, after the same depth of infiltrated water, dissolved phosphorus retention dropped significantly and ultimately became negative."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1061/9780784479889.020", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "611045725"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "652116948"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20162702563784"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84976503372"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84976503372"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "05", "@month": "07", "@timestamp": "BST 08:46:23", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "12", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "4139", "@last": "4155"}}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84976475436"}}, "ref-sourcetitle": "American Water Works Association, and Water Environment Federation (APHA/AWWA/WEF)", "ref-text": "American Public Health Association 4500-P phosphorus Standard methods for the examination of water and wastewater, L. S. Clesceri, A. E. Greenberg, and A. D. Eaton, eds., APHA, Washington, D. C", "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "1998"}}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "American Public Health Association, American Water Works Association, and Water Environment Federation (APHA/AWWA/WEF). 1998. \"4500-P phosphorus. \" Standard methods for the examination of water and wastewater, L. Papers from Sessions of the Proceedings of the 2016 World Environmental and Water Resources Congress", "dc:creator": {"author": [{"@auid": "56111472800", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Weiss P.T.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/56111472800", "ce:initials": "P.T.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60025751", "@id": "60025751"}, "ce:given-name": "Peter T.", "ce:surname": "Weiss", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Weiss P.", "ce:given-name": "Peter T.", "ce:surname": "Weiss", "ce:initials": "P.T."}}]}, "dc:publisher": "American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) onlinejls@asce.org", "prism:url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84976503372", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84976503372", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84976503372&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus-citedby", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84976503372&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "dc:description": "\u00a9 ASCE. As a stormwater management technique, rain gardens can reduce runoff volume and retain contaminants such as metals found in urban stormwater runoff. Due to organic material in rain gardens such as plants, mulch, and compost, however, rain gardens have been shown to release dissolved phosphorus, which is typically targeted for removal from stormwater. As a result, rain gardens can act as a source of dissolved phosphorus and cause a corresponding increase in the dissolved phosphorus concentration in runoff. This project assesses the performance of an iron-enhanced rain garden with regards to its ability to retain dissolved phosphorus. Studies have shown that iron-enhanced sand filtration has the ability to remove over 90% of dissolved phosphorus from stormwater runoff. A new rain garden design incorporating a layer of sand mixed with iron shavings at 5% (by weight) beneath typical rain garden media was tested under laboratory conditions for its ability to retain dissolved phosphorus. Performance was compared to a control rain garden that contained a layer of only sand beneath typical rain garden media. Preliminary results indicated that the iron-enhanced rain garden consistently retained approximately 90% or more of the dissolved phosphorus load after more than 61 m of water had infiltrated. The control rain garden initially retained over 50% of the dissolved phosphorus load. However, after the same depth of infiltrated water, dissolved phosphorus retention dropped significantly and ultimately became negative.", "source-id": "21100466766", "srctype": "p"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": "56111472800", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Weiss P.T.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/56111472800", "ce:initials": "P.T.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60025751", "@id": "60025751"}, "ce:given-name": "Peter T.", "ce:surname": "Weiss", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Weiss P.", "ce:given-name": "Peter T.", "ce:surname": "Weiss", "ce:initials": "P.T."}}, {"@auid": "6504805012", "@seq": "2", "ce:indexed-name": "Aljobeh Z.Y.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/6504805012", "ce:initials": "Z.Y.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60025751", "@id": "60025751"}, "ce:given-name": "Zuhdi Y.", "ce:surname": "Aljobeh", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Aljobeh Z.", "ce:given-name": "Zuhdi Y.", "ce:surname": "Aljobeh", "ce:initials": "Z.Y."}}, {"@auid": "57190018072", "@seq": "3", "ce:indexed-name": "Bradford C.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/57190018072", "ce:initials": "C.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60025751", "@id": "60025751"}, "ce:given-name": "Chelsey", "ce:surname": "Bradford", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Bradford C.", "ce:given-name": "Chelsey", "ce:surname": "Bradford", "ce:initials": "C."}}, {"@auid": "57190013319", "@seq": "4", "ce:indexed-name": "Breitzke E.A.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/57190013319", "ce:initials": "E.A.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60025751", "@id": "60025751"}, "ce:given-name": "E. "Zhenqing", "ce:surname": "Shi", "ce:initials": "Z."}, "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2304"}, {"$": "2310"}, {"$": "2311"}, {"$": "2305"}]}, {"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "443.3", "classification-description": "Precipitation"}, {"classification-code": "461.2", "classification-description": "Biological Materials"}, {"classification-code": "471", "classification-description": "Marine Science and Oceanography"}, {"classification-code": "481.2", "FLXCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "902", "classification-description": "FLUIDEX; Related Topics"}}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENVI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 Elsevier B.V..Bioretention systems are designed to remove contaminants from stormwater; however, studies have shown that bioretention systems can export excess nitrogen, phosphorus, and copper when amended with compost. The objectives of this study were (1) to quantify removal of nitrates, phosphorus, copper, and dissolved organic matter (DOM) from compost-amended bioretention systems, and (2) to investigate the role of DOM on the leaching of copper. Simulated bioretention systems were irrigated with stormwater for seven storms in two-weeks intervals. Leachates were analyzed for nutrients, copper, and DOM. Visual MINTEQ was used to determine the speciation of copper and to quantify interactions of copper with DOM. Results showed that compost-amended bioretention systems were a source of nitrates, phosphorus, and DOM. Nitrate and phosphorus amounts were elevated up to three orders of magnitude in the leachate compared to the stormwater itself. Bioretention systems were a source for copper during the first 3-5 storms, but during later storms, they were a sink for copper. Copper speciation modeling indicated that the majority of dissolved copper was complexed with DOM. Dissolved organic matter thus helps to mobilize copper from the compost, particularly in the first few storms after compost application. However, since copper-DOM complexes are usually much less toxic than free copper ions, we expect that compost amendments may reduce harmful effects of copper on aquatic organisms."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1016/j.scitotenv.2016.02.125", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "608914949"}, {"@idtype": "CABS", "$": "2016105179"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "647091409"}, "4887005"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "2016690713"}, {"@idtype": "RMC", "$": "2016082785"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84960374894"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84960374894"}], "ce:pii": "S0048969716303357"}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CABS"}, {"$": "CHEM"}, {"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "EMBASE"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "RMC"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": however, studies have shown that bioretention systems can export excess nitrogen, phosphorus, and copper when amended with compost. The objectives of this study were (1) to quantify removal of nitrates, phosphorus, copper, and dissolved organic matter (DOM) from compost-amended bioretention systems, and (2) to investigate the role of DOM on the leaching of copper. Simulated bioretention systems were irrigated with stormwater for seven storms in two-weeks intervals. Leachates were analyzed for nutrients, copper, and DOM. Visual MINTEQ was used to determine the speciation of copper and to quantify interactions of copper with DOM. Results showed that compost-amended bioretention systems were a source of nitrates, phosphorus, and DOM. Nitrate and phosphorus amounts were elevated up to three orders of magnitude in the leachate compared to the stormwater itself. Bioretention systems were a source for copper during the first 3-5 storms, but during later storms, they were a sink for copper. Copper speciation modeling indicated that the majority of dissolved copper was complexed with DOM. Dissolved organic matter thus helps to mobilize copper from the compost, particularly in the first few storms after compost application. However, since copper-DOM complexes are usually much less toxic than free copper ions, we expect that compost amendments may reduce harmful effects of copper on aquatic organisms.", "source-id": F.", "ce:surname": "Hunt", "ce:initials": "W.F."}, "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "443.3", "classification-description": "Precipitation"}, {"classification-code": "444", "classification-description": "Water Resources"}, {"classification-code": "444.1", "classification-description": "Surface Water"}, {"classification-code": "446.1", "classification-description": "Water Supply Systems"}, {"classification-code": "452.1", "classification-description": "Sewage"}, {"classification-code": "619.2", "classification-description": "Tanks"}, {"classification-code": "821.3", "classification-description": "Agricultural Methods"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "79.22", "classification-description": "THE ATMOSPHERE"}}, {"@type": "GEOCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "70.4.3.2", "classification-description": "Water Resources; Planning"}, {"classification-code": "71.6.14", "classification-description": "Water resources and management"}]}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2305"}, {"$": "2304"}, {"$": "2205"}, {"$": "2300"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "ENVI"}, {"$": "ENGI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 American Society of Civil Engineers. Rainwater harvesting (RWH) systems provide the dual, but often opposing, benefits of acting as alternate water supply sources and providing detention/retention of roof runoff that would otherwise become stormwater runoff. A major challenge that exists when using a RWH system to simultaneously accomplish stormwater and water-conservation benefits in nonarid regions is that these systems are often underutilized, thus remaining full a large portion of the time. For a system to mitigate stormwater runoff, however, there must be sufficient room available in the tank to store a runoff event. Two novel approaches were implemented to improve the ability of RWH systems to serve as both water-conservation practices and stormwater-management practices: an active release technology and a passive release technology. Two locations in Craven County, North Carolina, had RWH systems installed to capture roof runoff and store it for nonpotable uses. One system was equipped with the passive release mechanism, which divided the storage tank into a detention storage volume that was slowly drained between storm events, and a retention storage volume, which was retained for harvesting. The other system included an active release mechanism that automatically released harvested water based on real-time forecasted precipitation and current RWH system conditions. Despite minimal usage, both systems provided substantial stormwater mitigation. The passive release system averaged 82 and 90% volume and peak flow reductions, respectively, while the active release system reduced volumes and peak flows by an average of 91 and 93%, respectively. Both of these mechanisms exhibit great promise in revolutionizing rainwater harvesting system use to meet both water-conservation and stormwater-management goals."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1061/(ASCE)EE.1943-7870.0001108", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "611332838"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "652800784"}, {"@idtype": "CHEM", "$": "2016150757"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20163002639918"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016548892"}, {"@idtype": "FLX", "$": "1224096"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "4969668"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20161614459"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84978884554"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84978884554"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CHEM"}, {"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "FLX"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "26", "@month": "07", "@timestamp": "BST 05:29:58", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "31", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "13", "@last": "21"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "40", "@issue": "1"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Ahmed W.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Ahmed", "ce:initials": "W."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Gardner T.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Gardner", "ce:initials": "T."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Toze S.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Toze", "ce:initials": "S."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2011"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "78651388075"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Microbiological quality of roof-harvested rainwater and health risks: A review"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "J Environ.
