"http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/57190285604", "ce:initials": "K.D.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60020027", "@id": "60020027"}, "ce:surname": "Gee", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Gee K.", "ce:given-name": "K. D.", "ce:surname": "Gee", "ce:initials": "K.D."}}]}, "dc:publisher": "American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) onlinejls@asce.org", "prism:issn": "07339372", "prism:url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84978884554", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016 American Society of Civil Engineers. Rainwater harvesting (RWH) systems provide the dual, but often opposing, benefits of acting as alternate water supply sources and providing detention/retention of roof runoff that would otherwise become stormwater runoff. A major challenge that exists when using a RWH system to simultaneously accomplish stormwater and water-conservation benefits in nonarid regions is that these systems are often underutilized, thus remaining full a large portion of the time. For a system to mitigate stormwater runoff, however, there must be sufficient room available in the tank to store a runoff event. Two novel approaches were implemented to improve the ability of RWH systems to serve as both water-conservation practices and stormwater-management practices: an active release technology and a passive release technology. Two locations in Craven County, North Carolina, had RWH systems installed to capture roof runoff and store it for nonpotable uses. One system was equipped with the passive release mechanism, which divided the storage tank into a detention storage volume that was slowly drained between storm events, and a retention storage volume, which was retained for harvesting. The other system included an active release mechanism that automatically released harvested water based on real-time forecasted precipitation and current RWH system conditions. Despite minimal usage, both systems provided substantial stormwater mitigation. The passive release system averaged 82 and 90% volume and peak flow reductions, respectively, while the active release system reduced volumes and peak flows by an average of 91 and 93%, respectively. Both of these mechanisms exhibit great promise in revolutionizing rainwater harvesting system use to meet both water-conservation and stormwater-management goals.", "article-number": "04016039", "srctype": "j"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": "57190285604", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Gee K.D.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/57190285604", "ce:initials": "K.D.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60020027", "@id": "60020027"}, "ce:surname": "Gee", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Gee K.", "ce:given-name": "K. "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "403", "classification-description": "Urban and Regional Planning and Development"}, {"classification-code": "403.1", "classification-description": "Urban Planning and Development"}, {"classification-code": "443.3", "classification-description": "Precipitation"}, {"classification-code": "444.1", "classification-description": "Surface Water"}, {"classification-code": "444.2", "classification-description": "Groundwater"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "79.25", "classification-description": "WATER ENGINEERING"}}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": "2312"}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENVI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 Elsevier B.V. This paper presents a novel modeling analysis of a 40-year-long dataset to examine the impact of urbanization, with widespread stormwater infiltration, on groundwater levels and the water balance of a watershed. A dataset on the hydrologic impact of urbanization with extensive stormwater infiltration is not widely available, and is important because many municipalities are considering infiltration as an alternative to traditional stormwater systems. This study analyzes groundwater level observations from an urban catchment located in Perth, Western Australia. The groundwater observation data cover approximately a 40-year-long period where land use changes (particularly due to urbanization) occurred; moreover, the monitored area contains both undeveloped and urbanized areas where stormwater infiltration is common practice via soakwells (shallow vertical infiltration wells). The data is analyzed using a distributed and dynamic hydrological model to simulate the groundwater response. The model explicitly couples a soakwell model with a groundwater model so that the performance of the soakwells is reduced by the increase of groundwater levels. The groundwater observation data is used to setup, calibrate and validate a coupled MIKE SHE-MIKE URBAN groundwater model and the model is used to quantify the extent of groundwater rise as a result of the urbanization process. The modeled urbanization processes included the irrigation of new established private and public gardens, the reduction of evapotranspiration due to a decrease in green areas, and the development of artificial stormwater infiltration. The study demonstrates that urbanization with stormwater infiltration affects the whole catchment water balance, increasing recharge and decreasing evapotranspiration. These changes lead to a rise in the groundwater table and an increase in the probability of groundwater seepage above terrain."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1016/j.jhydrol.2016.11.030", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "613575305"}, {"@idtype": "CABS", "$": "2016423400"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "658926625"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20165103133618"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016772949"}, {"@idtype": "FLX", "$": "1248311"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "5055188"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20162515206"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "85003875099"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "85003875099"}], "ce:pii": "S0022169416307363"}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CABS"}, {"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "FLX"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "16", "@month": "12", "@timestamp": "BST 05:45:15", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "61", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "31", "@last": "42"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "1975"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": {"ce:indexed-name": "Allen A.D.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Allen", "ce:initials": "A.D."}}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "1976"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "85003792027"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Outline of the hydrogeology of the superficial formations of the Swan Coastal Plain: Western Australia Geological Survey"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Ann. This paper presents a novel modeling analysis of a 40-year-long dataset to examine the impact of urbanization, with widespread stormwater infiltration, on groundwater levels and the water balance of a watershed. A dataset on the hydrologic impact of urbanization with extensive stormwater infiltration is not widely available, and is important because many municipalities are considering infiltration as an alternative to traditional stormwater systems. This study analyzes groundwater level observations from an urban catchment located in Perth, Western Australia. The groundwater observation data cover approximately a 40-year-long period where land use changes (particularly due to urbanization) occurred; moreover, the monitored area contains both undeveloped and urbanized areas where stormwater infiltration is common practice via soakwells (shallow vertical infiltration wells). The data is analyzed using a distributed and dynamic hydrological model to simulate the groundwater response. The model explicitly couples a soakwell model with a groundwater model so that the performance of the soakwells is reduced by the increase of groundwater levels. The groundwater observation data is used to setup, calibrate and validate a coupled MIKE SHE-MIKE URBAN groundwater model and the model is used to quantify the extent of groundwater rise as a result of the urbanization process. The modeled urbanization processes included the irrigation of new established private and public gardens, the reduction of evapotranspiration due to a decrease in green areas, and the development of artificial stormwater infiltration. The study demonstrates that urbanization with stormwater infiltration affects the whole catchment water balance, increasing recharge and decreasing evapotranspiration. These changes lead to a rise in the groundwater table and an increase in the probability of groundwater seepage above terrain.", "source-id": "50089", "srctype": "j", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@country": "usa", "organization": [{"$": "Ecology"}, {"$": "Evolution and Environmental Biology Department"}, {"$": "Columbia University"}]}, "author": {"@auid": "42962113400", "@seq": "3", "ce:indexed-name": "Palmer M.I.", "ce:initials": "M.I.", "ce:given-name": "Matthew I.", "ce:surname": "Palmer", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Palmer M.", "ce:given-name": "Matthew I.", "ce:surname": "Palmer", "ce:initials": "M.I."}, "ce:degrees": "PhD", "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "1107"}, {"$": "1111"}, {"$": "2303"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "AGRI"}, {"$": "ENVI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 Elsevier GmbH This study investigated the impacts of successive simulated droughts and floods on two plant species (Carex lurida and Liriope muscari) commonly installed in green-infrastructure (GI) sites built in the urban northeast USA. The instantaneous stomatal conductance, and belowground biomass growth (in a second drought experiment only) were used as metrics, since they are indicators of the ability of plants to provide ecosystem functions such as transpiration and carbon uptake. The results indicate that both species have greater tolerance for floods than for droughts. Signs of stress were only evident after a simulated flood exceeding the duration of 95% of all storms that occurred in this geographic region between 1950 and 2000. By contrast, simulated droughts had a more pronounced effect on both the instantaneous conductance measures during drought and the recovery following the cessation of drought in both species. Liriope subjected to drought treatments were all able to recover and to re-establish stomatal conductance levels similar to those displayed by a control group even after repeated drought treatments. By contrast, Carex showed reduced recovery after multiple droughts, in two separate rounds of experiments. However, regardless of moisture conditions and treatment, Carex generally displayed higher stomatal conductance than Liriope, indicating greater transpiration, and CO2 uptake than Liriope. The belowground biomass results supported this finding, i.e. Carex gained more belowground biomass than Liriope during all experiments. At the end of the experiment, the Carex subjected to drought had less than one sixth the belowground biomass of the control treatment, whereas for Liriope this ratio was only 50% (drought to control). The drought treatments, therefore, reduced the biomass of Carex more than it did Liriope, when compared to the respective control plants. Nonetheless, both species survived repeated cycles of droughts and floods, suggesting that these particular species are both likely suitable for use in GI facilities, despite projected future increases in the frequency and intensity of floods and droughts in this geographic region. From a practical perspective, the results suggest no need for irrigation or potential replacement of plants in GI systems in a changed climate."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1016/j.ufug.2016.08.014", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "612053003"}, {"@idtype": "CABS", "$": "2016313889"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "654973898"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016628268"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "4998252"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20161913894"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84986550747"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84986550747"}], "ce:pii": "S1618866716300401"}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CABS"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "15", "@month": "09", "@timestamp": "BST 14:15:22", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "64", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-authors": {"author": {"ce:indexed-name": "Akbari H.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Akbari", "ce:initials": "H."}}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2009"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84986582536"}}, "ref-text": "Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory", "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Cooling our communities"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "A guidebook on tree planting and light-colored surfacing"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Akbari, H., Cooling our communities. A guidebook on tree planting and light-colored surfacing, 2009, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory."}, {"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "450", "@last": "458"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "13", "@issue": "3"}}, "ref-website": {"ce:e-address": {"@type": "email", "$": "http://ac.els-cdn.com/S1618866714000557/1-s2.0-S1618866714000557-main.pdf?_tid=16da8ff8-3150-11e5-8f61-00000aacb361&amp;acdnat=1437665755_e1ce4dcc88df351947bf64b5d3791f3f"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Asgarzadeh M.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Asgarzadeh", "ce:initials": "M."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Vahdati K.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Vahdati", "ce:initials": "K."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Lotfi M.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Lotfi", "ce:initials": "M."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Arab M.", "@seq": "4", "ce:surname": "Arab", "ce:initials": "M."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Babaei A.", "@seq": "5", "ce:surname": "Babaei", "ce:initials": "A."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Naderi F.", "@seq": "6", "ce:surname": "Naderi", "ce:initials": "F."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Rouhani G.", "@seq": "7", "ce:surname": "Rouhani", "ce:initials": "G."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2014"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84905752245"}}, "ref-text": "Retrieved from", "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Plant selection method for urban landscapes of semi-arid cities (a case study of Tehran)"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Urban For. J. Am. Water Res. Assoc., 2015."}, {"ref-info": {"ref-website": {"ce:e-address": {"@type": "email", "$": "ccrun.org/seminars"}}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84986574301"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": {"ce:indexed-name": "Wiener S.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Wiener", "ce:initials": "S."}}, "ref-text": "(Producer), 2015, August 19, 2015. Cities Retrieved from ccrun.org/seminars."}, {"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "205", "@last": "213"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "134", "@issue": "3"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Xie H.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Xie", "ce:initials": "H."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Eheart J.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Eheart", "ce:initials": "J."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "An H.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "An", "ce:initials": "H."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2008"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "42449158955"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Hydrologic and economic implications of climate change for typical river basins of the agricultural midwestern United States"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage."}, "@id": "64", "ref-fulltext": "Xie, H., Eheart, J., An, H., Hydrologic and economic implications of climate change for typical river basins of the agricultural midwestern United States. J. Water Resour. Plann. Manage. 134:3 (2008), 205\u2013213, 10.1061/(ASCE)0733-9496(2008)134:3(205)."}]}}}}, "subject-areas": {"subject-area": [{"@code": "1107", "@abbrev": "AGRI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Forestry"}, {"@code": "1111", "@abbrev": "AGRI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Soil Science"}, {"@code": "2303", "@abbrev": "ENVI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Ecology"}]}, "idxterms": null, "affiliation": [{"affiliation-country": "United States", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60030162", "@id": "60030162", "affiliation-city": "New York", "affilname": "Columbia University in the City of New York"}, {"affiliation-country": "United States", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60014662", "@id": "60014662", "affiliation-city": "Philadelphia", "affilname": "Drexel University"}], "authkeywords": null, "coredata": {"pii": "S1618866716300401", "prism:coverDate": "2016-12-01", "prism:volume": "20", "dc:title": "Potential climate change impacts on green infrastructure vegetation", "prism:publicationName": "Urban Forestry and Urban Greening", "dc:publisher": "Elsevier GmbH info@urbanfischer.de", "prism:issn": "16108167", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:84986550747", "prism:startingPage": "128", "citedby-count": "0", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016 Elsevier GmbH This study investigated the impacts of successive simulated droughts and floods on two plant species (Carex lurida and Liriope muscari) commonly installed in green-infrastructure (GI) sites built in the urban northeast USA. The instantaneous stomatal conductance, and belowground biomass growth (in a second drought experiment only) were used as metrics, since they are indicators of the ability of plants to provide ecosystem functions such as transpiration and carbon uptake. The results indicate that both species have greater tolerance for floods than for droughts. Signs of stress were only evident after a simulated flood exceeding the duration of 95% of all storms that occurred in this geographic region between 1950 and 2000. By contrast, simulated droughts had a more pronounced effect on both the instantaneous conductance measures during drought and the recovery following the cessation of drought in both species. Liriope subjected to drought treatments were all able to recover and to re-establish stomatal conductance levels similar to those displayed by a control group even after repeated drought treatments. By contrast, Carex showed reduced recovery after multiple droughts, in two separate rounds of experiments. However, regardless of moisture conditions and treatment, Carex generally displayed higher stomatal conductance than Liriope, indicating greater transpiration, and CO2 uptake than Liriope. The belowground biomass results supported this finding, i.e. Carex gained more belowground biomass than Liriope during all experiments. At the end of the experiment, the Carex subjected to drought had less than one sixth the belowground biomass of the control treatment, whereas for Liriope this ratio was only 50% (drought to control). The drought treatments, therefore, reduced the biomass of Carex more than it did Liriope, when compared to the respective control plants. Nonetheless, both species survived repeated cycles of droughts and floods, suggesting that these particular species are both likely suitable for use in GI facilities, despite projected future increases in the frequency and intensity of floods and droughts in this geographic region. From a practical perspective, the results suggest no need for irrigation or potential replacement of plants in GI systems in a changed climate.", "source-id": "145301", "srctype": "j", "link": {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "902", "classification-description": "FLUIDEX; Related Topics"}}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2305"}, {"$": "2309"}, {"$": "2308"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENVI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 Elsevier B.V. Research on rain gardens generally focuses on hydrology, geochemistry, and vegetation. The role of soil invertebrates has largely been overlooked, despite their well-known impacts on soil nutrient storage, removal, and processing. Surveys of three rain gardens in Melbourne, Australia, revealed a soil invertebrate community structure that differed significantly among sites but was stable across sampling dates (July 2013 and April 2014). Megadrilacea (earthworms), Enchytraeidae (potworms), and Collembola (springtails) were abundant in all sites, and together accounted for a median of 80% of total soil invertebrate abundance. Earthworms were positively correlated to soil organic matter content, but the abundances of other taxonomic groups were not strongly related to organic matter content, plant cover, or root biomass across sites. While less than 5% of total soil N was estimated to be stored in the body tissues of these three taxa, and estimated N gas emissions from earthworms (N2O and N2) were low, ingestion and processing of soil was high (e.g., up to 417% of the upper 5\u00a0cm of soil ingested by earthworms annually in one site), suggesting that the contribution of these organisms to N cycling in rain gardens may be substantial. Thus, invertebrate communities represent an overlooked feature of rain garden design that can play an important role in the structure and function of these systems."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Lumbricidae"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "WSUD"}]}, "coredata": {"pii": "S092585741630516X", "prism:coverDate": "2016-12-01", "prism:volume": "97", "dc:title": "Soil invertebrates in Australian rain gardens and their potential roles in storage and processing of nitrogen", "prism:publicationName": "Ecological Engineering", "dc:publisher": "Elsevier", "prism:issn": "09258574", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:84987974003", "prism:startingPage": "138", "citedby-count": "0", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016 Elsevier B.V. Research on rain gardens generally focuses on hydrology, geochemistry, and vegetation. The role of soil invertebrates has largely been overlooked, despite their well-known impacts on soil nutrient storage, removal, and processing. Surveys of three rain gardens in Melbourne, Australia, revealed a soil invertebrate community structure that differed significantly among sites but was stable across sampling dates (July 2013 and April 2014). Megadrilacea (earthworms), Enchytraeidae (potworms), and Collembola (springtails) were abundant in all sites, and together accounted for a median of 80% of total soil invertebrate abundance. Earthworms were positively correlated to soil organic matter content, but the abundances of other taxonomic groups were not strongly related to organic matter content, plant cover, or root biomass across sites. While less than 5% of total soil N was estimated to be stored in the body tissues of these three taxa, and estimated N gas emissions from earthworms (N2O and N2) were low, ingestion and processing of soil was high (e.g., up to 417% of the upper 5\u00a0cm of soil ingested by earthworms annually in one site), suggesting that the contribution of these organisms to N cycling in rain gardens may be substantial. Thus, invertebrate communities represent an overlooked feature of rain garden design that can play an important role in the structure and function of these systems.", "source-id": "20291", "srctype": {"@type": "GEOCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "901", "classification-description": "Geobase; Related Topics"}}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2305"}, {"$": "2309"}, {"$": "2308"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENVI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 Elsevier B.V. Road runoff pollutants are widely recognized as major causes of receiving water pollution. Bioswale serves as an effective storm-water natural purification and disposal technology, which presents important practical value in controlling runoff pollution and stormwater utilization. Multiple bioswale cells with different media are designed and built. Artificial stormwater is synthesized on the basis of the investigated and measured data on the surface runoff pollution in Northwest China, which is used to study the purification effect of bioswale on runoff pollutants from four aspects. Results show that different factors significantly affect water purification process. The removal rate of nitrogen decreases with the increase of inflow concentration for most of media; however, which is contrary for phosphorus and mostly greater than 90%. Blast furnace slag has the best removal of nitrogen, phosphorus and heavy mental Zn under low inflow concentration. The correlation models between the purification effects of total nitrogen, total phosphorus and COD and their influencing factors are established using the multivariate regression method. The Nash-Suttcliffe simulation efficiency coefficients of the models are greater than 0.6.", "grantlist": {"grant-text": {"@xml:lang": "eng", "$": "This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant Nos. 51279158 and 51209168) and the Natural Science Foundation of Shaanxi Province (Grant No. 2015JZ013)."}, "@complete": "y", "grant": [{"grant-id": "2015JZ013", Road runoff pollutants are widely recognized as major causes of receiving water pollution. Bioswale serves as an effective storm-water natural purification and disposal technology, which presents important practical value in controlling runoff pollution and stormwater utilization. Multiple bioswale cells with different media are designed and built. Artificial stormwater is synthesized on the basis of the investigated and measured data on the surface runoff pollution in Northwest China, which is used to study the purification effect of bioswale on runoff pollutants from four aspects. Results show that different factors significantly affect water purification process. The removal rate of nitrogen decreases with the increase of inflow concentration for most of media; however, which is contrary for phosphorus and mostly greater than 90%. Blast furnace slag has the best removal of nitrogen, phosphorus and heavy mental Zn under low inflow concentration. The correlation models between the purification effects of total nitrogen, total phosphorus and COD and their influencing factors are established using the multivariate regression method. The Nash-Suttcliffe simulation efficiency coefficients of the models are greater than 0.6.", "source-id": "20291", "srctype": "j", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENGI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 The Authors. The use of rain gardens and other ecological rainwater management methods in urban areas aims, among others, at: 1) reduction of total rainwater runoff and of its peak and 2) reduction of property damage and activity disruption, which is due to insufficient sewer network capacity. While rain gardens cannot substitute sewer networks, they can be used as integral parts of sewer systems in a cost-efficient way. In this paper, integration of rain gardens in sewer systems is investigated, by means of a case study, in Thessaloniki, Greece. The effect of location and size of rain gardens is examined, together with the quality of local sewer network. Our calculations have shown that existing infrastructure is insufficient and that construction of rain gardens could substantially mitigate the nuisance caused by inundation of streets and sidewalks during rain events."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1016/j.proeng.2016.11.084", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "613648834"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "659056729"}, {"@idtype": {"ce:e-address": {"@type": "email", "$": "http://Pub.NL@taylorandfrancis.com"}, "publishername": "CRC Press/Balkema"}, "publicationyear": {"@first": "2016"}, "isbn": {"@length": "13", "@type": {"@xml:lang": "eng", "$": "Sustainable Buildings and Structures - Proceedings of the 1st International Conference on Sustainable Buildings and Structures, ICSBS 2015"}, "issuetitle": "Sustainable Buildings and Structures - Proceedings of the 1st International Conference on Sustainable Buildings and Structures, ICSBS 2015", "contributor-group": [{"contributor": {"@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Wilkinson S.P.", "ce:initials": "S.P.", "ce:given-name": "Stephen P.", "ce:surname": "Wilkinson", "@role": "edit"}}, {"contributor": {"@seq": "2", "ce:indexed-name": "Xia J.", "ce:initials": "J.", "ce:given-name": "Jun", "ce:surname": "Xia", "@role": "edit"}}, {"contributor": {"@seq": "3", "ce:indexed-name": "Chen B.", "ce:initials": "B.", "ce:given-name": "Bing", "ce:surname": "Chen", "@role": {"affiliation": {"country": "Iran", "organization": "Azad University of Gonbad-e Kavoos", "@afid": "116110080", "@country": "irn", "city": "Gonbad-e Kavoos, Golestan"}, "author": {"@auid": "57003368700", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Mostaed Shirehjini R.", "ce:initials": "R.", "ce:surname": "Mostaed Shirehjini", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Mostaed Shirehjini R.", "ce:given-name": "R.", "ce:surname": "Mostaed Shirehjini", "ce:initials": "R."}, "@type": "auth"}}, "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": "2215"}, {"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "402", "classification-description": "Buildings and Towers"}, {"classification-code": "403", "classification-description": "Urban and Regional Planning and Development"}, {"classification-code": "454.1", "classification-description": "Environmental Engineering, General"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "902", "classification-description": "FLUIDEX; Related Topics"}}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENGI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 Taylor &amp; Francis Group, London. To respond to the environmental concerns raised by patterns of human development, changing the way that land-use decisions are made, to adopt a sustainable framework is inescapable. In view of this fact, to limit the built environment impact on the natural environment, and therefore to produce a built environment that mimics and complements rather than conflicts with nature is emerging as a vital goal for those who design cities, neighborhoods, and buildings. At the same time, the second important factor for land-use planning is the term \u201clivability\u201d that describes quality of life and the characteristics of cities that make them livable. Traffic, health, safety, the environment, and many other factors are important to quality of life, and all are influenced in some way by the built environment. The key question of this paper is: whether and to what extent we can integrate environmentally friendly design concepts into our livable neighborhood. To find the relationship between \u201clivability\u201d and \u201csustainability\u201d in neighborhood design, this paper first highlights the key elements of livable neighborhoods, and their design components. Second, the environmental consequence of the elements will be determined. For example; how design for physical activities\u2014like providing walking paths\u2014can influence directly or indirectly on the environment. Moreover the paper seeks to find ways to add efficiency to sustainable design solutions. The results indicate the benefits and problems with environmentally designed livable neighborhoods."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "607274585"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "643112045"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20155101691012"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84949844087"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84949844087"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "19", "@month": "12", "@timestamp": "BST 17:09:29", "@year": "2015"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "43", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84949852483"}}, "ref-website": {"ce:e-address": {"@type": "email", "$": "http://www.aia.org/about/initiatives/AIAS075360"}}, "ref-text": "AIA, Livability 101 (What Makes A Community Livable?). Proceedings of the 1st International Conference on Sustainable Buildings and Structures, ICSBS 2015", "dc:creator": {"author": [{"@auid": "57003368700", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Mostaed Shirehjini R.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/57003368700", "ce:initials": "R.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/116110080", "@id": "116110080"}, "ce:surname": "Mostaed Shirehjini", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Mostaed Shirehjini R.", "ce:given-name": "R.", "ce:surname": "Mostaed Shirehjini", "ce:initials": "R."}}]}, "dc:publisher": "CRC Press/Balkema http://Pub.NL@taylorandfrancis.com", "prism:url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84949844087", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84949844087", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84949844087&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus-citedby", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84949844087&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "dc:description": "\u00a9 2016 Taylor &amp; Francis Group, London. To respond to the environmental concerns raised by patterns of human development, changing the way that land-use decisions are made, to adopt a sustainable framework is inescapable. In view of this fact, to limit the built environment impact on the natural environment, and therefore to produce a built environment that mimics and complements rather than conflicts with nature is emerging as a vital goal for those who design cities, neighborhoods, and buildings. At the same time, the second important factor for land-use planning is the term \u201clivability\u201d that describes quality of life and the characteristics of cities that make them livable. Traffic, health, safety, the environment, and many other factors are important to quality of life, and all are influenced in some way by the built environment. The key question of this paper is: whether and to what extent we can integrate environmentally friendly design concepts into our livable neighborhood. To find the relationship between \u201clivability\u201d and \u201csustainability\u201d in neighborhood design, this paper first highlights the key elements of livable neighborhoods, and their design components. Second, the environmental consequence of the elements will be determined. For example; how design for physical activities\u2014like providing walking paths\u2014can influence directly or indirectly on the environment. Moreover the paper seeks to find ways to add efficiency to sustainable design solutions. The results indicate the benefits and problems with environmentally designed livable neighborhoods.", "source-id": "21100429585", "eid": "2-s2.0-84949844087"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": "57003368700", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Mostaed Shirehjini R.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/57003368700", "ce:initials": "R.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/116110080", "@id": "116110080"}, "ce:surname": "Mostaed Shirehjini", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Mostaed Shirehjini R.", "ce:given-name": "R.", "ce:surname": "Mostaed Shirehjini", "ce:initials": "R."}}]}}}, {"abstracts-retrieval-response": {"language": {"@xml:lang": "eng"}, "item": {"ait:process-info": {"ait:date-sort": {"@day": "01", "@month": "04", "@year": "2016"}, "ait:status": {"@state": "update", "@stage": "S300", "@type": "core"}, "ait:date-delivered": {"@day": "13", "@month": "12", "@timestamp": "2016-12-13T05:37:07.000007+00:00", "@year": "2016"}}, "bibrecord": {"head": {"correspondence": {"person": {"ce:indexed-name": "Paus K.H.", "ce:given-name": "Kim H.", "ce:surname": "Paus", "ce:initials": "K.H."}, "ce:e-address": {"@type": "email", "$": "kim.paus@ntnu.no"}, "affiliation": {"city": "Trondheim", "@country": "nor", "country": "Norway", "address-part": "S.P. "ce:surname": "Braskerud", "ce:initials": "B.C."}, "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "442.1", "classification-description": "Flood Control"}, {"classification-code": "461.2", "classification-description": "Biological Materials"}, {"classification-code": "632.1", "79.25", "classification-description": "WATER ENGINEERING"}]}, {"@type": "GEOCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "70.11.1", "classification-description": "Environmental Assessment and Monitoring"}, {"classification-code": "71.6.5", "classification-description": "Runoff, streamflow and basins"}]}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": "2312"}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENVI"}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 IWA Publishing 2016. Three bioretention cells in Norway were monitored for 23 to 36 months to evaluate the hydrological performance of bioretention cells operated in regions with cold climates and to test if cell size equations can be used to predict hydrological performance. Values of saturated hydraulic conductivity (Ksat) were determined for separate events by analyzing the observed infiltration rates and via infiltration tests. The two cells with the highest Ksat values (15.9 and 45.0 cm/h) performed excellently during the study period infiltrating nearly all of the incoming runoff. In contrast, the cell with low Ksat value (1.3 cm/h) infiltrated barely half of the incoming runoff. The latter cell had a clear seasonal variation in hydrological performance relating to changes in the Ksat values over the year. The size equation that gave the best predictions of the observed hydrological performance accounts for both surface storage and infiltration. By using this equation to evaluate various bioretention cell designs, it was found that the most effective way to increase the hydrologic performance is to have a Ksat value above 10 cm/h."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.2166/nh.2015.084", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "610629509"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "651186666"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20162302476495"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016474958"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "4939509"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20161309012"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84971619647"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84971619647"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "08", "@month": "12", "@timestamp": "BST 15:49:16", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "47", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "535", "@last": "553"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "52", "@issue": "4"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Archer N.A.L.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Archer", "ce:initials": "N.A.L."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Quinton J.N.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Quinton", "ce:initials": "J.N."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Hess T.M.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Hess", "ce:initials": "T.M."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2002"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "0036896899"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Below-ground relationships of soil texture, roots and hydraulic conductivity in two-phase mosaic vegetation in South-east Spain"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "J. Three bioretention cells in Norway were monitored for 23 to 36 months to evaluate the hydrological performance of bioretention cells operated in regions with cold climates and to test if cell size equations can be used to predict hydrological performance. Values of saturated hydraulic conductivity (Ksat) were determined for separate events by analyzing the observed infiltration rates and via infiltration tests. The two cells with the highest Ksat values (15.9 and 45.0 cm/h) performed excellently during the study period infiltrating nearly all of the incoming runoff. In contrast, the cell with low Ksat value (1.3 cm/h) infiltrated barely half of the incoming runoff. The latter cell had a clear seasonal variation in hydrological performance relating to changes in the Ksat values over the year. The size equation that gave the best predictions of the observed hydrological performance accounts for both surface storage and infiltration. By using this equation to evaluate various bioretention cell designs, it was found that the most effective way to increase the hydrologic performance is to have a Ksat value above 10 cm/h.", "classification": [{"$": "2300"}, {"$": "2304"}, {"$": "2312"}, {"$": "2205"}]}, {"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "406", "classification-description": "Highway Engineering"}, {"classification-code": "632.1", "classification-description": "Hydraulics"}, {"classification-code": "741.1", "classification-description": "Light and Optics"}, {"classification-code": "802.3", "classification-description": "Chemical Operations"}, {"classification-code": "922.2", "classification-description": "Mathematical Statistics"}, {"classification-code": "931.2", "classification-description": "Physical Properties of Gases, Liquids and Solids"}, {"classification-code": "951", "classification-description": "Materials Science"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "78.23", "classification-description": "MIXING AND SEPARATION"}}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "ENVI"}, {"$": "ENGI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 ASCE. Engineered media used in living roofs and bioretention plays a crucial role in determining stormwater mitigation performance. Engineered media with compositions varying in four aggregates, volumetric ratio of compost (0, 10, and 20%) and three amendments (zeolite, paving sand, and topsoil) were prepared in the laboratory. Media basic properties including particle-size distribution (PSD), dry bulk density, particle density, porosity, and saturated hydraulic conductivity (Ks), were characterized and investigated as a function of the varying composition. All media are classified as poorly-graded sand (SP), exhibiting porosity greater than 0.51, with magnitudes of Ks ranging from 10-2 to 10-1 cm/s. Media with pumice-based aggregates have particle densities between 2.21 and 2.48 g/cm3. The Ks of a pure aggregate classified as SP is positively related to the particle size corresponding to 50% fines on the cumulative PSD curve. Ks values of four aggregates either remain unchanged or decrease by 73% at most with the addition of the compost. An amendment to an aggregate-compost mixture can alter Ks in different ways, depending on its particle shape, coarseness, and organic material."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1061/(ASCE)HE.1943-5584.0001373", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "610470444"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "650692705"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20162202431217"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016455394"}, {"@idtype": "FLX", "$": "1213176"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "4931153"}, {"@idtype": "REAXYSCAR", "$": "20161228370"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84969668291"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84969668291"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "FLX"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "REAXYSCAR"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "27", "@month": "05", "@timestamp": "BST 12:50:17", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "32", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-authors": {"collaboration": {"ce:indexed-name": "ASTM", "@seq": "1", "ce:text": "ASTM"}}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2006"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84969663504"}}, "ref-text": "West Conchohocken, PA", "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Standard test method for permeability of granular soils (constant head)."}, "ref-sourcetitle": "ASTM D2434-68"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "ASTM. "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84969668291&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "eid": "2-s2.0-84969668291", "prism:publicationName": "Journal of Hydrologic Engineering", "dc:creator": {"author": [{"@auid": "56710760400", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Liu R.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/56710760400", "ce:initials": "R.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60005686", "@id": "60005686"}, "ce:given-name": "Ruifen", "ce:surname": "Liu", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Liu R.", "ce:given-name": "Ruifen", "ce:surname": "Liu", "ce:initials": "R."}, "ce:degrees": "Ph.D."}]}, "dc:publisher": "American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) onlinejls@asce.org", "prism:issn": "10840699", "prism:url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84969668291", "dc:description": "\u00a9 ASCE. Engineered media used in living roofs and bioretention plays a crucial role in determining stormwater mitigation performance. Engineered media with compositions varying in four aggregates, volumetric ratio of compost (0, 10, and 20%) and three amendments (zeolite, paving sand, and topsoil) were prepared in the laboratory. Media basic properties including particle-size distribution (PSD), dry bulk density, particle density, porosity, and saturated hydraulic conductivity (Ks), were characterized and investigated as a function of the varying composition. All media are classified as poorly-graded sand (SP), exhibiting porosity greater than 0.51, with magnitudes of Ks ranging from 10-2 to 10-1 cm/s. Media with pumice-based aggregates have particle densities between 2.21 and 2.48 g/cm3. The Ks of a pure aggregate classified as SP is positively related to the particle size corresponding to 50% fines on the cumulative PSD curve. Ks values of four aggregates either remain unchanged or decrease by 73% at most with the addition of the compost. An amendment to an aggregate-compost mixture can alter Ks in different ways, depending on its particle shape, coarseness, and organic material.", "article-number": "06016002", "srctype": "j"}, ATMOSPHERE"}}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "COMP"}, {"$": "SOCI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2016 IEEE. Green stormwater infrastructure is of great significance to alleviate urban waterlogging and build healthy urban water cycle. Traditional stormwater infrastructure is not a good solution to the problem of urban flooding, contrary causes more serious consequences. When the green stormwater infrastructure is used to build urban rainwater recycling system, it should be combined with the landscape, highlighting its aesthetics, ecology, culture. Combined with outstanding cases at home and abroad, the paper analyzes the rain gardens, green streets, ecological park these three typical green stormwater infrastructure, and sums up the landscape policy of green stormwater infrastructure in order to provide reference for 'sponge city'."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1109/ICITBS.2015.147", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "610013705"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "649369872"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20161702294333"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84963900682"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84963900682"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "25", "@month": "04", "@timestamp": "BST 05:59:29", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "12", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "22", "@last": "27"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "4"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Wei Z.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Wei", "ce:initials": "Z."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Wu C.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Wu", "ce:initials": "C."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Wang J.-L.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Wang", "ce:initials": "J.-L."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Wang S.-S.", "@seq": "4", "ce:surname": "Wang", "ce:initials": "S.-S."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2011"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84963803886"}}, "ref-text": "in Chinese", "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Management of urban stormwater runoff by green infrastructures [J]"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "China Water &amp; Wastewater"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Zhang Wei, Che Wu, Wang Jian-long, Wang Si-si. Green stormwater infrastructure is of great significance to alleviate urban waterlogging and build healthy urban water cycle. Traditional stormwater infrastructure is not a good solution to the problem of urban flooding, contrary causes more serious consequences. When the green stormwater infrastructure is used to build urban rainwater recycling system, it should be combined with the landscape, highlighting its aesthetics, ecology, culture. Combined with outstanding cases at home and abroad, the paper analyzes the rain gardens, green streets, ecological park these three typical green stormwater infrastructure, and sums up the landscape policy of green stormwater infrastructure in order to provide reference for 'sponge city'.", "article-number": "7384093", "srctype": "p"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": "57188861401", "@seq": "1", "BUSI"}, {"$": "ENVI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "With the environmental degradation, how to build the ecological sponge city has become an important problem which needs to be solved urgently. This paper established the input-output based life cycle assessment model. By taking one rain garden as an example, the life cycle greenhouse gas emissions as well as the distribution of it in the production chain are calculated. The results indicate that the input-output based life cycle assessment model can comprehensively evaluate the impacts of sponge city construction on greenhouse gas emissions, which has a certain reference value for designing supportive policies of sponge city."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "612256070"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "655511752"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20163902832050"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84988005827"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84988005827"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "23", "@month": "09", "@timestamp": "BST 05:44:11", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "17", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "316", "@last": "326"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "75"}}, "ref-authors": {"et-al": null, "author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Soratana K.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Soratana", "ce:initials": "K."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Harden CheyenneL", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Harden CheyenneL"}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Zaimes G.G.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Zaimes", "ce:initials": "G.G."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2014"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84921846936"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "The role of sustainability and life cycle thinking in U.S. Biofuels policies[J]"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Energy Policy"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Kullapa Soratana, CheyenneL. "abstracts": "\u00a9 2015, Springer Science+Business Media Dordrecht. Recognized as an effective low impact development (LID) practice, rain gardens have been widely advocated to be built with urban landscaping for stormwater runoff reduction through the retention and infiltration processes; but the field performance and regional effect of rain gardens have not been thoroughly investigated. In this paper, we presented a four-year monitoring study on the performance of a rain garden on stormwater retention; hydrological models were proposed to predict the potential effect of rain gardens on runoff reduction under different storms and the future urban development scenarios. The experimental rain garden was constructed in a sub-humid loess region in Xi\u2019an, China; it has a contributing area ratio of 20:1 and depth of 15\u00a0cm. During the study period, we observed 28 large storm events, but only 5 of them caused overflow from the rain garden. The flow reduction rate for the overflow events ranged from 77 to 94\u00a0%. The runoff coefficient from the contributing area (RC) was reduced to less than 0.02 on annual basis, and 0.008 over the four years average. Field observations also showed that infiltration rate remained stable during the operation period. The predictions based on the future landuse and storm variability of the study area showed that by converting a small fraction of the city land area into rain gardens, the negative hydrological effect from expansion of impervious area can be reduced significantly. The challenge, however, lies in how to plan and build rain gardens as an integral part of the urban landscape."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1007/s11269-015-1206-5", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "607151446"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "642817262"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20155001650880"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016182399"}, {"@idtype": "FLX", "$": "1171085"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "4806514"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84957433628"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84957433628"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "FLX"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "18", "@month": "02", "@timestamp": "BST 05:00:57", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "25", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "132", "@last": "143"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "137", "@issue": "3"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Brown R.A.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Brown", "ce:initials": "R.A."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Hunt W.F.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Hunt", "ce:initials": "W.F."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2011"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "79952341063"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Impacts of media depth on effluent water quality and hydrologic performance of undersized bioretention cells"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "J Irrig Drain Eng"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Brown RA, Hunt WF (2011) Impacts of media depth on effluent water quality and hydrologic performance of undersized bioretention cells. Water Resour Manag 11(2):136\u2013164"}, {"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "149", "@last": "168"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "28", "@issue": "1"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Zhang S.H.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Zhang", "ce:initials": "S.H."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Guo Y.P.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Guo", "ce:initials": "Y.P."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2014"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84890865600"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Stormwater capture efficiency of bioretention systems"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Water Resour Manag"}, "@id": "25", "ref-fulltext": "Zhang SH, Guo YP (2014) Stormwater capture efficiency of bioretention systems. Water Resour Manag 28(1):149\u2013168"}]}}}}, "subject-areas": {"subject-area": [{"@code": "2312", "@abbrev": "ENVI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Water Science and Technology"}, {"@code": "2205", "@abbrev": "ENGI", "@_fa": "true", "$": "Civil and Structural Engineering"}]}, "idxterms": {"mainterm": [{"$": "Design storms"}, {"$": "LID"}, {"$": "Overflow"}, {"$": "Rain gardens"}, {"$": "Storm runoff"}], "@candidate": "n", "@weight": "b"}, "affiliation": [{"affiliation-country": "United States", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60004923", "@id": "60004923", "affiliation-city": "Raleigh", "affilname": "North Carolina State University"}, {"affiliation-country": "China", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60007381", "@id": "60007381", "affiliation-city": "Yangzhou", "affilname": "Yangzhou University"}, {"affiliation-country": "China", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60026981", "@id": "60026981", "affiliation-city": "Xi'an", "affilname": "Xi'an University of Technology"}], "authkeywords": {"author-keyword": [{"@_fa": "true", "$": "Design storm"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Infiltration"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "LID"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Overflow"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Rain garden"}, {"@_fa": "true", "$": "Storm runoff"}]}, "coredata": {"prism:volume": "30", "prism:coverDate": "2016-02-01", "prism:doi": "10.1007/s11269-015-1206-5", "dc:title": "Evaluating Retention Capacity of Infiltration Rain Gardens and Their Potential Effect on Urban Stormwater Management in the Sub-Humid Loess Region of China", "prism:publicationName": "Water Resources Management", "dc:publisher": "Springer Netherlands", "prism:issn": "15731650", "dc:identifier": "SCOPUS_ID:84957433628", "prism:startingPage": "983", "citedby-count": "0", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2015, Springer Science+Business Media Dordrecht. Recognized as an effective low impact development (LID) practice, rain gardens have been widely advocated to be built with urban landscaping for stormwater runoff reduction through the retention and infiltration processes; but the field performance and regional effect of rain gardens have not been thoroughly investigated. In this paper, we presented a four-year monitoring study on the performance of a rain garden on stormwater retention; hydrological models were proposed to predict the potential effect of rain gardens on runoff reduction under different storms and the future urban development scenarios. The experimental rain garden was constructed in a sub-humid loess region in Xi\u2019an, China; it has a contributing area ratio of 20:1 and depth of 15\u00a0cm. During the study period, we observed 28 large storm events, but only 5 of them caused overflow from the rain garden. The flow reduction rate for the overflow events ranged from 77 to 94\u00a0%. The runoff coefficient from the contributing area (RC) was reduced to less than 0.02 on annual basis, and 0.008 over the four years average. Field observations also showed that infiltration rate remained stable during the operation period. The predictions based on the future landuse and storm variability of the study area showed that by converting a small fraction of the city land area into rain gardens, the negative hydrological effect from expansion of impervious area can be reduced significantly. The challenge, however, lies in how to plan and build rain gardens as an integral part of the urban landscape.", "source-id": "18853", "srctype": "j", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": L.", "ce:surname": "Lau", "ce:initials": "T.L."}, "@type": "auth"}}, {"affiliation": {"city": "Kelantan", "@country": "mys", "country": "Malaysia", "@afid": "60000906", "organization": [{"$": "Environment and Occupational Health Programme"}, {"$": "School of Health Sciences"}, {"$": "Health Campus"}, {"$": "Universiti Sains Malaysia"}], "@dptid": "113493759"}, "author": {"@auid": "56844951100", "@seq": "4", "ce:indexed-name": "Foo K.Y.", "ce:initials": "K.Y.", "ce:surname": "Foo", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Foo K.", "ce:given-name": "K. Y.", "ce:surname": "Foo", "ce:initials": "K.Y."}, "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "3305"}, {"$": "2312"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "SOCI"}, {"$": "ENVI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2015 Taylor &amp; Francis. A well-designed engineered soil for bioretention is important as it ensures that pollutant removal requirements are met. This laboratory study investigated the nutrient removal efficiency of bioretention media enhanced with 10% (by volume) additives from various waste materials (cockle shell, newspaper, printed paper, coconut husk and tyre crumb) and planted with Red Hot Chinese Hibiscus (Hibiscus rosa-sinensis), a common landscape shrub in tropical countries. The results showed that media enhanced with shredded newspaper demonstrated a significant improvement in total nitrogen (TN) removal (80.4%), compared to standard bioretention media (57.5%) without compromising total suspended solids (TSS) and total phosphorus (TP) removal, when dosed with actual runoff. The thick root system and rapid growth rate of the plant was proven to contribute to TN removal. This study concluded that shredded newspaper can be a potential addition to enhance bioretention media performance in treating stormwater, especially nutrient rich runoff from mixed development areas."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1080/1573062X.2015.1076861", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "606037619"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "639931777"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016071627"}, {"@idtype": "FLX", "$": "1154018"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "4760242"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84941686698"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84941686698"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "FLX"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "20", "@month": "09", "@timestamp": "BST 04:23:46", "@year": "2015"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "45", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "W04512"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "47", "@issue": "4"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Arora B.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Arora", "ce:initials": "B."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Mohanty B.P.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Mohanty", "ce:initials": "B.P."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Mcguire J.T.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Mcguire", "ce:initials": "J.T."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2011"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "79955051941"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Inverse estimation of parameters for multidomain flow models in soil columns with different macropore densities"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "Water Resources Research"}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Arora, B., Mohanty, B.P., and Mcguire, J.T., 2011. A well-designed engineered soil for bioretention is important as it ensures that pollutant removal requirements are met. This laboratory study investigated the nutrient removal efficiency of bioretention media enhanced with 10% (by volume) additives from various waste materials (cockle shell, newspaper, printed paper, coconut husk and tyre crumb) and planted with Red Hot Chinese Hibiscus (Hibiscus rosa-sinensis), a common landscape shrub in tropical countries. The results showed that media enhanced with shredded newspaper demonstrated a significant improvement in total nitrogen (TN) removal (80.4%), compared to standard bioretention media (57.5%) without compromising total suspended solids (TSS) and total phosphorus (TP) removal, when dosed with actual runoff. The thick root system and rapid growth rate of the plant was proven to contribute to TN removal. This study concluded that shredded newspaper can be a potential addition to enhance bioretention media performance in treating stormwater, especially nutrient rich runoff from mixed development areas.", "source-id": "4500151528", "srctype": "j", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84941686698", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84941686698&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus-citedby", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84941686698&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "dc:creator": {"author": [{"@auid": "56844924900", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Goh H.W.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/56844924900", "ce:initials": "H.W.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60000906", "@id": "60000906"}, "ce:surname": "Goh", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Goh H.", "ce:given-name": "H. "454.1", "classification-description": "Environmental Engineering, General"}, {"classification-code": "483.1", "classification-description": "Soils and Soil Mechanics"}, {"classification-code": "804", "classification-description": "Production Engineering"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "78.23", "classification-description": "MIXING AND SEPARATION"}, {"classification-code": "79.26", "classification-description": "WASTEWATER AND OTHER EFFLUENT/LIQUID WASTE ENGIN."}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": "ENVI"}]}}, "abstracts": "Many structural best management practices (BMPs) were installed as part of the storm drainage system in a city in North Dakota. The designs of existing BMPs were largely dependent on the state and city's runoff volume requirements, rather than the pollutant removal efficiency of the BMPs. The framework for assessment of the efficiency of a BMP in a cold region was limited, and hence, an initiative was carried out to gauge the performance of the existing BMPs. An assessment plan, including monitoring hydrologic and water quality parameters, was established before the arrival of any spring runoff. Based on the successful captures of the first summer's storm events, the performance of a BMP was assessed. The average removal efficiency of the nutrients was 73% for total phosphorus and 40% for nitrate as nitrogen. Conductivity was found to increase between the influent and the effluent concentrations. Measurements on total suspended solids, phosphate and bacteria showed certain removal efficiency, but were not proven to be statistically significant. Parameters of ammonia as nitrogen, nitrite as nitrogen, total copper, total lead, total zinc, chloride, pH, and dissolved oxygen did not suggest effective removal trends. Attenuations of storm peaks were confirmed. A continuation of the assessment plan was carried out in the second summer using two more automatic samplers. However, inconsistent results were found for cases of incomplete sampling over the full-event times. On the operational aspect, derivations of the probable number of storms of a certain depth for the city has proven very useful for confirming a field trip decision ahead of the arrival of a forecasted storm."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1061/9780784479858.033", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "611038305"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "652108924"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20162702561449"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84976509144"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84976509144"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "05", "@month": "07", "@timestamp": "BST 05:13:29", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "16", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-sourcetitle": "Stormwater BMP Design Supplement for Cold Climates", "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84971594053"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Caraco D.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Caraco", "ce:initials": "D."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Claytor R.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Claytor", "ce:initials": "R."}]}, "ref-text": "Center for Watershed Protection, Ellicott City, MD", "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "1997"}}, "@id": "1", "ref-fulltext": "Caraco, D. Papers from Sessions of the Proceedings of the 2016 World Environmental and Water Resources Congress", "dc:creator": {"author": [{"@auid": "8641807200", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Lim Y.H.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/8641807200", "ce:initials": "Y.H.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60026161", "@id": "60026161"}, "ce:given-name": "Yeo Howe", "ce:surname": "Lim", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Lim Y.", "ce:given-name": "Yeo Howe", "ce:surname": "Lim", "ce:initials": "Y.H."}}]}, "dc:publisher": "American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) onlinejls@asce.org", "prism:url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84976509144", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84976509144", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84976509144&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus-citedby", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84976509144&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "dc:description": "Many structural best management practices (BMPs) were installed as part of the storm drainage system in a city in North Dakota. The designs of existing BMPs were largely dependent on the state and city's runoff volume requirements, rather than the pollutant removal efficiency of the BMPs. The framework for assessment of the efficiency of a BMP in a cold region was limited, and hence, an initiative was carried out to gauge the performance of the existing BMPs. An assessment plan, including monitoring hydrologic and water quality parameters, was established before the arrival of any spring runoff. Based on the successful captures of the first summer's storm events, the performance of a BMP was assessed. The average removal efficiency of the nutrients was 73% for total phosphorus and 40% for nitrate as nitrogen. Conductivity was found to increase between the influent and the effluent concentrations. Measurements on total suspended solids, phosphate and bacteria showed certain removal efficiency, but were not proven to be statistically significant. Parameters of ammonia as nitrogen, nitrite as nitrogen, total copper, total lead, total zinc, chloride, pH, and dissolved oxygen did not suggest effective removal trends. Attenuations of storm peaks were confirmed. A continuation of the assessment plan was carried out in the second summer using two more automatic samplers. However, inconsistent results were found for cases of incomplete sampling over the full-event times. On the operational aspect, derivations of the probable number of storms of a certain depth for the city has proven very useful for confirming a field trip decision ahead of the arrival of a forecasted storm.", "source-id": "21100466763", "srctype": "p"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": "8641807200", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Lim Y.H.", "author-url": E.", "ce:surname": "Line", "ce:initials": "D.E."}, "@type": "auth"}}, {"affiliation": {"city": "Greenville", "@country": "usa", "country": "United States", "state": "NC", "@afid": "60016280", "organization": [{"$": "Dept. of Biology"}, {"$": "East Carolina Univ."}], "@dptid": "100277652", "postal-code": "27981"}, "author": {"@auid": "7401767333", "@seq": "2", "ce:indexed-name": "White N.M.", "ce:initials": "N.M.", "ce:surname": "White", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "White N.", "ce:given-name": "N. M.", "ce:surname": "White", "ce:initials": "N.M."}, "@type": "auth"}}], "enhancement": {"classificationgroup": {"classifications": [{"@type": "CPXCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "403", "classification-description": "Urban and Regional Planning and Development"}, {"classification-code": "403.1", "classification-description": "Urban Planning and Development"}, {"classification-code": "442.1", "classification-description": "Flood Control"}, {"classification-code": "443.3", "classification-description": "Precipitation"}]}, {"@type": "FLXCLASS", "classification": {"classification-code": "79.25", "classification-description": "WATER ENGINEERING"}}, {"@type": "GEOCLASS", "classification": [{"classification-code": "70.10.1", "classification-description": "National and Land-Use Planning"}, {"classification-code": "71.6.5", "classification-description": "Runoff, streamflow and basins"}]}, {"@type": "ASJC", "classification": [{"$": "2305"}, {"$": "2304"}, {"$": "2205"}, {"$": "2300"}]}, {"@type": "SUBJABBR", "classification": [{"$": "ENVI"}, {"$": "ENGI"}]}]}}, "abstracts": "\u00a9 2015 American Society of Civil Engineers. Storm rainfall on and runoff from a 3.35-ha low-impact development (LID) residential subdivision in the Piedmont region of North Carolina were monitored for 6+ years, which included predevelopment, during-development, and postdevelopment phases. Runoff was monitored and sampled at two stations using automated samplers. Along with residences, the drainage area to one of the stations (PC1) included an undisturbed wooded riparian buffer with level spreaders to distribute runoff, while the area to the other station (PC2) included four bioretention areas, permeable pavement, a roof runoff collection system, a detention pond, and other LID measures. Monitoring results documented that the postdevelopment, runoff to rainfall ratio, and pollutant export at both stations were significantly greater than those of the predevelopment phase, during which time the land use on the site was mature woods. The total nitrogen (TN), total phosphorus (TP), and total suspended solids (TSS) export at both LID monitoring stations was 23 to 92% less than those from a nearby conventionally-developed subdivision monitored previously. These data indicated that LID subdivisions constructed on moderately to slowly permeable soils may not be able to maintain the runoff to rainfall ratio and TN, TP, and TSS export if the predevelopment land use was mature woods; however, if the predevelopment land use was cropland mixed with woods, then it may be possible to maintain predevelopment runoff to rainfall ratio and TN, TP, and TSS export. Further, the extensive use of LID techniques/measures in this residential subdivision resulted in less TN, TP, and TSS export compared to a similar conventional subdivision."}, "item-info": {"itemidlist": {"ce:doi": "10.1061/(ASCE)EE.1943-7870.0001018", "itemid": [{"@idtype": "PUI", "$": "607345850"}, {"@idtype": "CAR-ID", "$": "643354567"}, {"@idtype": "CHEM", "$": "2015818470"}, {"@idtype": "CPX", "$": "20155201715020"}, {"@idtype": "EMBIO", "$": "2016210602"}, {"@idtype": "FLX", "$": "1173925"}, {"@idtype": "GEO", "$": "4817160"}, {"@idtype": "SCP", "$": "84950336435"}, {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "84950336435"}]}, "dbcollection": [{"$": "CHEM"}, {"$": "CPX"}, {"$": "EMBIO"}, {"$": "FLX"}, {"$": "GEO"}, {"$": "Scopusbase"}], "copyright": {"@type": "Elsevier", "$": "Copyright 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved."}, "history": {"date-created": {"@day": "11", "@month": "05", "@timestamp": "BST 19:38:37", "@year": "2016"}}}, "tail": {"bibliography": {"@refcount": "20", "reference": [{"ref-info": {"ref-volisspag": {"pagerange": {"@first": "693", "@last": "708"}, "voliss": {"@volume": "41", "@issue": "3"}}, "ref-authors": {"author": [{"ce:indexed-name": "Carle M.V.", "@seq": "1", "ce:surname": "Carle", "ce:initials": "M.V."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Halpin P.N.", "@seq": "2", "ce:surname": "Halpin", "ce:initials": "P.N."}, {"ce:indexed-name": "Stow C.A.", "@seq": "3", "ce:surname": "Stow", "ce:initials": "C.A."}]}, "ref-publicationyear": {"@first": "2005"}, "refd-itemidlist": {"itemid": {"@idtype": "SGR", "$": "21744442631"}}, "ref-title": {"ref-titletext": "Patterns of watershed urbanization and impacts on water quality"}, "ref-sourcetitle": "J. "dc:title": "Runoff and pollutant export from a LID subdivision in North Carolina", "prism:doi": "10.1061/(ASCE)EE.1943-7870.0001018", "intid": "84950336435", "prism:coverDate": "2016-01-01", "prism:aggregationType": "Journal", "link": [{"@rel": "self", "@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84950336435", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84950336435&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}, {"@rel": "scopus-citedby", "@href": "https://www.scopus.com/inward/citedby.uri?partnerID=HzOxMe3b&amp;scp=84950336435&amp;origin=inward", "@_fa": "true"}], "eid": "2-s2.0-84950336435", "prism:publicationName": "Journal of Environmental Engineering (United States)", "dc:creator": {"author": [{"@auid": "7004003124", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Line D.E.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/7004003124", "ce:initials": "D.E.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60004923", "@id": "60004923"}, "ce:surname": "Line", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Line D.", "ce:given-name": "D. E.", "ce:surname": "Line", "ce:initials": "D.E."}}]}, "dc:publisher": "American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) onlinejls@asce.org", "prism:issn": "07339372", "prism:url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/abstract/scopus_id/84950336435", "dc:description": "\u00a9 2015 American Society of Civil Engineers. Storm rainfall on and runoff from a 3.35-ha low-impact development (LID) residential subdivision in the Piedmont region of North Carolina were monitored for 6+ years, which included predevelopment, during-development, and postdevelopment phases. Runoff was monitored and sampled at two stations using automated samplers. Along with residences, the drainage area to one of the stations (PC1) included an undisturbed wooded riparian buffer with level spreaders to distribute runoff, while the area to the other station (PC2) included four bioretention areas, permeable pavement, a roof runoff collection system, a detention pond, and other LID measures. Monitoring results documented that the postdevelopment, runoff to rainfall ratio, and pollutant export at both stations were significantly greater than those of the predevelopment phase, during which time the land use on the site was mature woods. The total nitrogen (TN), total phosphorus (TP), and total suspended solids (TSS) export at both LID monitoring stations was 23 to 92% less than those from a nearby conventionally-developed subdivision monitored previously. These data indicated that LID subdivisions constructed on moderately to slowly permeable soils may not be able to maintain the runoff to rainfall ratio and TN, TP, and TSS export if the predevelopment land use was mature woods; however, if the predevelopment land use was cropland mixed with woods, then it may be possible to maintain predevelopment runoff to rainfall ratio and TN, TP, and TSS export. Further, the extensive use of LID techniques/measures in this residential subdivision resulted in less TN, TP, and TSS export compared to a similar conventional subdivision.", "source-id": "23355", "srctype": "j"}, "authors": {"author": [{"@auid": "7004003124", "@seq": "1", "ce:indexed-name": "Line D.E.", "author-url": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/author/author_id/7004003124", "ce:initials": "D.E.", "affiliation": {"@href": "http://api.elsevier.com/content/affiliation/affiliation_id/60004923", "@id": "60004923"}, "ce:surname": "Line", "@_fa": "true", "preferred-name": {"ce:indexed-name": "Line D.", "ce:given-name": "D.
